Introverts may be annoyed by the profusion of loud televisions at gyms, airports, doctor’s waiting rooms, elevators, etc., but I think it’s quite a stretch to suggest that introverts are being discriminated against. The book states that introverts get better grades in school and states repeatedly that one-third to one-half of all people are introverts. Is it really possible that we live in an “extroverted world”?In my opinion, this book is just an amalgam of second-hand knowledge about stuff related to introversion (some of it only vaguely related, such as the habits of fruit flies). The author’s theories are supported more by cherry-picked anecdotes than scientific evidence. I think a book written by an actual psychologist – perhaps even an analytical psychologist – might have a more insightful theory about introversion.There are many things this book could have discussed but did not. For example, if our educational system makes class participation part of a student’s grade, how should class participation be measured in a way that would not favor extroverts? How exactly can introverts use written communication via the internet to harness their power in ways that are not possible using only local, face-to-face communication? How can we re-design waiting areas to ensure that there is a quiet, well-lit space where people can read or do some other activity that requires concentration, without being bombarded by unwanted sensory stimuli?Finally, I found this book to be very culturally specific to well-off people from industrialized countries. I doubt this book would have much relevance to most people. I guess the word “world” in the subtitle is just meant to refer to the “world” of the author.

I wish I could require every conference session leader in the Western world to read this book. You know the type: those perky people who take the podium and say things like "Before we start, shake hands with and greet at least three people you don't know." Arrrrrggggh. Like it's not already taking every ounce of energy I have to sit here in a room full of a hundred strangers.Cain confirms with data from various studies what I've observed time and again: In group/committee situations, those who speak with assertiveness and eloquence get their ideas implemented. Those who aren't so bold or persuasive are largely ignored, even if their ideas are demonstrably better than those of the loudmou--- er, extroverts.Cain also discloses that Harvard Business School teaches its students to speak with absolute conviction, even if they're only 55% sure they're correct. I would recommend this book for everyone, but I can't imagine most extroverts bothering, since the U.S. is already set up to cater to them. So I'll recommend it for the introverts, who could likely use the pep talk it delivers.

“Persistence isn’t very glamorous. If genius is one percent inspiration and ninety-nine percent perspiration, then as a culture we tend to lionize the one percent. We love its flash and dazzle. But great power lies in the other ninety-nine percent”  Wow. Can I just say this book has changed my life!?  This book was freaking phenomenal. It was enlightening and helped me understand myself better in myriad ways.  Just like a lot of other people, I watched Susan Cain's TED talk about the power of introverts and what she said during the presentation really spoke to me. I am, without a doubt, the classic introvert. For as long as I can remember, I always felt very isolated from the rest of my peers. In high school, I never recognized that my distaste for small talk and parties was linked to an innate part of my being. I prefer to spend the vast majority of my time alone. I am perfectly content with spending my day reading, writing, and studying. When I took the MBTI, I was like 90% introverted. Was I surprised? Nope. Still, despite being an introvert, I need to socialize with others, BUT when I do engage in a conversation, I want it to be a highly stimulating and deep topic. It is only after I get to know a person on a deeper level that I can enjoy having small talk with them. I understand most people on Goodreads are introverted themselves, and probably empathize with the confusion I felt for most of my life. It was not until I graduated high school that I understood why I am the way I am. Taking courses related to personality psychology helped me connect the dots about why I interact with my environment the way that I do. Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking is an informative book. Although it is filled with personal anecdotes, most of the book features different case studies and research projects that have been conducted to understand human behavior. Although I enjoy reading memoirs and biographies, most of the non-fiction readings I do are for school, so getting into this book was a bit challenging, but once I became used to the writing style I did not want to put this book down. I learned a great deal about myself, as well as how I can interact with others who have a different personality type than mine. The terms "introvert" and "extrovert" in this book are told from a cultural perspective. People who identify themselves as soft-spoken, deep, quiet and so forth, will find themselves identifying with the introvert personality type whereas people who believe they are vivacious, outgoing and so forth will identify with being an extrovert.  In essence, Susan Cain is comparing and contrasting the paradigm of the man who acts and the man who contemplates.  But the author acknowledges that personality psychologists believe that some of the characteristics that are identified in this book are not part of the introvert/extrovert spectrum, but rather within the categories of "openness to new experiences" and "neuroticism".In this book, Susan Cain presents us with people throughout history like Rosa Parks, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Mahatma Gandhi  who were quiet, but formidable and persistent when driven by a good cause.  Despite these great influencers, in the West, we continue to believe introvert and fortitude are antonyms. But why? And where did this notion come from? Cain answers these questions in the book. Something that I found fascinating was all the biological mechanisms at play that influence our temperament. I always assumed I was introverted as a result of my upbringing and South Asian cultural background. However, I learned that introvert brains work differently than extrovert brains, and this is crucial for us to understand. No matter where we fall on the spectrum, we have a balance of personalities in our society for a reason. There are positive qualities to both, but often being an introvert is stigmatized - especially in Western culture. I also realized the advantages of being an introvert because I always viewed my true nature as a drawback. In the book, Cain states that academia is full of introverts and it is not because one temperament type is smarter than the other. Introverts and extroverts have the same IQ results more or less. However, what sets introverts apart is our ability to engage in deliberate practice and flow. We can spend a lot of time in solitude while delaying gratification - an essential quality for any type of academic success. And since we do not crave as much social stimulation, we can spend more hours on studying because everybody only gets 24 hours in a day and how we use those hours can sometimes be linked to our temperaments. But I walk away from this book with a greater understanding of who I am as a person, and how I can still succeed despite having a soft-spoken demeanor. I guess the reason why I found this book to be life-changing is because I often felt isolated. When I first started university, I despised the small talk during orientation week and I just wanted to run back to my dorm, read books and face time with a close friend. I always knew what introversion and extroversion meant, but this book contained so much profound information that it helped me make sense of who I am. I recommend this book for those who are introverted themselves or are close to an introvert and looking for ways to support them. It will enable introverts and extroverts to understand how they can use their temperament to their advantage. There are always many paths to a fulfilling life :) I wanted to end this review with a quote I found in the book by Kafka that I loved!  “You said that you would like to sit beside me while I write. Listen in that case I could not write at all. For writing means revealing oneself to excess; the utmost of self-revelation and surrender, in which a human being, when involved with others, would feel he was losing himself, and from which, therefore, he will always shrink as long as he is in his right mind.... That is why one can never be alone enough when one writes, why there can never be enough silence around one when one writes, why even night is not night enough”

Quiet could easily have been a doctoral dissertation. It is that well researched and uses a wide and diverse variety of sources. It is cross-referenced throughout and a real bonus is its extensive resource summary for future reading and exploration. The good news is that it is not a dry, academic paper. It is a well written, lively read. Susan Cain has apparently wanted to be a writer since she was four but at first detoured to train and practise as a corporate lawyer, specializing in negotiation. She admits that if she couldn’t be a writer she would choose to be a psychology researcher and is fascinated by human nature. The book, seven years in the making, definitely demonstrates her research capability. It is the backbone of the book along with Cain’s obvious passion for her subject matter.The book is easy to read and filled with real people and real life examples who bring the topic to life. The writing is always thoughtful and thought provoking, sometimes kind or humourous and often fierce. You can tell that Cain strongly believes that introverts have been given a raw deal, are undervalued and have much to offer the world.Cain makes a strong case illustrating that the current North American culture in particular is skewed heavily in favour of accommodation, influence and success for extraverts. (Did you catch that? A light bulb flash moment for me - you can even spell it “extra” vert rather than “extro” vert if you wish. Now how “extra” special and skewed is that, especially considering how powerful words are?) The book explores the differences between extroverts and introverts - primarily differences in how much stimulation their true nature requires to be at its best or optimum level of being and doing. Cain documents the strengths of introverts and the type of activities they are especially good at.Anyone who reads this book will better understand a large percentage of people in the world; either one out of every three people or one out of every two people, depending on how recent a study you use. Either way, introverts make up a large part of the world. That in and of itself, suggests they should be included not discounted and encouraged to continue with their valuable contributions. Interestingly enough there are introverts and extroverts in the animal and insect kingdoms as well and the culture of many countries can also be categorized using the same introvert and extrovert differentiation. Parents, teachers, coaches, bosses, partners, co-workers, friends, political and business leaders and anyone who is in contact with introverts in their daily lives (pretty much the whole world) should read this book. Reading by the way is a very introverted undertaking – going within, for quiet stimulation to refuel rather than looking outside for stronger, more active stimulation to get recharged. The writing in Quiet is excellent and flowed very easily. In addition to solid informative research, it was a very enjoyable read brought to life with numerous anecdotes and stories. Basically, Quiet is a celebration of introversion. Anyone growing up or grown up, who heard themselves described as an introvert or who prefers the company of one or two close friends rather than large, social groups of friends, or who likes in depth conversations one on one or with a few people rather than group chit chats with many people interjecting, will see themselves in this book and celebrate. Anyone who doesn’t fit into the introversion category, based on the odds, knows someone and probably an important someone someone who would be categorized as an introvert. For this reason alone, Quiet is worth reading for insight into such important people in your life. I’d recommend that you make some quiet time for yourself and read Quiet – Goodreads Choice Award for Best Nonfiction for 2012.

An old Robert Benchley joke says "There are two kinds of people in the world: those who divide the world into two kinds of people, and those who don't." The author belongs to the former. Dividing everyone into just two types leads to oversimplifications and stereotypes that muddle things as much as they clarify. This book was supposedly based on years of research synthesizing all that is known on the issue. Instead, it is written in a chit-chatty style with many anecdotes from the author ("Let me tell you about when I went to see Tony Robbins!"). The scientifical bits are self-contradictory and over-reaching (Introverts are often blue-eyed and Asians are generally Introverts). "Quiet" can serve as an entertaining superficial introduction to personality types if you are unfamiliar with the topic. Otherwise, books like "Please Understand Me" or "Do What You Are" for jobs or "Nurture by Nature" for parenting, have been out for a long time and are more complete and useful.

An insight into the world of introverts and extroverts. An excellent book, providing informative research and giving profound advices to parents, teachers, and introverts themselves. A must read book for those who are interested in psychology.

If you've ever been called or thought of yourself as introverted, quiet, sensitive, shy, aloof, antisocial, ... the list goes on—then you owe it to yourself to read this book. It has flaws—it crams in an awful lot of material and doesn't always make interrelations clear—but it's the best book I've read yet for understanding how I'm different from most people and what I—and they—can do about it.The validation starts early, on page 4: "Introverts living under the Extrovert Ideal are like women in a man's world, discounted because of a trait that goes to the core of who they are." Cain doesn't harp on the incongruity that women are a majority, unlike introverts, but this tossed-off analogy gave me a new perspective on feminism and male privilege, as well as the extra challenge of being a male with this "female" trait.I was a very early reader of Elaine Aron's book The Highly Sensitive Person—I was at what must've been her second reading, in Palo Alto, and then took a seminar with her in SF—and that book really helped me understand myself at the time. But it also provided a too-attractive label for others to interact with rather than actually dealing with the real person. In Quiet, Cain talks a lot about Aron's ideas—HSP is another trait that overlaps with introversion etc.—but she starts from Jerome Kagan's original label of "high reactivity." Aron probably does too, but if I'd lost that term over the last 15 years. And it's useful in how it clarifies the relation between the individual and the world: it's not just the individual's susceptibility but the world's insistence, and it's not just feelings but any new sensation. "What we're really observing is a child's sensitivity to novelty in general, not just to people" (102). Knowing that I react easily to stimulation is very different from knowing that I am sensitive. (Other labels for the same trait include "negativity" and "inhibition," but I doubt I have to explain how deforming and disabling they are.)Reading Quiet prompted a gillion other "duh!" moments. For instance, "An audience may be rousing, but it's also stressful" (90): How rarely do we hear that acknowledged? How often is it assumed all an artist wants is an audience? Or the fact (152) that HSPs enjoy small talk only after they've established a deep connection with someone; for us, it's not a relaxing way to ease into things, it's a frustrating waste of time playing a (difficult, deceptive, meaningless) social role. Or the very simple observation that "participation [in social exchange] places a very different set of demands on the brain than observing does" (237). In other words, I am not weird for not liking large-group discussions, where in addition to thinking of what I have to say I have to pay attention to what everyone else is saying at the same time and how they're reacting to what they hear etc etc; nor for not liking the phone, where I get no non-verbal cues whatsoever yet have to participate in real time.Other new insights:—p. 81: "Deliberate Practice is best conducted alone": This is a necessary corrective to the impression left by Malcolm Gladwell and his "10,000 hours" theory (which actually isn't his, apparently—another false impression he's happy to reap the benefit of). The simple fact is that Deliberate Practice cannot work in groups; only you can determine the challenge most compelling to you.—p. 142: Low reactivity (as opposed to high reactivity/sensitivity/etc.) generally correlates with people whose skin remains cool. So the "cool" people really are! And it makes sense that I am both easily embarrassed (and I blush) and occasionally a "hot head" with anger about some minor circumstance. Embarrassment, by the way, is "a moral emotion" (144): it means you care about what other people think. Think about it: the most common opposite of "easily embarrassed" is probably "shameless," and that's definitely not a compliment.—p. 212-5: The whole concept of low and high self-monitors, which is not the same as extroversion/introversion but overlaps as a tool for categorizing and stereotyping people. Low self-monitors like me, who don't pay attention to how we're seen by others (except when forced by an extreme, i.e. angering or embarrassing, situation), dislike charades, improv, arguing for a position not our own, adapting our behavior or opinions to situations or people. High self-monitors are better liars. Shameless liars?—p. 231: "Introverts like people they meet in friendly contexts; extroverts prefer those they compete with." In other words, extroverts take your resistance as a sign of engagement. This is how bullies think. Bullying, at its core, may just be an extreme or misguided extroversion—and that's why our extrovert-dominated society has trouble seeing and stopping it.In later chapters, Cain discusses how those of us addressed by her book, whatever the label, can adapt to a world—or at least a dominant culture—that tends to see us as somehow or other defective. Play to your strengths, she says, work against your type for things that matter to you—but for once she acknowledges that "It's not always so easy, it turns out, to identify your core personal projects. And it can be especially tough for introverts, who have spent so much of their lives conforming to extroverted norms that by the time they choose a career, or a calling, it feels perfectly normal to ignore their own preferences" (217). Yes! For some of us, being told as a child "You can be anything you want!" has been more of a curse than an invitation.Quiet is organized to be read, not for ongoing reference. It's essentially journalism, not a single focused argument, not a how-to guide, definitely not original scientific research. Reading it gave me lots of things to think and learn more about, but I'll go to other sources. Still, I've been reading about myself in various forms for decades and I've never felt as many moments of recognition.

68. Quiet : The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking (Audio) by Susan Cain, read by Kathe Mazur2012, 10:39 (352 pages in hardcover)listened Sep 2-14, Nov 1-2Rating: 2.5 stars 	The low rating is meant to express how annoyed I was. Disappointed really. Cain has a nice point for all of us introverts in the world. She makes an argument that we are overlooked, and under-appreciated because we are so quiet. The business world is basically ready to run over introverts and actively looks for and promotes the most extroverted extroverts (think Enron). The classroom, at least in the United States, encourages extroversion and discourages any signs of introversion. The world is against us. And yet, we play valuable roles throughout all levels of society and it is aspects of our introverted character that allows us to do that. This is an introvert's manifesto.The problem is that Cain is so smug about this and she really oversimplifies. She tells us story early on about a quiet lawyer who is finally placed in a lead role, and she excels. She was smart and she was better prepared and calmer and more thoughtful than the other people in the room. This introverted hero turns out to be autobiographic - Cain is Ms. Perfect. As the book carries on, the reader slowly realizes that Cain thinks all introverts are basically like her, and that all extroverts are basically shallow yapping idiots. She never comes out says it, and she always makes qualifying statements about extroverts, but also she never corrects the impression either. It’s there under the text as the background argument. It’s not only unfair to non-introverts, but actually very unfair to introverts too. We are not all so quietly perfect as she likes to think we are. As the book carried on, this bothered more and more.For me that overshadowed all the many very interesting parts to the book. Cain did a lot of research and presents a lot of interesting information. She talks a lot about introverted children (although I don’t have any. My are insanely extroverted. And, another bitter note, she spends a lot of time on the problem of extroverted parents with introverted children, but not a single sentence on the problem of introverted parents with extroverted children.)One of the most interesting factoids I pulled out of this book was the comparison of introverted and extroverted managers. Overly extroverted managers excel at motivating employees, but they get in the way of their better people and actually hold them back. Introverted managers struggle with unmotivated employees, but generally help their better people excel more. I’m not sure I agree with her analysis. She doesn’t bring up the possibility that introverts may simply stay out of the way more and let people be. But still, it’s interesting…and I can relate. There is a place for an introverts manifesto, but it doesn't require such an unbalanced take. There is a wide and interesting and useful psychology around introversion. I would have liked a more carefully balanced view.

« You may have known more about who you were then, than you do now. »In this work of quiet perseverance, author Susan Cain explores in-depth the introversion/extroversion personality trait, and some related theories. She delves into the physiological and psychological make-up of introverts and extraverts in a Western society where the ‘Extrovert Ideal’ has prevailed and we are all expected to sell, even ourselves.The author talks from personal experience, and subjects herself to multiple ‘experiments’, meets with subject matter experts, and interviews introverts over several years. She talks mainly about the US and, to a lesser extent, Asian American population in a bid to introduce cultural differences that promote/demote introversion. There was little reference to gender-specifics, which I expect would account for some of our differences, certainly in today’s western societies. The author careful avoids common pitfalls by: treating introversion/extroversion as a fuzzy logic scale - we are who we are and that’s perfectly fine; understanding the situational factors that can cause everyone of us to act outside of our true self, either consciously or unconsciously stretching our natural abilities; promoting freedom of thought rather than presenting a guru-like approach - « Agressive power beats you up; soft power wins you over ». Susan Cain is clearly driven and delivers a message of hope to introverts. Even if ‘Succeeding’ may mean marching to the beat of our own quiet drum, this isn’t a self-help book, it is a thought enabler, based on facts (historical and present), figures, and detailed accounts and interviews. I needed time between readings to process the dense information and many references. But then again this is not my preferred genre. I made my way from being a shy, sensitive, introverted child, quite content to walk in the playground alone, lost in thought and daydreaming, to an adolescent rebel and the grown-up pseudo-extrovert I am today. I just had never realised the extent to which I had lost my connection with that quiet, curly haired little girl.This book has changed the way I see myself, and, although this was not the grippiest read for me, I feel compelled to give it a whopping 5-stars for being such a well-researched eye-opener.

The only good thing I can say about this book is that it serves as a one stop collection of references to more intelligent analysis of the topic of introversion. The book itself  brings nothing to the table. Worse than that, by cherry picking data to support her generalizations, she does introverts a huge disservice. She actually manages to make introverts sound like weaklings which I feel insulted by. Her implication that introverts are superior, sensitive beings who absorb every negative slight to slowly destroy their psyche is just ridiculous. In Chapter 11, she gives ‘insights’ for parenting introverts - Don't tell your kid she's shy, be a role model by greeting strangers in a calm gentle way, don't pick over-aggressive kids as playmates, let your child know gently that tugging at your pant legs is not okay, instead let him know speaking up quietly is better to get attention. Three simple rules will help: Smile, stand up straight and make eye contact? - What the bloody hell? In the real world, all that is just obvious basics of good parenting! She actually says “make sure you're not imposing your own dreams on your kid” Well, no shit!  Chapter 8 is probably her least balanced chapter. She discusses how studious the Cupertino Asians are and is positively salivating about how great they are. Reading this chapter, one would think that all Asian kids are born studious introverts and sadly have to make radical adjustment when they face the terrible extroverted American life. Presumably, the only extroverted Asians she met were the ones that were sadly changing their core beings to fit into American society! There’s no discussion of the pressures faced by the kids to succeed at the expense of exploring other aspects of life.  I wish I had read the conclusion chapter first which basically sums up the book. From her bullet points on the insights she felt she had provided, I’d have been able to see she had nothing more than already well known ideas and I’d have skipped this one. Save yourself the trouble and copy down her references to read instead.

I have a misanthropic friend. Onetime I invited him to a movie about a misanthrope. He rejected my offer and said "I hate misanthropes". Needless to say, it was a really funny, smart, engaging film. He would have loved it. But he never saw it. Ironic no?I have to admit I'm plenty guilty of the same kind of (tired old) opinions (usually negative) made before investigation.The fact that I loved this book is not surprising, and neither is the fact that I avoided reading it for a long time.I avoided this book because it was (and still is) a huge hit best seller in it's category. I typically avoid popular books, films, music etc. And because the author isn't a psychologist. I'm pretty cautious about my sources. And because I had a lot of other things to read. I love reading.The irony is so obvious in retrospect. If you love books, steer clear of cocktail banter, love deep conversation, hate bright and shiny, groupish, joinery shit, than you, like me, may qualify as an introvert. It's not a bad thing. It's a good thing, and this book is FUBU (for us by us), or BUFU (by us for us) depending on how you roll.This is such a big hearted, normalizing, useful, game changing read. I hope you get over your "too smart for popular psychology" self a read this (very smart and well done) book.After you're done, you may be kicking yourself that you didn't think of it first. A book for, by and about bookish, cerebral, sensitive (in the good way) types. Who knew it would be such a huge hit? You'd almost think the author was a Machiavellian marketing genius, if she wasn't so dang sincere and genuinely likable (from a distance of course).

Wow, this book was simply amazing. Every piece of information found here is something I wish I'd known in junior high school, high school, or even college. And I wish my parents had known more about when I was even younger than all that. I finished the book with mixed reactions though. On the one hand I feel completely validated, in a way I've never been able to grasp before, and I feel like there are definitely some simple things I can change about my life now that will help me become even better adjusted to daily existence. But on the other hand, it's so frustrating to see all of this so late in life (relatively speaking). If I had understood these things about myself, about many of my friends, about so many people I came into contact with, I think I could have enjoyed my childhood and early adulthood instead of constantly hoping for things to change. I can only hope now that I can still figure some of this out.

Brilliant book. Contains a lot of amazing research that just made me feel better and better about myself. For many years, I struggled with trying to be a team player - I was a management consultant so that was one of the highest values. But it's just not me. A few years ago, I embraced my introversion and started to understand my energy levels and how they worked. I particularly like the section on how introverts can act like extroverts when it is important to them - this is how I do public speaking. But I need at least a day to recover afterwards. This book will help you if you are an introvert, or if you want to understand those people in your lives who need solitude and silence. Fantastic.

1. Interesting premise.2. Poor construction.3. Annecdotes.4. Rage.5. Needs editing.6. Really, really needs editing.7. Confirms all the conclusions I, an off-the-chart extrovert, have come to in trying to have great relationships with introverts, like my husband. 8. Pass unless you're an introvert who's really mad at extroverts and want to read a whole book about how super special you are.9. Rinse.10. Repeat.

Quiet illuminates the differences between introverts and extroverts -- citing the important roles both personalities play in a healthy society -- and qualifies as required reading for all who wish to better understand themselves and the people around them. A valuable resource for parents, teachers, employers, and everyone else.

Susan Cain believes our society unduly emphasizes traits of extroverts, and believes we are missing out on many of the strengths of introverts. She supports her thesis by citing a number of studies done by others and weaving them together in a logical manner. This book contains helpful insights on how to relate to introverted adults and encourage introverted children. It is partly a self-help book in showing married couples of different types how to compromise between social functions and quiet activities. The author is an introvert and cites anecdotes from her personal history. While she offers the idea that people fall at different places on the introversion-extroversion continuum, most of the book focuses on the two extremes. It certainly provides food for thought and can help improve communications between those with different temperaments. It will be interesting to see if her ideas can make any headway in corporate America.

An evocative and compelling start of a revolution to unlock the power and understanding of introverts.  ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️SUMMARYAt least one-third to one-half of the people we know are introverts. They are the ones who prefer listening to speaking, reading to socializing, and working on their own to working in teams. Many of society’s great contributors are introverts: Rosa Parks, Gandhi, Chopin, Theo Geisel, Warren Buffett, Steve Wozniak and Eleanor Rosevelt. In QUIET, Susan Cain argues that we dramatically undervalue the traits and capability of introverts and she shows us how much we lose in doing so. She offers advice to introverts and urges changes in the workplace, in schools and in parenting.“The secret to life is to put yourself in the right lighting. For some it’s a Broadway spotlight; for others, a lamp lit desk.REVIEWWhat if everyone was an extrovert? According to composer Allen Shawn “A species in which everyone was General Patton would not succeed, anymore than would a race in which everyone was Vincent Van Gogh.” Introverts are needed for their creativity, careful analysis and thoughtfulness. Susan Cain does a superb job at identifying the strengths and weakness of both introverts and extroverts. There were several things I liked about this smartly structured and thought-provoking book. Cain provides a clear explanation of the societal benefits of introverts with real world examples throughout history. QUIET is weighted with research in biology, psychology, and neuroscience demonstrating the value of introverts.Of particular interest were Cain’s chapters on extroverts who are the parents of introverts, and the issue of schools and classes being designed in such a way that favors extroverts. Having raised a introverted son, I can certainly attest to the exhaustion my son felt after a day at school. QUIET is essential reading for introverts, parents of introverts, and spouses of introverts. It should also be read by teachers, counselors, and employers, so just about everyone! She is an introvert who practiced law for seven years before becoming a writer. she is cofounder of Quiet Revolution and has also written Quiet Power; The Secret Strength of Introverts. If you are introverted on any level at all, this is a must read! This is a book based on science and studies of the brain, but for me it felt like a self-help book of sorts. For example, I can go to a party and be "the life of the party" but afterward I am exhausted and need a lot of quiet down time. It's sometimes hard for me to believe that I'm an introvert (an assessment based on my own observations as well as a Meyers-Briggs test I took before I got married) because I am pretty social and enjoy being around people. Of course, this type of thinking---equating introversion with anti-social behavior---is, according to Susan Cain in her wonderful book "Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking", part of the residual societal anti-introvert indoctrination. Being an introvert does NOT mean one is anti-social. It also doesn't mean one is "shy". Indeed, the word "Introvert" can still have many negative connotations in the minds of most people, especially in the fields of business, finance, law, entertainment, and politics (fields in which extroverts still predominate), which it shouldn't because, as Cain demonstrates through anecdotal evidence as well as hard scientific data, introverts are the ones who tend to get things done, and/or done right. They just tend to do it quietly, often without fanfare or even credit. According to studies, somewhere between one-third and one-half of the world population could be described as introverts. Some regions of the world (Asia, for example) have a heavier population of introverts because, culturally, they value introverts over extroverts. It is the complete opposite in this country, a country that is blatantly pro-extrovert. Cain calls the American obsession and glorification of extroversion "'The Extrovert Ideal'---the omnipresent belief that the ideal self is gregarious, alpha, and comfortable in the spotlight. (p. 4)" Introversion, on the other hand, "is now a second-class personality trait, somewhere between a disappointment and a pathology. (p. 4)" We, as a culture, seem to idolize extroverts when, in fact, historically and statistically, it is usually the introverts who have given us the most beautiful art and literature, the most innovative scientific inventions, and the most profitable business practices. Cain's book is loaded with fascinating interviews and stories, as well as hard data, that supports the theory that introversion is unjustly dismissed in this country, often to the extreme detriment of the rest of society. In one of the more fascinating chapters in the book, Cain looks at the Wall Street Crash of 2008, a monumentally devastating event in American financial history that, she argues (fairly convincingly), could have been prevented or at the very least lessened had the loud-mouthed action-oriented extroverts leading the companies actually paid attention to the bookish, soft-spoken introverted number-crunchers in their midst who, for some time before the crash, were sending memos, e-mails, and trying to get a word in edge-wise with warnings about rampant spending and bad spending that could potentially lead to exactly what happened. Ironically and sadly, many of these quiet harbingers of doom were actually criticized after the fact for not bringing the information to the attention of their bosses.Part of the problem is what Cain calls "the myth of charismatic leadership", a cultural belief that often equates charismatic behavior and attitudes (confidence, talkativeness, assertiveness, aggressiveness) with superior intelligence. In truth, there is no difference in the intelligence levels between introverts and extroverts. Unfortunately, what tends to happen, especially in group settings (an environment in which introverts naturally feel uncomfortable to begin with) in which ideas are being brainstormed, introverts often feel hesitant to contribute or are quickly dismissed by the more assertive and charismatic members of the group. Thus, potentially good ideas are drowned out and lost. Several studies have proven this phenomenon to be accurate.Another interesting fact that Cain points out is from a well-known study of some of the best-performing companies of the late 20th century. Without exception, every single best-performing company had the same thing in common: Their CEOs were all introverts. Unassuming, thoughtful, often described as "taciturn" or even "eccentric", these men and women preferred to lock themselves away in their office to work quietly rather than work in group settings. What do introverts do better than extroverts? One of the key factors, according to studies, is the ability to listen. An introvert is more likely to actively listen to the ideas of others when making a decision, as well as actually implement those ideas. An introvert is also more likely to designate jobs and duties to people they think are more qualified rather than take on the job themselves simply to receive the credit. The Extrovert Ideal doesn't just effect the world of business and finance. It can also have a negative effect within politics, education, and evangelical Christianity. Cain interviewed several pastors, members of clergy, and church members to see how the Extrovert Ideal has impacted the church. Not surprisingly (to anyone who has ever attended a church service), church clearly caters more toward extroverts than introverts. Flamboyant singing, being forced to "greet-and-smile" with your neighbors, not-so-subtly glorifying and extolling those congregants who have gone out into the community or taken mission trips: all of these are things that most introverts find uncomfortable and even painful. Worse, they sometimes feel that they are looked down upon for their introversion. For many introverts, church is "a religious culture that sees extroversion not only as a personality trait but also as an indicator of virtue. (p. 70)"Basically, Cain laments the sad fact that many introverts in this country are made to feel guilty or somehow less-important than extroverts because of their personality style, especially when mounting evidence suggests that introverts contribute a great deal to society. Cain, an introvert, never resorts to an anti-extrovert mentality. (Perhaps due to the fact that she's happily married to an extrovert.) She makes the point numerous times that extroverts and introverts have a lot to teach each other. In her own relationship (a model for introvert-extrovert couples, which are quite common apparently), she has learned from her husband to be more outgoing. Her husband has also learned from her how to be more introspective and less impulsive. "Quiet" is one of those books that I can't recommend highly enough. Everyone should read this book. At the very least it might help extroverts to realize why introverts act the way they do sometimes, and it may help introverts realize that they have nothing about which to feel embarrassed, ashamed, or guilty.

I am fairly conversant with psychology, and the kinds of tests (eg, Myers-Briggs) that determine personality type - for instance, whether a person is more extroverted or introverted in temperament - but I still found Quiet to be a mentally and emotionally transformative reading experience. Some of its analysis as to why America has become the most extroverted nation in history, and how the "cult of personality" developed, was also very insightful. Cain wrote this book several years before the 2016 presidential election, but so many of her findings really helped me understand the otherwise inexplicable: in other words, how someone like Donald Trump could be elected as president of the United States.I am not an obvious introvert because I have a chatty and confident social manner. I'm far from the stereotypical 'nerd' who avoids human contact as much as possible. But in many important ways, I am a classic introvert. One of the valuable things that Cain does is both broaden and refine the definitions of what an introverted temperament looks and acts like. An essential difference between introversion and extroversion is whether social contact gives you energy (a "buzz") or drains you. I have known, since I was a very young child, that being with people drains me - even if I am enjoying that contact. I am really uncomfortable at cocktail parties, large sporting events and any situation where I feel obligated to make superficial chit-chat. I'd rather send a text than talk on the phone, but I do enjoy intense one-on-one conversations. I dislike noise in general, and find certain noises almost unbearable. I'm conflict averse and very sensitive to the feelings of others. I relax by being alone with a book. Before reading this book, I don't think I have ever fully appreciated the cultural pressure I felt to be extroverted, or conversely, experienced so much acceptance of my own natural temperament.What Cain does so skilfully is describe - in laymen's terms, but with the backing of scientific research - why a balance of 'extroverted' and 'introverted' qualities is needed for everything from personal relationships to education to business culture. She shows that introverted types can learn some of the positive aspects of extroverted behaviour - and indeed, that those behaviours can be key for being an effective communicator. But she also points out that extroverted 'confidence' can be misplaced, and more like arrogance, and that there is much danger is always following the person who shouts loudest and seems most convinced of his or her own beliefs. Having grown up in America, and being used to its ways, I was very intrigued by Cain's comparison of a typically extroverted culture with the more introverted Asian cultures. I was struck by the idea of 'relationship honouring': the innate cultural belief that it is worse to embarrass someone else than to be embarrassed oneself. How 'foreign' that is to the average American, although it used to be the very core of good manners. Introverts tend to be more susceptible to guilt, and they often are more concerned with the value of moral behaviour. They tend to think before they speak, and to consider a situation more carefully and from all angles. They tend to be risk-averse and more analytical, which actually makes them more successful in jobs in the financial sector - although many practises of the last 20 years have rewarded risky 'extroverted' types instead. They are not as concerned with 'vanity,' popularity and external rewards. (I think we can infer that Donald Trump is definitely not an introvert.)As I was reading this book, I felt like there were just so many people I wanted to share it with. It gives so much insight to how parents can more sensitively raise their introverted children and honour their strengths while encouraging them to develop the weaker areas of their character. It also made me understand how difficult it can be for my older daughter to be the only extrovert in a family of introverts. Although there is quite a lot of business-oriented information, which may not interest everyone, I think this book is a must-read.

I have always felt that I'm a little bit different from my peers and friends. Introversion is not something new, Carl Jung discussed this personality long time ago but it was until recently it started to have a global recognition. Susan Cain defines introverts as people who prefers quiet and less stimulating environments than others, listens more than they talk and think before they act on the contrary of extroverts who are open and react highly in stimulating environments, feels more comfortable with a large group of people and under spotlights.Being an introvert myself, reading this book didn’t come with something new to me except that it validated how I feel and react as an introvert. I think because I took some time accepting myself as I am before reading this book made me want to jump through pages very fast maybe because I found that the scientific researches and psychological work aimed at convincing the others that introversion has a scientific background for them to accept us rather than for me to accept myself.I listened to almost all the talks and discussions Susan Cain had on this topic at YouTube and I had very high expectations from this book but I was somehow a little bit disappointed. I think the book was well written and supported with statistics, experiments and researches on many topics related to this personality type but it needed more headings and sub-titles as you might read very long passages and sometimes you need just a new subject to wrap up everything you have just read. In her defense for introverts, I think un-intentionally she was spreading the message that introverts are idealist and the misconception of the west (especially in the US) regarding the idealist extrovert.The last two chapters about the communication gap between introverts and extroverts and how to deal with your introverted child were the reason I gave the book a high rating. The chapter that talked about workplace was really awesome and hit me the most as I do myself hate open space work places and I was the first to get a divider to my cubical in the office. I highly recommend this book for people who are new to this subject and need a better understanding of introverts that communicate with and for me I think I need to have a better understanding of extroverts in order to maintain a better relationship and communication with them.

I hope Quiet is read by every introvert out there and everyone who may be in a relationship with an introvert....really anyone hoping to gain understanding about intro/extroversion. Susan Cain offers up an incredibly engaging, comprehensive look at introversion. She takes a multidisciplinary approach to the concept of introversion in a culture where we are often measured against an "Extrovert Ideal" - in the workplace, schools and social settings. She offers workable, empowering solutions to introverts, parents of introverts, managers of introverts. It's not a self-help book; she is a pragmatist. She offers ways to honor who we are but also offers up ways to still function successfully in social situations, work, marriage and friendship.Highly recommended to all introverts and plenty of great information for the extroverts out there too!Side note: I would have possibly given this book 4 stars if I'd not heard her speak recently. As a result, I thought a few chapters could use a little editing but this book and her speech so resonated with me personally, I bumped up my rating to 5 stars.Lastly: a tiny quibble--in the end, she offers possible advice to introverts who may be unhappy in their jobs. This book is so damn well researched - the author's passion for the understanding of introversion is evident on every page. As an introvert myself (an INTP to be specific), I believe I've adapted a reasonable extroverted persona for everyday activity with the attitude that there is something to gain from each interaction. Nonetheless, when I receive an invitation for a party my instinct is to politely decline with a white lie unless within my circle of good friends, which I will attend. This book has provided evidence with people's experiences from young to old as well as social experiments for answers about temperament, shyness & personality traits attributed to introverts and extroverts. Many important mentions include Rosa Parks, Obama, Gandhi, Warren Buffet & Steve Wozniak. A great insightful read for introverts & extroverts alike. Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can’t Stop Talking was brilliant. It was well researched, well written, and well edited. Susan Cain starts by looking at the history and the culture in the United States to help put into context how we moved from a culture of character to a culture of personality. She looks at the characteristics of introverts and extroverts from a physical, psychological, and biological viewpoint and discusses that we are not all one or the other but a mixture of both. Cain looks at how introverts and extroverts function in school, the work place, and relationships; how to value the strengths of both personality types; and how to work together to get the best results. This book gave me a better understanding of myself and the people around me. and is beneficial on both a personal and professional level. Highly recommended!

What a fascinating and well written study on the differences between introverts and extroverts and what goes in to making them that way. I believe anyone managing people in any capacity should read this book as well as parents who are raising children, wondering why they are so different. Highly informative and the examples used are many well known people. I was surprised by quite a few that I thought were extroverts, were not and visa versa.

I’m not shy, I don’t sit in a corner, I’m the funny one, a ranter who is fluent in sarcasm and can hold her own. And she who is from the tiniest of families (current count 7) married into the biggest, loudest, most extroverted family on planet earth (current count approx. 1,038,428). If only I could get them to read this, to give them an insight as to what life as an introvert is like. 
”Without people like you, we will, quite literally, drown.”
Susan Cain highlights through case studies and facts, that success can and does come as a result of introvercy. Introverts are of as much value as extroverts and there’s plenty of room for us all. Deep down I know this, but after another family gathering which has left me drained and a bit down-in-the dumps (but loving my nephew’s girlfriend hard because it seems after 18 years I‘m no longer the lone introvert), re-reading this 6 years on from when I first picked it up has reminded me that there’s abso-fucking-lutely nothing wrong with me. I listened to this book because I have heard some very good things about it. Also I consider myself very much an introvert and wanted to hear what the author had to say about us. She actually had quite a bit to say, maybe a little too much because I decided to speed through a couple of the last chapters. The beginning confirmed what we readers already know -- that bookworms (and authors, scientists, computer geeks, artists, etc.) are mostly introverts, gratefully, as their need for alone time is the main reason for the existence of our favorite books (and inventions, computers, paintings, etc.).It also confirmed that one may be considered shy but convince oneself to try, successfully, to change that. Not all are successful, and not all will even attempt it.So many stories were regaled, I couldn't possibly absorb them all, much less repeat them. I'm glad I read it but it was less amazing than I had hoped.

I'm an extrovert. To give you an idea of just how far over I am on the extrovert side of the spectrum, in one of the companies that I previously worked for, we did some team building based around our Myer-Briggs profiles and at one point, the trainer asked the extroverts to go to one corner of the room and the introverts to the other. I was closest to the extrovert corner so immediately stuck my hands up in the air and started dancing around calling "Extroverts over here! Extroverts over here!"But I also am: married to an introvert, the daughter of two introverts, the mother of an introvert and co-worker with a whole team of introverts (a new situation for me as I've previously worked in extrovert-dominant companies). So, when an introvert friend of mine said that she loved this book and kept saying "Finally! Somebody who gets what it is like to be an introvert!" while reading it, I was intrigued and interested. Essentially, I opened this book with a mind eager to learn more. Unfortunately, I ended up feeling like I was the enemy. This quote in the Introduction chapter captures the sentiment that snakes through the whole book:"Introversion - along with its cousins sensitivity, seriousness, and shyness - is now a second-class personality trait, somewhere between a disappointment and a pathology. Introverts living under the Extrovert Ideal are like women in a man's world, discounted because of a trait that goes to the core of who they are. Extroversion is an enormously appealing personality style, but we've turned it into an oppressive standard to which most of us feel we must conform."And another example (although here Cain is quoting someone else):"If "fast" and "slow" animals had parties, writes the evolutionary biologist David Sloan Wilson, "some of the fasts would bore everyone with their loud conversation, while others would mutter into their beer that they don't get any respect. Slow animals are best described as shy, sensitive types. They don't assert themselves, but they are observant and notice things that are invisible to the bullies. They are the writers and artists at the party who have interesting conversations out of earshot of the bullies. They are the inventors who figure out new ways to behave, while the bullies steal their patents by copying their behavior.""So, extrovert type animals are "bullies?" And in Chapter 7, "Why Did Wall Street Crash and Warren Buffett Prosper?" she seems to be making the case that it's all because of extroverts that we ended up in our financial mess! To be fair, Cain does actually want both sides to get along and there are several times where she extols the virtues of both introverts and extroverts and the need to have both in this world, just more in balance with each other.My biggest problem with the book is that I didn't feel she answered questions that she set up for herself. Take Chapter 5, for example. This is called "Beyond Temperament. The Role of Free Will (and the Secret of Public Speaking for Introverts)." The chapter makes the argument that you can choose to stretch yourself out of the personality that you are born with, but you can stretch only so far. We learn how a key difference between introverts and extroverts is a preference for stimulation. If an introvert is in too noisy an environment, they don't function at their best. An extrovert needs more stimulation to be firing on all cylinders. As public speaking is a stimulating activity, "introverts can find their attention impaired just when they need it most." And the "secret" to public speaking? Lots of prep, and talk about topics that matter deeply to you. Umm, I think that's advice that works for everyone.Chapter 3 "When Collaboration Kills Creativity" was interesting. It reiterated some of the findings that I've read in other books - that group brainstorming is not as effective as we've all thought, for example. But I hadn't heard of The Coding War Games. This was a study of more than 600 developers in 92 companies to identify the characteristics of the best and worst computer programmers. What they found was that the top performers "overwhelmingly worked for companies that gave their workers the most privacy, personal space, control over their physical environments, and freedom from interruption."The chapter on parenting an introvert was interesting but reinforced what I already knew rather than giving me specific advice/new approaches to consider. (Sorry, that sounds more arrogant than I intended. I guess I have an interest in all of this so Quiet was not my first introduction to personality research.) My son is the type of kid who starts reading a book if a playdate goes on too long. (He's 11.) When he first started Kindergarten, he went immediately to the book corner and started reading while all the parents and kids were milling about, talking and waiting to say goodbye. Reading is his way of dealing with over stimulation and we support that with a ton of library books lying around the house at any given moment. I guess overall, my disappointment was that there were a lot of sweeping statements about extroverts and introverts which then didn't get backed up. I felt like each chapter jumped around a lot and you'd get to the end and wonder what the key points were.

“Don't think of introversion as something that needs to be cured.”

I didn't realize that the world had it out for introverts but maybe it's just my problem for missing it?Based on this book's gross generalization I'm neither an introvert nor an extrovert. While I am an introvert at my core, my personality is also sprinkled with characteristics that are attributed solely to extroversion. Apparently I'm the 
Divergent
 in Cain's world which is divided in these two factions: introverts and extroverts. I found little use to the book. Barely any insightful information is provided. Like I said, it was overall just a gross generalization. Cain's view of the matter is seriously biased. I am all for protecting and cherishing introversion, after all, I am mostly introverted. And I have had that held against me on occasions. I felt wronged, of course. Nonetheless, I was quite taken aback by the villainization of extroverts. Cain portrays introverts as these perpetually misunderstood geniuses, who need to be handled like delicate flowers, who would fix all the world's problems if only they would be allowed to take over. Because introverts are such good folks. And extroverts are these loud, stupid, intimidating assholes who never listen to the voice of reason, who only care about themselves and always try to manipulate everyone for their own gain, therefore they are those who will bring on the Apocalypse. Even when she makes some feeble attempts to give extroversion some credit it always comes out as a insult that's masked a compliment. The truth is, throughout my lifetime, I've faced a lot of assholes, and they were from both camps. The extroverted ones used loud, aggressive methods of intimidation while the introverted ones used insidious passive-aggressive tactics. None was better than the other. So it's really not about where you are on the introversion-extroversion scale is what you end up doing with it and this point seems to completely escape Cain's view. This book was meant to stroke my introverted ego, but it failed miserably. To me, it felt like a big pity party while I was expecting a fairly objective opinion based on scientific findings about introversion and extroversion.  I'm not saying that her criticism of today's western society is invalid. And that she doesn't have a point when she talks about how awful corporations and the educational system are. Or about how they brake spirits and suppress valid ideas just based on the delivery. Loud, arrogant, impulsive, stupid people are usually the ones who end up in charge everywhere nowadays and this is causing so many issue for everyone. But it's not a simple matter of introverts vs. extroverts. The only few sections that were not completely tainted by her personal convictions, did provide some useful information and helped me confirm the knowledge of my own personality. But nothing was revolutionary, I had an intuitive understanding of most of those ideas. Needless to say I was very disappointed by this book. It's of little value from a scientific point of view. For me it was mostly Cain's way of dealing with her own challenges of being an introvert and frankly she comes out as a somewhat bitter, passive-aggressive individual. Otherwise, the narration was quite pleasant and there are quite a few good quotes and ideas, too bad they were tainted with the author's defensive attitude.

I work in an environment where extroverts have the run of the place. Because I eat at my desk while reading and do not really enjoy small talk and big parties I’m often the odd one out. I’ve been trying to be more sociable and have internalized other people’s opinion that there is something not quite right with being an introverted. Reading this book I felt vindicated and understood. Never again will I blame myself or make excuse for being introverted. In a lot of ways, I’m still old fashioned. I value discipline and moral. So it was with a mix of sadness and pleasure that I read how the extrovert came to dominate the business world and the rise of the “Culture of Personality”. Susan Cain’s book helped me understand why in such a culture, my favorite candidate in the last municipal election didn’t stand a chance. What she writes about Harvard Business School could apply with any business school and explains why acting decisively and rapidly is valued over pondering one’s decision. In Canada pharmaceutical industries are not allowed to advertise so I was shocked and appalled to read that Paxil was promoted as a drug to cure shyness. I was touched to read about the gentleness of Rosa Park and not so surprise to read that creativity is often a lonely endeavor.Curiously I was less enamoring with the second section “Your Biology, Your Self?” I did find the whole discussion about high versus low reactivity interesting and appreciated that the author wrote that “High- and low-reactivity are probably not the only biological routes to introversion and extroversion. However she does put a lot of emphasis on those factors almost to the exclusion of anything else. Of course my impressions are not scientific at all but based on my own, limited experience. I’m definitely am introverted but I don’t see myself as being high-reactive and adverse to novelty and I’m a little embarrassed to admit that I am not highly emphatic (but I’m working on it). But am I? On one hand, I’m certainly not an early adapter. I down have a smart phone yet and still read paper books. On the other hand I am not usually anxious and love travelling. Like the author, I have learnt to stretch myself by talking in public and talking to people in parties and cocktail. I’ve even been told that I’m lucky to be extroverted. I they only knew!The third section thought me that there are places in the word where introversion is valued.All this theory would have been interesting but not as useful without Part four “How to Love, How to Work” which teaches how introvert and extrovert can get along and how to fit in when you’re an introvert. I have learned to leave 15 minutes between meetings to restore myself. I now work from home once a week. I just whish some of my bosses and colleagues would also read this book.

I went 3, no 4, no 3, no 4, no 3 on this. And I realised this was an example of one of the traits of introversion, to decide correctly so as not to feel guilt. "Guilt" is mentioned 22 times in this book.What sucked me in to trying this book was in the intro: "Now that you're an adult, you might still feel a pang of guilt when you decline a dinner invitation in favor of a good book."EXACTLY!!In fact, it doesn't even have to be a GOOD book, just a book! Or a magazine! Anything rather than having to (gasp) socialise. And if one doesn't really drink much alcohol, or "a glass of extroversion", than it does become a painfully long ordeal.The first 2/3 was quite interesting. About one-third of the population are introverted, but the extroversion bias of North American society, especially the US, means that introversion becomes regarded as a defect or something to overcome, rather than just a temperament which in many ways is more desirable than its opposite. Society needs both temperaments and the spectrum between them. (But try telling that to the pharmaceutical companies making Paxil and Zoloft etc., who would love to label as all as having 'social anxiety disorder'. They are trying to create disease out of normal human nature. They could make twice as much money if they instead try to create a disease of extroverts and call it something like "pathologic social exhuberance disorder". :-) )The last part lost my interest, as it degenerated into a self help type style, thereby somewhat contradicting the first parts of the book. Still, it was an interesting enough book. I never read these kinds of books, so that I managed to finish it says something.

I guess basically every single person can be boiled down as either an introvert or extrovert. And without any sort of survey, you can say at least two-thirds of the Goodreaders/book-people (or whatever -philes) are introverts. I mean who else can be passionate about a bunch of words put together for pages? So this book might've reached a good amount of introverts. But the trouble is, it's supposed to work another way. I wouldn't say this book is a waste of time for introverts, it validates their behavior, maybe makes them quit their search for approval. But in a world dominated by ideal extroverts, it wouldn't make much of a difference. If managers, interviewers, parents etc can't exactly understand the fact that 'Introversion isn't something to be cured', there's no point in self-validation(in the bigger picture). So if introverts come out as narcissists and anti-social(but who exactly defined social?), it's because of the other group. Other than this, Quiet also talks about the cultural differences with respect to personality traits. While introversion is ideal in fareast, it just works the other way in the west. Susan Cain also calls out America as the most extroverted nation. And India, as a country which is highly influenced by the USA follows the same ideal of extroversion. If you've also read this book called, The Culture Map, you can easily make out why Eastern Asians can read between the lines, westerners just can't and South Asians lie somewhere in between.

So I probably picked up this book, as most others do, due to identifying as an introvert. This book explores both extroversion and introversion. It uses case studies of both famous and non-famous people, as well as psychological and business studies. The case studies were great as you could identify with others personal experiences. It was also refreshing to read some of the psychological studies as a reminder of what I had learned as an undergraduate psychology student. This is definitely a book I should have read earlier in my life- during college or university. I always felt weird being the one who is described as shy and quiet by teachers and bookish. I don't particularly socialise much and have social anxiety before going to seminars. It made me identify that my experiences are not alone- I'm just an introvert. This book explores introversion through different cultural experiences and shows the power and benefits of an introvert in these circumstances. A much needed brilliant read!

This is one of the most self-congratulatory books I’ve ever read.In theory, this book had a lot to offer, but it didn’t deliver. Rather than create a nuanced web to help express the ways that temperament develops in the human mind and in our cultures, Quiet describes an unreal version of reality where two binary spectrums of humanship exist- the loud, and the shy. The popular and the pariah. Nary is the middle ground discussed, despite the fact that everyone on earth at times has felt both ends of this spectrum.One of the greatest mistakes of this book is that it appropriates bookishness, introspection, and wisdom with introversion. This is problematic- the act of reading or thinking or affinity for knowledge is not exclusive to shy or introverted persons. Nor is the act of laughter or enjoying jokes exclusive to extroversion. Of course, the world would be improved with a greater balance of types- but mistaking habits and preferences for temperament is downright problematic, and more or less, annoying. Based on this book, extroverts are unfeeling, unthinking bumblers that stumble about loudly, eating and drinking themselves to death. But don’t worry, the world needs extroverts, if nothing but to balance out the more valuable, cerebral, noble introverts that have long gone undervalued. Gimme a break.The main issue with this book though, is that temperament is not genuinely explored through the lens of any other variable of the human existence- gender, ethnicity, geographic location, family experiences, race, socio-economic status, so on and forever. Of course, addressing each of these would be exhaustive, but the fact that so little is explored regarding these important factors is an unfortunate oversight that detracts from the overall effectiveness of the arguments in this book.

I have long known I am an introvert and thought I understood things pretty well, but Susan Cain's research turned up some fascinating details about this personality trait. I really enjoyed learning these things--from my thin skin (that has toughened over the years) to my ability to function reasonably well on little sleep (thanks to being a new mom). I also enjoyed her ability to delve into extroversion; it is a mistake to talk about one without the other. But the one aspect I missed seeing in this book has to do with parenting. She covered social life, the workplace, partnerships, and parenting introverted children...but her thoughts and information were quite thin on how/what it's like to be a parent who is introverted. I was hoping for more of that...she made suggestions about how to deal with certain things, but as an introvert I found myself wondering how I might actually do those things. Over and over again I get anxious about the future and that anxiety almost always is related to navigating parenthood as an introvert...am I up for dealing with teachers and schools? Other parents? And (good lord) birthday parties?? She had coaching tips for how to help a child cope with parties--but what about the mom? I'm not joking.I told the one known extrovert in my office about this book in an attempt to encourage her to read it. She wondered if there is a book called Loud, because Quiet just is not capturing her imagination. So I would like to ask Susan Cain to write a book about Loud, or better yet, repackage Quiet as Loud....and perhaps exponentially increase her audience and the number of extroverts learning about their introverted family members, colleagues, and friends.

A very divisive, uneven book, this one is. At first I (an introvert) was happy that I got the confirmation that the world's adherence to extroversion could negatively affect the introverts. And then I was relieved that being an introverts also have its benefits. I became aware that there is a spectrum and not a binary, where I do have some extrovert parts in me. I also learned that introverts can fake their way into a more extroverted behavior even in daily basis, but has to be aware that it has consequences and thus careful 'transaction' needs to be done to balance it out. On the chapter about Asian values, while it focuses more on Asian Americans, I still could relate and reflect.Those are the useful stuff. Then come the rest. I could not care less of the famous people the author use as examples of role models of introverts. I'd like to have more scientific analysis on introversion than the book gives me. Instead it provides very lengthy accounts on marriage lives and child raising practices, which I could not relate and thus feel very bored listening to them. I need more analysis than self-help tips, more 'why' than 'what' and 'how'.

There was a time when I considered myself to be an introvert, but as time has passed I have given up defining myself under any term, that being introvert or extrovert , but this book reminded me of what I loved about being defined as an introvert and the inner world we seem to share, it is true that society is based around charismatic and aggressive personalities and there is nothing wrong with that, but there is noting wrong either with a more mild and deep thinking personality , it takes all sorts to make this world and if we can learn to work together , the world would be better for it , this book it's a great step towards that.

What would you say to an attorney who loved her work on Wall Street but hated face to face meetings and found her self as the lead attorney on a negotiation team charged with solving a serious problem for a client as she sat across the table from a team of intimidating lawyers from the other side? What would you say to a frustrated and concerned parent who wanted her child to fit in and have friends but who instead preferred to read at home?How about a university student who found the "discussions" of their classes disgusting and a waste of time?With the premise in her introduction (that parallels Stephen Covey's similar views in his introduction to his 7 Habits of Highly Effective People) that a shift from a Culture of Character to a Culture of Personality has "unleashed in ordinary people-introverts and extraverts-a nagging sense of personal inferiority that plagues them to this day" Susan Cain, a self-professed introvert, begins leading us on a journey of visits to quiet people such as university and high school students, parents of "quiet" but gifted and articulate children, a well-known mega church (Saddleback Community in Southern California), and through a number of signifcant studies of introversion and extroversion as she seeks to encourage all of us to "be true to yourself."Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking, (to be published in January 2012 by Crown Publishing) is a thoroughly researched book in which Cain argues for a greater understanding and acceptance of those who are often thought shy, bookish, backward, and even anti-social - introverts. Basing her views of introversion on the views and study of Carl Jung, Cain suggests that there is a place, a much needed place at times, for introverts in our society as a companion, and in some cases, a check, against the predominate extroversion of our time.Along the way, Cain, takes us into... the workplace and challenges the current preoccupation with groupthink and argues that working alone is still a viable and necessary activity for both productivity and business success.... the modern American classroom and the need to help both school systems as well as the classroom affirm and encourage the introverted student to thrive as much as the extroverted student... the financial world and how "introverts and extroverts think (and process dopamine) differently" as she contrasts the 'Wizard of Omaha" Warren Buffett who has made money in a tough economy with those whose risk taking caused financial loss for themselves and others as well... parents, and students, who struggle with a 'shy' label that creates both personal and academic problems instead of seeing how the richness of their inner world is an assetIn this midst of this journey she focuses her study on what I have often thought about on this discussion on personality as a whole and this particular aspect of personality.How much of it is nurture and how much of it is nature? Where does free will come into play?Her significant use of studies done on identified introvert and extroverted students using MRI scans is a strength of this book as it reveals that there is a biological and chemical aspect to personality that must be considered. But in doing so she acknowledges that there is a grey area into which we must take account in the dynamic of human personality.In short, Quiet affirms the place and importance of introversion in society and Cain challenges our current extroverted society with bringing the deep and necessary gifts of those who are more introverted into play.(I wish Cain would have taken more time to discuss ambiversion as I believe that I am such a person and that there are others who are equally able to move between introversion and extroversion without difficult. But I also enjoyed her presentation of High and Low Self Monitoring (HSM's and LSM's) discussed in chapter 9, When should you act more extroverted that you really are?)In short, I believe that Quiet is going to be, and must be, a welcome volume to the discussion of personality in the years ahead because of its impact on our personal lives, our education, our workplace, our financial health, and (an area Cain briefly discussed) our faith. I am glad that Cain, whose own story is told in a unique way in the book, has written this book.I believe that this book would be a great book for college classes on personality, for those in ministerial training, as well as for human resource and educator continuing ed and training.On my review scale of 1 (poor) to 5 (great) book I rate Quiet a 5 a great read!

Susan Cain’s Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can’t Stop Talking is a powerful and important book.Quiet heightens my awareness of how extroverted students thrive on group work and class discussion while introverts thrive on opportunities for quiet reflection and expression, either on their own or with a very small group of co-thinkers. I know plenty of educators and others who believe that group work and class discussion are more valuable real-world skills than those offered to the world by introverts. That belief is a myth, and Susan Cain proves it in Quiet through study after study explained in clear, engaging language.The fact is that extroverts tend to dominate the spotlight and microphone while shouting the glories of their own attributes while introverts tend to avoid doing that. So the societal message that comes through is the extroverted version of things, and then it becomes a convoluted but self-fulfilling prophecy. The ideas in Quiet also have enormous implications for teacher professional development.
