In order for introverts to contribute to meaningful collaboration with other teachers, a reflective design is needed. Introverts are likely to contribute more in-depth, nuanced ideas to collaborative efforts, but they need a different model than what we frequently see in PLC-based schools where teachers have no choice regarding with whom they collaborate, what they discuss, or how and when their “learning” is reported. (For teachers and professional development designers, Jane Kise’s Creating a Coaching Culture for Professional Learning Communities (Solution Tree 2010) can be a useful companion to Quiet.)Quiet also delves into implications of introversion and extroversion for the business world, parenting, and relationships. If any of what I’ve said here sounds remotely relevant, please do yourself a favor and read Quiet. I saw myself on almost every page. Cross posted on What's Not Wrong?

What do Rosa Parks. Dr. Seuss and Eleanor Roosevelt have in common? They are introverts. Yep, that brave woman that refused to give up her seat, the children's book writer and the first lady all share this rather unique characteristic. Or not so unique after all. Susan Cain, the author, points out that one third of the population is introverted. Through research studies, anecdotes and examples Cain walks us through the power of quiet.This is not the typical book I read but, boy, I am glad I did. Ever since I was a kid, it has been difficult for me to interact with people. I was the student that did not speak up in class but not because I had nothing to say. Try as I might, I could not get words out. Its not a good feeling. Most frustrating of all, was that I did not understand why. Now I do, I am an introvert (and shy to boot; not all introverts are shy though). To be fair, this is something I suspected for a while but can now confirm it. First off, it should be made clear that this is not an attack on extroverts. Cain covers a broad range of topics to highlight that introverts, as well, as extroverts can make valuable contributions. Cain explains the differences between temperament and personality. That leaders do not have to be loud to triumph (Mother Teresa and Mahatma Ghandi are among the most recognized examples). Its about finding the most optimal way to communicate. This work spoke for me, to me. Without denying that there is always room for improvement, I no longer feel apologetic for the way I am. Introversion is always going to be part of my life. And know what? I don't mind that one bit. And that same girl that had a hard time speaking up in class is the same one that has no qualms about screaming and jumping up and down when my team scores a goal.

I am so surprised by how much I loved this book! I think its FANTASTIC! And it helped explain a lot of how I experience the world and why certain things do and do not work for me. Being an introvert can be very tricky in today's society and I found this book so reassuring!This book is very readable. It's a pretty quick read, moving fast & keeping the readers attention consistently. The variety of situations and topics covered in the book were great. There was a good mix of explanation, tips and examples within the book. I think this would be good for both introverts AND extroverts to read - to help us all understand one another better. I can think of a number of people in my own life that I wish would read this so they can better understand some of the choices that I make instead of treating me as if I'm crazy for those choices. I think it would be valuable for ALL of us to better understand one another and work together to honor the BEST in everyone!I strongly recommend this one!

I am introvert and I have lived in an extrovert world. I used to be quite, shy and almost invisible, always standing at the corner. I was happy with my books and doing hand work and solitude! Everyone had an advice for me. Be social, talk! That's not good. That's not normal! I always thought that something was wrong with me. It took years to understand how to live in this world and how to overcome my shyness and I'm normal as any other extroverts. I wish I could read this book when I was 16. This book is not just for introverts people. One third of the people are introvert, so you or one of your relatives is introvert. introverts have to learn how to live in this extroverts societies and extroverts need to learn how to communicate with introverts. this book has done a good job of explaining the differences and presenting many researches and theories about introvert/extrovert psychologies.
I reviewed this both on my channel and goodreads back in January. Why is goodreads taking books off of my read shelf..

Excellent book on the world of introverts and extroverts. It gets into the weeds and plows through stereotypes. Though there are traits that will be recognizable to all, it goes past some standard black and white snapshot to one with more nuanced shades of gray (with layers upon layers of things to consider). For those that like lots of data, this is the book for you. This is a well-researched book that isn't some fluff piece. One thing shared early on in the book gave me pause. Infants that cry more or overact to things are more likely to be introverts. The reason being is that they are more sensitive to new stimuli. This caught my attention as I'm an introvert but I didn't cry when I was born. I was calm, cool, and collected said my mom. This book had many such moments for me as the author gets into different aspects thought of as exclusive to introverts or extroverts and how they aren't so cut-and-dried. Being an introvert doesn't automatically mean you are also bookish and shy anymore than being an extrovert means one can't be either of these things. There are different types of introverts and extroverts - nothing is black and white.The book explores how introverts and extroverts relate to each other (or don't as the case may be) - this part is worth the read alone. It also explores why introverts get passed over for leadership positions in favor of extroverts. And why often it's a mistake, as most financial collapses can bear witness to (fueled by too many extroverts making too many risky decisions). The book explains why someone like introvert Warren Buffett makes a better leader than someone like extrovert Donald Trump (the gist is that the latter gets too much of a buzz from the attention he gets than giving attention to detail). The book brings home that it's all too easy to confuse schmoozing ability with talent. All too often, schmoozing is rewarded over critical thinking. While the book leans more to singing the praises of introverts, it certainly doesn't discount what extroverts have to offer. The book brings home that both doers and thinkers make the world go round. A world with only introverts would be just as much of a disaster as one filled only with extroverts, though the former might be a lot more quiet. The part of the book that discussed brainstorming sessions rang true. I've been part of countless brainstorming sessions and I find validity to the studies shared in the book that show that groupthink can kill creativity and that better ideas initially come from solitary brainstorming. There are several reasons, but suffice it to say that the loudest bird doesn't always get the worm, but they often drown out great ideas with their mediocre bluster. Of course extroverts have stellar ideas, but sometimes their showy banter is given more weight than it deserves.The most revealing part of the book has to do with why so many people are medicated for anxiety these days. It dives into the history of how and why the culture of personality overrode the culture of character. This shift required everyone in America to strive for some extrovert standard that was oppressive and quite frankly made introverts anxious. Cue the Xanax.When people moved out of small towns to the big city, it changed things. In small towns everyone knew most everyone for generations. They knew each other's business and everyone was invested in children becoming adults with character. When moving to the big city, one needed a shortcut to show they were of good character. Personality became that shortcut and pretty soon that shortcut replaced the real thing, character.It's easy to see why anxiety plagues so many in this country as half are likely introverts being asked to devalue their rich inner lives for a more showy extrovert ideal. An introvert having to live as an extrovert to survive would make anyone have to pop a chill pill. It turned half of us into circus performers until the ultimate circus, social media, took the wheel and drove us into a world where the culture of personality reigns supreme. Without personality trumping character, something like Facebook could not even exist (ironically created by an introvert). This book explains someone like our current U.S. president. Someone like him could never have won an election in a time when character mattered most. In the culture of character, the ideal would be serious, disciplined, and honorable. Bragging would be considered bad form. What impression one made in public would never be as important as how one behaved in private. The idea of a personality didn't even exist until the 18th century and the idea of having what one might call a "good personality" wasn't a real consideration until the twentieth century. It makes one wonder if America is largely responsible for this cult of personality as it forged its own path and myths. As American's, we are very big on myths of freedom and equality even though we have never had a moment where all have been considered or welcomed as equal by all. This makes me think about the Wild West and its cowboy criminals and later the age of the gangster that led to a major shift in hero worship - when we went from revering someone of character to obsessing over bad boys with personality. This led to being preoccupied with how others perceived us. Cue the Tequila shooters.There was an interesting correlation between the rise of the cult of personality and that of corporations and the self-help mania that focused on outer charm versus virtue. Add to that America's first tycoons and matinee idols and it was a perfect storm that led to the nonsense we have today of self-help gurus gunning to sell us a more dynamic life. The gist being that if you aren't an extrovert, you best fake it until you make it. I think the book leaves one having respect for the other side of the way of being in this world. There are things I'll never get a thrill out of in the same way as some true-blue extroverts but on the flip side, well, there's a flip side.This book has so many interesting things to ponder that I couldn't possibly hit on all of them in this review. What I have shared here is only a taste. I highly recommend reading this book.

I'm an introvert and I didn't like this book.When I was a child, I was decently popular. I had friends and good ones at that. One friend I've had for about 16 years. Another I've had for 9-10. But, I always drew my strength from being alone. Always. My parents are introverts as well, although they're like me. We can be extrovert and conform to situations as needed, however we largely enjoy being alone in separate parts of the house doing our own things. My mom always enforced alone time when I was a child so she could recuperate. In high school, I was remarkedly quieter. Which was when I heard about this book. If I read this book in high school, I would have loved it. Finally, reasons why I am this way! Finally, a way to show that the extroverts I'm around are insane!Now I'm almost done with college. I'm completely different. Still an introvert, but also high school was very difficult for me. I was a transgender person living in the closet because I didn't want to deal with my peers. Now, I'm out and proud. I pass very well and I'm unafraid of people who may not accept me for who I am. Also in high school, I wasn't as adept at looking at arguments and seeing their flaws.So, if you want a positive review of this book, there are many out there. Almost everyone I'm friends with or follow who have read this book have rated it 4-5 stars.* Read those. This is not a positive review, even if I did like some things about the book.My first issue is that this book is basically a self-congratulation for Susan Cain. It reads as: "Look at all of this information! See, the extroverts are wrong and we're right!" It's written by an introvert for introverts. This book is basically a way to show introverts that they have loads of research on their side to make them better and whatever. But, leading into my second issue, Susan Cain denies that there's a bias. She'll list off all of this information and studies and they all imply the same thing. Introverts are better. Introverts are the ones we should look to. Introverts are better adapted in x, y, and z. Then, almost like that racist person most of us know, she throws her hands up and says, "But I'm not biased!"My third issue is that someone who doesn't understand psychology shouldn't talk about it. Her theory about the rise of extroversion and how it's being promoted in businesses, schools, and other places is something she calls the new groupthink. Cain, that is not groupthink. Groupthink is the idea that people come together in groups and there is a lack of creativity. There is a person who rules the group and there's no way for dissenters to disagree with what's being said. Group polarization definitely plays a part in this, but it's not a new groupthink. Moreover, she starts randomly talking about psychopathy. (Maybe it was a jab at extroverts, but who the hell knows.) I'm in a class about psychopathy and, I hate to break it to you, psychopathy and sociopathy are not interchangable words.**My last complaint sort of ties in with my first, that this book is self-congratulatory. Every hypothetical situation that Cain talks about focuses on females. Because females are also the typical paradigm for introversion. She just focuses on females and their things. Probably because that's what she knows. And it was annoying. Talk about more than just women in your hypothetical stituations. Or, even better, be gender neutral! I know that people think that saying "they" is gramatically incorrect, but that's just not true. It's inclusive and honors that there are people out there that don't belong in the male/female binary.Basically, this book was good in some ways but my complaints outweigh them. It was well-written and competent in most places. The history of how our thinking changed from being more introverted to being extrovert is interesting. If she had left it there, I'd have been on board with it more. The only thing I'll take away that's positive is that I would use her chapter on school children and parenting. It was the tamest chapter that didn't show her bias.*There's one exception to this. One.**Sociopathy is more related with negative life events and life experiences. Psychopathy is that plus a genetic aspect. Sociopathy is also more like antisocial personality disorder, which is higher on different traits. If you look at the primary measure for psychopathy, ASPD is higher in the second factor while psychopathy is higher in the first factor. There's a whole lot of differences.

Say the word introvert and many people envision an antisocial loner hiding from the world. In Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking, author Susan Cain dispels the myths and negative connotations associated with the word introvert. As she explains, the “word introvert is not a synonym for hermit or misanthrope. Introverts can be these things, but most are perfectly friendly." Cain also tackles what it means to be an introvert in an American culture where being an extrovert is the ideal. The book highlights various findings of research and studies. One such finding is that introverts tend to be more sensitive to stimulation than extroverts, which I think leads to the stereotype of being antisocial. It’s not that introverts are particularly antisocial, it’s just that they find an abundance of stimulation draining. Where an extrovert needs to recharge by being social, introverts need time to recharge by spending some time alone. There was also a section offering advice for introverts on how to work in open space, team oriented business environments, which has become incredibly popular within the last twenty years, as well as advise for managers and business owners on how to create an environment that brings out the best of both introverts and extroverts. Cain points to studies that indicate the fallacy of open space environments being conducive to productivity and creativity. They have the opposite effect. Cain also includes a section for teachers and parents on working with introverted children. Despite these interesting tidbits, I found Quiet disappointing. I’m not sure what I was expecting, but I thought it would delve a little deeper. Much of the book felt sort of “surface” and shallow. A large portion felt like filler. The book was organized by topic, but it felt as though she jump around too much, which I think had the effect of making it feel as though she was glossing over things and not delving deeply. I also thought the section related to various Asian countries was overly broad. Instead of differentiating between them, she just lumped everyone under the umbrella of “Asian”. I get that she was trying to compare the Asian experience and culture with the American extrovert culture, but it would have been far more interesting if she had discussed introversion and extroversion from within the various cultures while also comparing their experiences east vs. west. Don’t get me wrong, it was interesting to read how the American culture of extroversion is perceived, but it could have been handled better. So, while Quiet offers interesting insight into the world of the introvert, overall I found it to be disappointing. While I still definitely think it's worth a read, I would recommend borrowing it from a library. Final rating: 3 stars

Susan Cain gives the reader an in-depth look at the differences between people that are introverts and those that are extroverts. She uses stories of real people, psychological studies, and lots of research to show how being an introvert or an extrovert impacts our day to day lives. Susan Cain talks a lot about how our culture is turning more and more extroverted and she gives some helpful advice to introverts on how to survive and thrive in this extroverted culture.I really got a lot of good information from this book. I am an introvert myself and after reading the stories of the many people Susan Cain interviews for this book I feel like I am not so alone in my desire to stay home and read on a weekend night instead of going to a party. What struck me the most while reading this was how much being an introvert of extrovert effects so many aspects of our lives. There are a lot of scientific parts to this book including case studies of experiments done, descriptions on how are brains work, the fight or flight response, etc. These parts some people might find tedious or boring, but I found them very interesting and I learned a lot from them.The most important part of the book for me was the advice Susan Cain gives to introverts and parents of introverted children. She talks about making time every day to be alone to recharge, how to talk to the extroverts in our lives, and things teachers can do to help children who are introverted to have a better learning experience. Having introverted children I wish this book was required reading for all teachers in my school district. Quiet is an excellent book for those interested in psychology or those looking for more information on what it really means to be an introvert.

I like the idea behind this book, but so far I'm not sure how well the author is succeeding in presenting her point.She makes it clear early on that "introverted" and "shy" are not the same thing...and then proceeds, at least in the early chapters, to fail to distinguish between the two.Preferring solitude and requiring alone time to recharge-hallmarks of introversion-are normal and healthy. Being pathologically incapable of functioning in a social situation because one is terrified of contact with other human beings-extreme shyness-is not.I am both introverted and shy. I wish I had been encouraged in my youth to be less shy. I missed out on a lot in school because I couldn't bring myself to ask for help when I didn't understand something in class.At least in these early chapters (I'm 17% in to the Kindle version), the author makes clear her disdain for the excessive extroversion preached by the likes of Tony Robbins and the Harvard Business School, but also seems to think that social anxiety disorders don't exist, or wouldn't if we didn't value personality over substance so highly.Finished the book last night. Interesting and gave me things to think about. This is another book I sort of wish I had in print, so I could flip around and look at certain parts again.

Ironically, it took me a long time to read this book because every time I picked it up and focused on a page some twerp would start babbling inanities about some trifling matter or another, thereby legitimizing the subtitle of the book in question. As for the book itself: well written and utterly engrossing right up to the last chapter or two, in which Ms Cain holds forth generally on the care and handling and education of the introverted child. In spite of the slow finish, the book is definitely worth the time it takes to read it.

There were parts that I enjoyed reading in this book. I mean, all the things I’ve struggled with and had to deal with is laid out very clearly here, and it’s validating in that sense. To know that it’s a struggle for so many people. But something about the tone of this book didn’t sit right with me. I think it’s a subject that needs more attention and discussion, but I’m not sure this book is it? On one level, this had to do with my expectations of the book. I expected something a bit more thorough, and maybe a bit more radical in its outlook. For instance, if extraversion/extroversion has become a mode of life, and primarily seen as the only way to survive (i.e. make a living), then what is it about capitalism and modes of work under capitalism that forces people into these extremely rigid forms of permissible behaviour? One would think that would be a question that comes up. I mean, I get it, I can’t expect leftist politics in all my books but it’s just weird that instead of looking at introverts and people who struggle to be well-adjusted in a profit-driven society in terms of what might be systemic structures that contribute to this, it’s essentialised into personality traits or genes or weird evolutionary psychology-type theories.I was expecting a more rigorously researched social history of personality traits. Instead, there’s a bit of waffling and all sorts of theories cherry-picked at random. There is one section that cites the work of a scientist who talks about how certain physical traits embody the behavioural traits of an introvert. So there’s something there about being fair-skinned and blue-eyed and being more thoughtful and introspective or something. The author admits there’s something weird about that without calling this shit out for what it is: racist! Especially since she cites examples from Disney where “rough-featured” and darker-skinned people are portrayed as “brash”. So yes, identifying white Aryan features with thoughtfulness and introspective tendencies is tantamount to saying darker-skinned people without “delicate” facial features are lumbering oafs. You need to call that shit out in your book. Saying, “OK, hmm, that’s interesting but maybe kinda not good” is not being an objective journalist, it’s perpetuating fucked-up thinking that leads to eugenics.Also, there is an entire chapter saying that to be Chinese is to be an introvert. Well, I’m simplifying, but so does the author. And that’s precisely the kind of thing I don’t like in my nonfiction. I could not even believe this chapter passed the editing stage. I mean, what? Also, what about the racism Chinese kids deal with in American society? Does that not factor into their behaviour? How can everything boil down to introversion vs extroversion? There are all these social factors like gender, class, race, caste that are never addressed at all, in any intelligent way, in terms of how it might complicate the introvert vs extrovert schematics. There are parts that I liked and then there are these repetitive, waffly bits just sort of thrown in there to make a book. There are some sections that are illuminating, and would be great for parents and educators. But it’s sandwiched in-between the waffly stuff. And I get the sense that Cain is building a brand off of “quiet”. Like, it’s not about pointing out how people who are introverts and demeaned as shy, etc. might have some fundamental problems with society. That maybe they’re ill-adjusted to a rapacious, capitalist, profit-seeking nightmare society. But this book sort of dials that down and sort of suggests that there are ways to monetise your quietness. Cain dares to cite Rosa Parks. Parks did not try to adjust to white supremacy. She did not retreat into her cubicle to design computers and become a capitalist. She wanted a fundamental shift in how social relations are organised. Parks’ actions were radical. It demanded a change. This book, on the other hand, gently nudges you to adjust to how life is. So that you can get by and make some money and become successful in all the conventional ways. That’s weird, to me. That is far from a quiet revolution. It’s just capitulation, but with “introvert” as a label.On the other hand, a lot of introverts are outsiders, but no doubt a lot of them use various forms of social privilege to behave irresponsibly towards others and leave most of the emotional labour to women or people of colour. I mean, some are full-fledged psychopaths who have no doubt used “introversion” as a shield to become the kind of people who carry guns into a public place to shoot up people because girls don’t want to have sex with them. So there’s that. Just a very weird book. Muddled and strange. Life is a hell of a lot more complicated than a division between people who don’t know how to be alone vs those of us who just want to be left alone to read a book.

A nagging sensation has pestered me incessantly through recent years. As I have not yet reached 30, I hope this sensation does not signify a mid-life crisis. However, I have recently felt a bit hopeless, that I will never find the American version of success through any profession or medium from which I experience a deep sense of passion or fulfillment.Listen, Ben...you gotta toughen up. The world's mean and doesn't care about you. Sure, your art was cute when you were a kid and I'm glad you had so much fun making books out of paper and tagboard in elementary school - it makes for great family reunion material. But, now, let's make sure we're obsessing over music at a reasonable level. And good Lord you read a lot! I can only imagine these words have reached the ears of many introverts as they come up in the world. To the listener, I have to assume that such words immediately translate into a dichotomous perspective of superiority and inferiority - valuable and wasteful. Of course, the listener instinctively categorizes themselves on one side of the split. Unfortunately, one might feel that their passions will never come to successful fruition in American consumerism because introverted tendencies and aspirations are just so darn undesirable - despite evidence to the contrary! Take music out of the schools! Those introverts need to learn how to make themselves note-worthy despite all the commotion of people competing to generate the next economic bubble! We would let them down if we did otherwise! Then quietly, someone suggests how music increases math and science scores. But the loud guy wins because that makes more sense than reasonable ideas.You want to be an art teacher?!?!? Good luck finding work.So on and so forth. But I'll quiet down now.Cain's book first inspired an emphatic resonance for me when she described the rise of personality over character - the evolution of American values from defining personal quality according to character and ethics to the sometimes shameless promotion of economic success as the determining factor for personal worth. I felt like a man at a rally speech violently shouting my fielty to Cain's message. Of course, all this happened in my head.Yet by deconstructing our current value system, showing how those values have shifted as described above, and exposing illogical idolization of extroversion as the means to American success, the introvert can confidently abandon feelings of low self-efficacy in a world that continually purges them to the outside rims. An introvert may find comfort on such fringes of parties, but I cannot concede that an introvert finds comfort in feeling unwanted, purged, worthless or diagnosable. Cain wields a wide variety of psychological and sociological research to make her point - introverts not only have value, but suffer under unfair stereotypes illogically associated with their preferences. Many of the reasons western culture idolizes extroversion make little sense. And along the path to this cultural sentiment, we've lost a sense of value for things previous generations would have died for: honor, integrity, etc. These qualities have not passed into extinction, but we have redefined their value according to what they can produce. And extroverts portray such characteristics as well! Cain made every attempt to describe the ideal of social and psychological balance between the traits; though I imagine many skeptics chastising her thesis anyway. If one were to read her conclusion first, it may sound as sentimental fluff - but her research! It lends unlikely credence to feelings expressed by many who have already considered the personality imbalance. To those who love quiet nights with a book with classical music blaring (I mean, subtly humming in the background), working in the office alone, who feel ashamed for wanting to avoid the party or "going out" in college (seriously...they talked about "out" like it was place down the street!), rediscover yourself through this book. Just because the status quo idolizes something, does not mean the disenfranchised should value themselves accordingly. After all, what group dynamic or sickness - racism, gender discrimination, etc - has not endured a similar enlightenment?

I’ve always counted myself an introvert so this book didn’t surprise me on how I could spot an introvert based on some specific traits. I already knew how! (You might know as well, but in case you don’t, you could take Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) test or answer the twenty questions provided by the author in this book.) This book has useful and practical advice for those who want to live a better life (Really!) It is an important read for anyone interested in the introvert-extrovert psychology research. Many introverts find it difficult to live in a world dominated by extroverts. The society tends to value the gregarious go-getters, the loud talkers and the forceful presenters. Business environments are dominated by people who themselves are extroverts and have developed highly social skills. Schools and work areas are well suited for people with high interest in socializing, teamwork, constant connection and multitasking. Susan Cain feels this idealization wrong. She proves that introversion is real and indeed a necessary type of personality that should be valued. "It might be sometimes helpful to pretend to be an extrovert, No big deal!", she says. But in the long run, staying true to one’s own temperament is the key to finding work or the relationship he/she desires. Here is the summary of Mrs. Cain’s advice in her own words: “The secret to life is to put yourself in the right lighting. For some it’s a Broadway spotlight; for others, a lamplit desk. Use your natural powers—of persistence, concentration, insight, and sensitivity—to do work you love and work that matters. Solve problems, make art, think deeply.Figure out what you are meant to contribute to the world and make sure you contribute it. If this requires public speaking or networking or other activities that make you uncomfortable, do them anyway. But accept that they’re difficult, get the training you need to make them easier, and reward yourself when you’re done.Quit your job as a TV anchor and get a degree in library science. But if TV anchoring is what you love, then create an extroverted persona to get yourself through the day. Here’s a rule of thumb for networking events: one new honest-to-goodness relationship is worth ten fistfuls of business cards. Rush home afterward and kick back on your sofa. Carve out restorative niches.”And her final praise to introverts! :“We know from myths and fairy tales that there are many different kinds of powers in this world. One child is given a light saber, another a wizard’s education. The trick is not to amass all the different kinds of available power, but to use well the kind you’ve been granted. Introverts are offered keys to private gardens full of riches. To possess such a key is to tumble like Alice down her rabbit hole. She didn’t choose to go to Wonderland—but she made of it an adventure that was fresh and fantastic and very much her own.Lewis Carroll was an introvert, too, by the way. Without him, there would be no Alice in Wonderland. And by now, this shouldn’t surprise us.”

"The secret to life is to put yourself in the right lighting. For some it’s a Broadway spotlight; for others, a lamplit desk."Mine is definitely the latter.I was impressed by all the scientific research and effort Cain had put in assembling and presenting each chapter. Her storytelling, also, is downright exquisite and compelling. I was hooked throughout despite that nagging boredom at times whenever she drifts into too much research data. These envelop each chapter's story in a circuitous fashion that is both enjoyable and persuasive, but can be boring if you're like me, eager to get the gist of it.I feel like I've come out with a decent understanding of extroversion and introversion after finishing this book. Although I admit, my reading would have been better were it not for my occasional dozes on the bus! I definitely need a second reading.Here is the sum of what I've learned, what I can recall at the moment at least and have the energy to put into writing:- Introverts are sensitive to novelty and social stimulation. They need solo time to recharge. They are often quiet and soft-spoken. They favor one-to-one conversations about deeper meaningful topics and feel awkward when it comes to small talk.- Extroverts are sensitive to familiarity and aloneness. They need social stimulation to recharge. They are often loud and have get-up-and-go style. They favor group conversations and are good in small talk.- Introverts need to develop an "extroverted persona" in order to cope with social demands. This is why the aforementioned characteristics can be deceptive in categorizing people at times. Introverts also need to establish "restorative niches," solitary timeouts to recover from too much social stimulation.- Being loud and gregarious, speaking with confidence, has zero correlation with the 
soundness
 of 
ideas
. In other words, don't confuse social confidence with wisdom.- In relationships, during arguments, introverts tend to become silent and withdrawn. Their tone becomes cold and detached. Extroverts, however, tend to become talkative and direct. Their tone becomes loud and engaged. In other words, extroverts tend to 
hiss
 and 
bite
, whereas introverts tend to 
recoil
. This is when misunderstanding happens because extroverts tend to see 
hissing
 and 
biting
 as a sign of 
caring
 and 
love
; they see 
recoiling
 and 
silence
 as a sign of 
indifference
. The opposite is true for introverts. They see 
recoiling
 and 
silence
 as a sign of 
caring
.- Solution: introverts need to learn that it's okay to 
hiss
 and become argumentative. Extroverts need to learn that it's okay to 
recoil
 and become silent.

So far, it's uninteresting psychobabble drivel. But I'll withhold judgment until (if?) I finish. Oops, too late.[/update]I have finally finished this unbearable book of platitudes. "Figure out what you are meant to contribute to the world and make sure you contribute it," she writes. "Love is essential; gregariousness is optional." And a good thing, too. "Spend your free time the way you like, not the way you think you're supposed to." If lines like this make you, like me, want to vomit, then you may want to reconsider spending your free time finishing this book like you think you're supposed to.This book had little interesting to say about introversion that could not be captured in a 60-second Google search. It seemed to me that the book's primary purpose was, in fact, to flatter introverts -- the book's likely audience -- by telling them that they are not alone and that they, too, could contribute Value to the world. One of the author's favorite gambits, for example, is to reveal that some of history's greatest and most successful personages -- Mahatma Gandhi! Rosa Parks! Warren Buffett! Eleanor Roosevelt! -- were introverts (ZOMG! We introverts are awesome, hooray, lulz!). "None of this is to denigrate those who forget ahead quickly, or to blindly glorify the reflective and careful," the author hastens to explain. Except that it is, wink wink. She spends most of the book telling introverts what we already know about ourselves: that we are the way we are. (See, e.g., anectodal examples of introverts acting introverted, ad nauseum! And it's OKAY! Introversion is perfectly normal, guys! We're just mizunderst00d by those unfeeling, unthinking extroverts.)To be sure, the author offers some potentially useful advice for parents of introverts, and for teachers and managers (Be mindful that there are introverts in the world. Don't just structure the world around extroverts! 'kay, thanks!). But the main thrust of the book is Hooray Introverts!, Introverts Are Cool!, If You're An Introvert and Want to Hear All About How You Are Just As Awesome As Everyone Else Please Buy My Book!Consider this introvert utterly bored.

Around 4.5/5, not because I thought it was a 5-star book , but because it wasn't like any other book I read before (psychological nonfiction) and took a long time to finish ; reading one book for over 2 weeks just ruins the whole process.  I thought introversion explains the behavioral term usually about tendency to hide feelings from others or personal preference to build walls around himself. I didn't know that my soft voice, risk-avoidance, reluctance in participating group activities, fear of public speaking, and solitude seeking were also characters of an introvert, instead, I just believed they were the flaws blocking me from being sociable person. In "Quiet", Susan Cain not only persuaded introverts to be not worried about their shy, cerebral and quiet qualities, but convinced them to make use of those differences.  Citing many references and researches, she almost made me believe that my introvert nature was inborn quality and cannot be changed with time and experiences. But shyness, quiet manners, fear of socializing can be covered through acting like an extrovert, if necessary. Hiding behind a rhino-skin, an introvert can be pseudo-extrovert. Loved the ideas and messages Susan Cain intended to deliver to her readers; they were powerful, clear, and immensely useful for the introverts who see themselves as freaks or anti-social ones. Also the examples were amazing, including stories of Rosa Parks, Mahatma Gandhi , Eleanor Roosevelt and Stephen Wozniak, all considered as introverts. Planning to read more psychology books.

4/5 - Full review at emileereads: http://emileereads.com/blog/2017/2/16...One third to one half of people in the world are introverts. Quiet is a wonderfully researched look into an introvert’s mind and life in this extroverted society. Cain cited dozens of scientific studies and researched as many people and books in her quest to explain why quiet people are the way that they are, and how they can thrive in today’s loud world.A large section of the book focused on introversion in the work place. I was glad Cain talked at length about open office plans and how studies have proven they're not that effective. The thought of an open office makes me want to cry. I would literally walk out of an interview if it was an open office - after explaining why, of course. The book did a good job of explaining how important it is to use your quiet skills, even while presenting or working in groups. At no point did Cain make this book into one glorifying the introverted person over the extroverted. She repeatedly emphasized the need for all types of people in order to create healthy environments and often compared the two. So often, I see memes or articles on the internet dissing extroverts for being loud and rude and I think that's a problem. I would happily read the extrovert version of this book. I'm giving Quiet four out of five stars. I loved the content and the careful research - that part really could not have been better - but some parts read rather slowly.

This book reminded me a lot of Willpower in that it also would have struck me as brilliantly illuminating if I had read it 15 years earlier. As it is, I thought this book about introverts did a good job of expressing things I already understand, such as the idea of understanding your own "sweet spot" of mental/social stimulation: "Imagine how much better you'll be at this sweet-spot game once you're aware of playing it." And this is a pretty good description of life inside my head: "Introverts tend to sit around wondering about things, imagining things, recalling events from their past, and making plans for the future." The closest thing to new information from this book, for me, was the discussion of how introverts can steel themselves to be more extrovert-like in the pursuit of things they care passionately about. That feels right, and I'd never quite thought of it that way.You would probably find this book more worthwhile if the concept of introversion were new to you and/or you recognize yourself in it. In a nutshell, introverts are people who tend to be thoughtful and conscientious, who take time to recover from social situations rather than gaining energy from them, and who are easily overstimulated, in part because they are very observant and notice more details.

Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking is an informative book about the value of being an introvert in a society that pushes people to be extroverted. The author cites research into the strengths and weaknesses of both introverts and extroverts, showing why both are important in business, relationships, and the classroom. She also writes about Eastern cultures that place more value on an introverted lifestyle than we find in Western culture. She encourages introverted individuals that spend their time in extroverted leadership positions to carve out restorative niches (quiet time, research, reading) in their day. Suggestions are included for parents to help their introverted child feel comfortable in the classroom and on playdates. The book was well researched and held my interest.

A great book to read if you're an introvert as the majority of GoodReads readers probably are. You're not weird because you prefer to be alone with a book or have a small group of friends. You're an introvert who (at least in America) is surrounded by groups of extroverts.Being an introvert has great advantages - it is probably true that most of the great thinkers were introverts - but only if you can relate to extroverts sufficiently that you are not ignored or dismissed by your peers.I wish I had this book when I was growing up. As an introverted executive who spends much of their time with hugely extraverted executives, I have found over time many of the survival techniques given in this book for managing one's energy in an extravert world, but it would have caused much less dissonance along the way if I'd known why I seemed to act and value things so differently from my happy and talkative peers.

I am the definition of an introvert (hello, bookworm) and I've always felt that life would be easier if I were more outgoing. This book is full of insightful information about how being introverted can actually be a good thing in a world that generally perceives extroverted personalities as ideal. I especially liked the message that introverts can achieve great things not in spite of being introverted but because they are introverted (for example, introverted leaders are more likely to listen and value the input and ideas of those around them). Also, I had fun spouting off random facts to friends and family about why introverts are cool and explained to my husband that introverts and extroverts perceive different levels of noise as "just right" and he should be mindful of that (he's the definition of an extrovert and the bane of my existence because he's so LOUD).I'd highly recommend this book to any introvert or anyone who knows an introvert!

This book is validating. I must take time to compose myself before committing to a full review, but know that without question it is one of the five most important non-fiction books I have ever read. EVER. I cried through the whole conclusion of the book, because this book was me, I identified with the children, and the adults, and to just know that I'm really not alone, that I really AM this way, is just so amazing. There is nothing wrong with being an introvert. There is nothing wrong with being an extrovert. We can change the way we interact with each other, teach our children, and structure our lives, and we can all strive for a better, healthier goal.P.S. If I could assign mandatory reading to the world at large, this would get assigned.

EVERYONE. READ THIS BOOK. NOW. I've never wanted to give a book to everyone I know so badly (okay, except maybe the Bible). It's gold. As a hardcore introvert, this book resonated with me on every page and made so much of how I feel and see things and respond to things make so much sense. It was hugely helpful, absolutely brilliant, deeply insightful, fascinating, wise, and just so very good. "The power of introverts in a world that can't stop talking" -- YES. Introverts and extroverts alike-- read this and I promise you will understand people and yourself more clearly and it will change your life. Also-- Susan's TED talk is incredible too, if you're more into that sort of thing than you are into reading a whole book. Whatever you do, just soak up her goodness ASAP.

I picked up this book few years ago, when it just came out and it instantly made me feel good about being an introvert. Susan Cain talks about the power of silence, and why we need to listen more, and talk less. A must read if you're an introvert.
Review under contemplation.

There are things about this book I really liked, especially all the tips on raising introverted children. Very good information.  My only problem was that I felt the author was harsh on the extroverts. I know she was trying to let introverts feel more important, but why is it necessary to say extroverts are clumsy, pushy and basically slow-witted?

“Why shouldn't quiet be strong? And what else can quiet do that we don’t give it credit for?” Before reading this book, I remembered the time I encountered the word ‘introvert’ for the very first time. Shy and quiet, crave solitude, seemingly unsocial  were some of the terms the author used to explain the word, and somewhere inside my mind, I screamed: This is so me! What followed was akin to the boundless joy every bibliophile across the globe must have experienced at least once: the sense of belonging; the assuring knowledge that you’re not alone, that there’s someone somewhere who can relate to what you feel, what you think. And there was something greatly relieving about the fact that to differ in traits with your peers is no big deal; that it’s all completely normal. You’re an introvert. Those people are extroverts. Two different personalities, that’s all.But it was only much later I realized that people mostly considered introversion as some kind of a flaw or disadvantage. Negative connotations are regularly employed whenever the word is uttered, and I've had my fair share of experiences as well. Extremely introverted was how someone dejectedly remarked about a peer who hardly socialized with anyone except a friend or two; anti-social, apathetic, selfish, moody socially awkward, misanthrope are only few of the large chunk of words used to “describe” introverts. We live in a culture that extols the Extrovert Ideal, where gregariousness is considered ideal, and quiet unacceptable. Susan Cain makes a compelling and engaging defense of introversion, and the book is filled with a perfect mix of scientific research and anecdotal evidences. The book did a lot of wonderful things to me. Most importantly, it took me back to all those times I had- consciously and unconsciously - behaved in ways that I couldn't fully comprehend or fathom back then, and answered all my Whys with clear and impeccable evidence; it has added a much needed sense of lucidity and clarity to my life; it gave me great dollops of inspiration (the striking image of the young Steve Wozniak working late into the night in his cubicle is still in front of me), and fanned my growing interest in neuroscience.“We know from myths and fairy tales that there are many different kinds of powers in the world. One child is given a light saber, another wizard's education. The trick is not to amass all the different kinds of available power, but to use well the kind you've been granted. Introverts are offered keys to private gardens full of riches. To possess such a key is to tumble like Alice down her rabbit hole. She didn't choose to go to Wonderland -- but she made of it an adventure that was fresh and fantastic and very much her own.” Quiet: the power of introverts."In a gentle way, one can shake the world." (Mahatma Gandhi)

PREACH, SISTER.This did not get a full 5 stars, as I would have liked to see more about how mental illness and introversion interact with each other (does one cause the other? how much harder is it for mentally ill introverts to act extroverted?), it really brought things into focus for me. Not only did it help me realize what being "sensitive" really meant, but it also solidly explained the cultural transition from neutral introversion to excessive extroversion (aka "oh, that's why I've turned into a cynical misanthrope!")I always thought that "sensitive" was a term used for people who were startled by anything and cried too easily. However, Cain explains sensitive introverts in terms that I found myself nodding along with--overly-stimulated senses, feeling anxious over small things, avoiding things that will over-stimulate... it all made much more sense, and I immediately started seeing points throughout my life where I showed sensitivity. It's not just feeling emotional, it's feeling connected to something so strongly that you just can't even. Oddly enough, though, I sometimes do seek out over-stimulating pieces of art because I can fall into them for hours at a time, picking them apart.But the best part, the chapter I want to memorize and quote at chipper interviewers and people who think presence and face is the only thing that will get you anywhere, is the first chapter. Cain explains how society used to be (blissfully) introverted, and how it abruptly changed in the 1920s to be extroverted--and has only gotten more extroverted since. The golden age of introversion is called the Culture of Character, when honor, sacrifice, and modesty was key, and how private life was more important than public life. But with the increasingly consumeristic and vain culture of the 20s, people started caring more about how they came across in public, creating the Culture of Personality (*cue the earworm*). It continued to grow until it's reached where it is now, where extroversion and putting your whole life out there is par for the course. People don't exist if they don't do that, and it makes it difficult to get by in the world today (at least in the U.S.). If you are introverted and would rather keep to yourself, society doesn't care--you need to fake extroversion to really get more opportunities.Unfortunately, no tips were really given if you would rather stay true to your introversion and not bow to the oversharing of your life.I had seen this book on feeds for a long time, but had thought "I know I'm introvert, what more do I need to know?" SO MUCH MORE apparently. It explained so many awkward points in my life and showed that introversion is totally normal and healthy and just as valid as extroversion--even if our narcissistic society tries to convince us differently.

Every personality type assessment that I have ever taken has placed me smack dab in the middle of the E & I spectrum. I am equal parts Extrovert and Introvert, or as Cain describes it, I am an ambivert. The introvert in me loved this book. It is educational and empowering. Cain details the undervalued strengths of introverts in a society that tends to give preference to individuals who exude extrovert qualities (a theory called the "Extrovert Ideal"). I found myself identifying with a lot of introvert qualifiers that she described. I think I was hooked within the first couple pages where she said something like ... it's not that introverts don't like going out and socializing, it's just that at some point in the evening there will come a time where they wish they were in their bed with a book. Umm ... yes.Cain not only made many points to identify with, but she also uses this book as a tool to explore biological explanations to being an introvert and studies that have demonstrated the strengths of introverts. The research that she cited was interesting and easy to understand. As compelling as this was to read, I have to say that it's not going to be for everyone. As I said, the introvert side of me loved this book. The extrovert in me - not so much. It's not that Cain discounts the strengths of extroverts. Just the opposite, in fact - she consistently recognizes that our society would fail to function without a balance of the two personalities. What she does is point out that there is a flawed societal desire to have everyone at least act like extroverts, even if they aren't one. In pointing out the pitfalls in that desire, Cain often makes extroverts appear as rash, unintelligent, and unaffected people. I'm sure that is not her intent, because she does so in a way to illustrate where listening to an introvert's voice could have prevented some big failures (aka the Wall Street Crash) and could help a business thrive. However, individuals who don't identify with introvert characteristics might not see this as the learning tool that it could be because she talks plenty about the downfalls of extroverts and it is hard not to get defensive.If you are an introvert, or think you might be, this is a great read. It helps explain and validate the introvert personality on a larger scale and empowers through recognizing the strengths of introverts and how to capitalize on them in a largely extroverted society.

Although the United States is the most extroverted country in the world, one third to one half of people are introverts. Introverts are often quiet people, the ones who would rather stay in on a weekend than go out to a party, the ones that need to recharge with solitude after giving presentations. Introverts are often deep thinkings and intimate friends, although our society (incorrectly) views them as passive and anti-social. In Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World that Can't Stop Talking, Susan Cain explains how Western society misunderstands the quiet among us.I do not count myself as one of the quiet ones. Indeed, I'm one of the extroverts, and I'll go so far as to say that no one has ever called me quiet. I know I'm an extrovert, because I look forward to giving presentations (the bigger the audience, the better). I get antsy when I don't have a party to go to on Friday night, and I recharge after a long day of work by socializing. Plus, I'm going to spend a large portion of this review talking about myself. Cain's book makes me realize that I also possess some traits that are more characteristic of introverts. I spend a fair amount of time with my nose buried in a book, and I'm hopelessly bad at multitasking. I'm not a fan of group work (unless I can be completely in control of the group), and I would certainly consider myself an intellectual. As Cain points out, no one is completely an extrovert, nor is anyone completely an introvert. Extroverts, however, flourish in American society, while introverts are often forced to pretend to be extroverts.Particularly interesting is the chapter on raising introverted children. I don't have children, nor do I have plans to gestate a human being anytime soon, so I was surprised at how much I got from this section. After reading it, I realized how difficult school must have been for the shy ones, the ones that "never spoke up" in class. It's clear that I got undue praised for being bossy and talkative. Who knows how many kids my teachers ignored while I blabbed on endlessly about who knows what.Throughout the book, Cain argues that introverts should be cultivated, that their unique abilities (such as the deep focus that so often eludes me) should be valued. I agree, and I think she should take her argument one step further: extroverts should try to bring out their introverted sides. Maybe, instead of telling introverts to be louder, we should all try to become more quiet.

This book answered so many questions for me and has already helped me to become better at setting up my work environment to be more productive and satisfied with decisions I make. In my line of work, being forceful, making quick decisions and aggressive management are things that get you noticed and praised. I have learned to integrate some of these things into my work style, but it makes me feel very fake and unsettled. I don't encounter a lot of other people like me, likely because I don't take the time to socialize beyond the people I need to get work in my area done. This book has given me a lot of valuable tools for planning to further my career and how to work with people who are not like me and do not recognize my strengths or know how to capitalize on them. It also made me feel free to stop doing a lot of things I've contrived in my work personal to "fit in" which I have continued even though they have not lead to the desired effect. It helped me sort out that while I do care deeply about not hurting or offending others, I do not care if others "like" me or enjoy working with me. It also made sense of why I feel very empathetic when I see others experiencing strong emotions, but rarely feel strong emotions myself. The end of the book gave some very helpful insight into raising children who are introverts and it was very affirming to find that I have already been doing many of the suggestions the author has for helping introverted children become comfortable in school and other social settings while also encouraging them to be who they are. I listened to the audio book version of this publication, the narrator was excellent. Her tone and cadence really lent itself to the material and I'm glad I listened to this book rather than reading it. I highly recommend this book for those who are introverts, live with an introvert, or are raising an introvert. I especially enjoyed learning more about the research on "free traits" and how adaptable we can be when we are doing things we believe in. It was just an excellent, well-researched and well-thought-out book.

I picked this book up because I am both introvert and shy. I wanted to see what Cain had to say about introverts. I agree with Cain’s assertion that American culture idolizes extroverts, making them the idea to strive for. As a teacher, I find myself carefully waking a tightrope. I can deeply empathize with my introverted students but I am also expected to grade these students based on their participation and how much they speak out in class.I thought Kagan’s data regarding qualities of babies and predicting temperament to be quite interesting. I wasn’t aware of the scientific community moving away from nature versus nurture debate moving into one that values both equally.I agreed with the author’s assertion that an introvert‘s heightened sensitivity may enhance his or her capacity to experience empathy. I also agreed with her statement that Individuals who are threat sensitive tend to be more cautious about losses and punishments. I have known many extroverts that were so interested in chasing the next high that they weren’t even aware of the changing emotions of someone around them.I totally related to the far east’s ideal of putting community needs over those of the individual. I would be interested in learning more about soft power and reading about examples of a circumstance in which someone used a soft power approach in a negotiation.My main critique is that this book supplied an overabundance of statistics and data, in my opinion. I feel like this book could have been condensed and it wouldn’t have seemed like information overkill. I couldn’t quite figure out if Cain is anything besides a writer, such as a psychologist or the like. She collected so much empirical data that I was wondering if this also plays into her job. Overall, this was a good book and I’d highly recommend it for anyone wanting to get to know the introvert in the life better.

This is a book that ALL people should read! As an introvert, I spent much of my adolescence feeling unsure of myself. It took me quite a while to really grasp that I am an introvert, and more than that, to understand that there's absolutely nothing wrong with it. Once I learned and accepted my personality, I have found so much more peace and balance in my life. This book has further helped me understand the way that I am, and I think it could do remarkable things for extroverts - to help them understand the mind of introverts. All people could benefit from reading this. Introverts, extroverts, teachers, businessman, everybody really... I know I, for one, am tired of people telling me to go out more, be more social, hang out, get used to a lot of stimuli, whatever... And when I try to explain being an introvert, I feel like people who aren't introverts look at it as a disease that needs to be cured. If this personality type was more understood...oh, the possibilities!The 4-star rating comes predominantly from my expectations. I just expected something else. This book is so incredibly well-researched. The time and effort Susan Cain took to create this, brava! But it was much more scientific than I expected, and though I ultimately enjoyed the facts, I was just expecting a little more story-telling, so I was slightly disappointed when I didn't get it as much.

Source: GoodreadsInfo:Publication date: January 24th 2012Pages: 333 PaperbackGenre: nonfictionGrow (Personal growth label)Synopsis:Have you ever felt like people expect you to be more; outgoing, fun, jolly just because you declined a dinner invitation over a good book? Or that you didn’t get a job or a project because you tend to not socialize in the evenings with your fellow colleagues? Has anyone considered you cold, just because you prefer your solitude? Or have you had fear of public speaking so much that your voice trembles?I know I have, and this book explores exactly that. Introversion, extroversion and different types of both. It gives vivid explanations, examples, statistics, study cases. The book is in 4 parts, plus introduction and conclusion.Review: √√√√√ (5 stars)I can talk about this book from my own perspective since I see myself as an introvert. I gave it 5 stars and I labeled it with Grow (which means if you use the information in this book, it can help with your personal growth in some way.). The thing that I liked with this book is that it explores different kind of introverts and extroverts. From the calm extroverts, anxious extroverts, calm introverts and anxious introverts.More at: https://thebookhamster.wordpress.com/...

I picked up this book at the beginning of my journey to understand introverts. After all, I’m an extrovert. When I saw this book, I couldn’t resist. Call it what you want- morbid curiosity or whatever, but something compelled me to pick this up.Not gonna lie, I low key expected some extrovert bashing. After all, the subtitle is- “The power of introverts in a world that can’t stop talking.”- which seemed almost like a jest at extroverts. I don’t wanna be known as someone who can’t stop talking!!! But when I opened the book I didn’t find any extrovert bashing. I found a well written book that was just trying to speak for the introverted population. Loving yourself for your own personality and not trying to change and be like someone else. I would’ve appreciated this book more had it been written from a Christian perspective but it was still good.A few swear words and some secular philosophies that I wouldn’t agree with but for the most part, everything was on point and very enjoyable.- great read!Happy reading guys!

I am introvert, hear me curl up and read a book!This book is a great big "Fuck You!" to society and it's current worship of the outgoing, bubbly, fake, collaborating mindset. But the book isn't angry; it's a well-researched argument that delves into the last 100 years of psychology research to back up the arguements.The book discusses the difficulties that an introvert faces in study, the workplace and in relationships while giving ccase-studies and examples throughout. Susan doesn't recommend that all us introverts curl up in a ball in the dark, she encourages us to push our boundaries; all the while questioning where these boundaries are set.This book was affirming and even though I am proud of my personality, it gave me more confidence in who I am and that my behaviours are normal and should not be viewed negatively.

I know I'm late to this party, but I am a terrible foot-dragger when it comes to reading most nonfiction and the reserve list at the library has been insane. This book is well-researched, well-written, and insightful. I could relate to almost everything Cain had to say, and it made me feel infinitely more confident about the way I see the world and my role in it. Also - I don't put my day job out on Goodreads much but I work with an author who is related to Susan Cain and she drives us all a little nuts. I really couldn't stop thinking about her while reading this.

A very interesting book filled with so many moments of understanding from this introvert. I think this book is a wonderful resource for anyone to read, introvert or extrovert, as there are so many levels within these personality types and we are bound to find ourselves, or those we know, within the pages. As we live in a world of relating to others, it's a great guide to improving all sorts of interactions we have on a daily basis.

I don't think I've ever read a book that put me more in touch with who I am and why I am that way--and not only that, but why it is a *really good thing*. Growing up in a culture that places value on extroversion and openly mocks introversion leaves long-lasting marks, but having the validation from this book has been very healing and eye-opening for me.Thank you Susan Cain for your research and your incredible way of conveying it to the world.

Blah blah blah blah blah. Will this woman ever stop talking?It's not just talking that irritates introverts -- it's noise. Period. This is a lot of white noise tarted up to sound like a real drum roll. In other words, " ... all sound and fury, signifying nothing."That's all I have to say about that.
I need a magic button that will allow me to add a sixth star for this book.
Very interesting. Reassuring for introverts, enlightening for extroverts, I think. Definitely a book everyone should read.
This book changed my life. Not more and not less. It had a large influence on my self-acceptance. I always tried to be another person, the raven. But I'm an owl

It was a little bit too much self-help-book-ish for me, especially at the ending, but other than that, I really learned a lot about myself and about introversion in general. I would definitely recommend this!

When Susan Cain gets past trying to emphatically convince us that introverts have been maligned – when she gets to the actual intricate data about the different types of introverts and extroverts – this book is one of the most fascinating reads out there. The problem is that so much of this book is a treatise on the power introverts, or it’s a cheerleading book for introverts. I did love how the book described the world through and introvert’s eyes. It was an eye opener. I flipped through a magazine as I was in the middle of this book; every ad, every article was an attack on the senses, a colorful celebration of the extrovert or extroversion. Sexy men in cologne ads stared with open face; people partied on cruise ships; colors burst all over each page. Reality programs celebrate the outgoing, loud, and even obnoxious over the quiet, steady, and thoughtful person. It’s as if the introvert doesn’t have a say, a role model in our culture.I also love how this book outlined the difference in American culture – a culture of extrovert ideal – versus a more Eastern look at personality. Ever wonder why so many times, people from Eastern countries do better at math and science? It’s because their value in introversion respects patience and working alone. (I still think these sections went on longer than they needed to, but that seems to be a flaw with the book.)The other area I found fascinating is the section that discussed the qualities of introversion and extroversion in all of us, how we can pull on these ideas and practice them based on the role we are in at a given moment. Information on high self-monitoring (adjusting to social situations) versus low self-monitoring (not adjusting, staying to task) was fascinating. Cain outlines how introverts become good speakers and negotiators. She also mentions (in brief passing) how more extroverted people can practice more quiet, contemplative skills in listening and doing. And Cain knows that, even when we practice flexibility, we will wear out after a while and go to our area of comfort.I have to admit; I am not as much of an extrovert as people think I am. I fake it. I have found tricks for introducing myself to strangers at parties, but given my druthers, I’d rather stay around the neighborhood with people I know. Even though I sometimes act noisy and energetic, I actually often feel uncomfortable with super-showy, loudness (which is why many characters on reality television make me wince.) I don't like performers whose primary purpose is to pull focus and grandstand. I love performers who interact well. In some social situations, I worry about my graciousness level, because I often am thinking to myself, “I don’t care; I’d rather be at home with my latest book,” when someone is telling me something. I hate, hate, hate watching people get publicly embarrassed. If I am watching a live performance where someone has the chance of being humiliated, I start to stare at the curtain or the floor. On TV programs with this, I’ve often turned off the TV before it gets too bad. On the other hand, I also feel uncomfortable around people who haven’t kicked in their slightest social skill, the basics needed to help others start and keep up conversation.So this book has taught me that I’m more of an ambivert (probably, honestly, leaning toward extroversion). I do have moments of stir-crazy where I just need people. However, there are other moments – moments when I am in the flow and getting things done – when I would rather be left alone to finish a task, write on a play, and problem solve. I sometimes even need time alone just to daydream, vent, nap, and recharge. I like this. I feel for the introvert among us. And if I can be more sensitive and help with the socialization and comfort of them, I feel like I won’t miss out on a wonderful person, just because he or she may be a bit quieter and a bit more deliberate.

I tend to think there are many misconceptions around introverts; we live in a world that seems to praise extroverts. Susan Cain tries to help people understand the importance of introverts and why we need a balance between the two personality traits. Susan is an introvert herself and found her job as a lawyer expected an extroverted personality. However embracing her introversion, she was able to prove herself a valuable employer and lawyer; so much so that she went on to become a negotiations consultant.Quiet is a book that seeks out to explain the need for introverts, while also looking at the history between these two personality types. I myself am extremely introverted and my Myers–Briggs Type Indicator is INTJ (this can change over time but I will not go into that at the moment). I found it useful to understand the history in how society deals with introverts; some of which still feels very relevant today. I remember reading sections focusing on the 1950s and 60s, thinking this happened to me and is still happening in today’s society. This leaves me to think that people do not have an understanding on the personalities and how to manage introverts.Susan Cain goes into a lot of detail with suggestions on how to fit into such an extroverted world, from developing a pseudo-extroverted personality to finding a quiet place to work. Obviously it does depend on your different situations but I think there were some interesting ideas to implement. She also goes into the problems with open offices and productivity levels as well as the extroverted nature of church. I was surprised by just how much this book covered.I really enjoyed Quiet and feel like I learnt a lot, however it just makes me want to learn more, especially about the history (it is a vicious cycle). I want to give this book to my parents because I think they might actually benefit in learning about the topic. In fact I want to give this book to everyone, I feel like it is an important topic and we need to know that people are different and need to be treated differently. This is another book to fulfil my passion for learning about psychology and I would happily take some recommendations based on this book.This book originally appeared on my blog; http://www.knowledgelost.org/book-rev...

An interesting and timely investigation into introversion, and how introverts are undervalued and misunderstood in schools, the workplace, and Western society.One of the most interesting chapters is about how, after industrialisation, the USA quickly evolved into a culture that valued a hearty, sales type personality over more considered personality traits, and how this outgoing stereotype now dominates at the expense of people who are naturally quieter and more thoughtful.All of the book's more salient points also feature in Susan Cain's presentation on the TED Talks website however the book elaborates on the key points. In common with many similar books and writers (e.g Malcolm Gladwell), the main points can easily be summarised in a few pages however, in order to create a book, the central ideas have been filled out into c300 pages of science, research, social history, questionnaires, and anecdote, much of which adds little to the central message. I got impatient throughout the many sections which felt like padding and added little to the central thesis.Susan Cain's book contains some important, timely and provocative messages that are worth understanding. That said, it's not necessary to read the book to grasp the key points, which can be understood more quickly by watching this TED talk and/or reading the book's summary on Wikipedia.3/5

After watching Susan Cain’s TED talk, I wanted to read her book immediately. While the TED talk made me feel that she is talking about me and expressing my thoughts, the book induced some valuable self-realization and self-validation.I needed almost a month to complete it and still felt that I should have taken it up slower. I could not read more than a few pages at a time, because I had to constantly pause and reflect on what I read. Holding this book in my hand, I was either nodding my head in agreement or digging up past memories related to whatever I was reading. This is one of my favourite books because it made me accept my traits and encouraged me to face my fears.The book tends to glorify introverts and should be taken with a pinch of salt. I would still recommend it to everyone. Whether you are an introvert or an extrovert, if you ever wanted to understand people who are quiet, introverted or sensitive, this book is for you.Full review in my blog:https://anushanarasimhan.com/2015/10/...
I loved this book. Well researched. It helped me understand more things about myself. I'm an introvert and I'm also highly sensitive. I particularly liked the chapter on quiet children.

This was a terrific review of the research on introversion and extroversion. I especially appreciated the balanced and nuanced discussion of the strengths of both personality types. She has great tips on the best ways to make use of your relative strengths and interact with others. Also, she is convincing in explaining how everyone can learn and benefit from the best of both introversion and extroversion.A more detailed summary of my reaction to most of the chapters:The introduction immediately caught my attention. As cheesy as it was, I enjoyed the opening story of Laura the lawyer. In the first chapter, she did a good job of defining introvert and extrovert, explaining the complexities of these definitions, and differentiating introversion from shyness. I also appreciated the discussion of how economic forces and advertising led to the increasing emphasis on extroversion. In chapter 2, I thought the part about Tony Robbins was funny and interesting. I also like the research on successful business leaders and how they are often not extroverts. The research that suggests that it really depends on a good match between leader and employee personality and behavior makes total sense but was new to me. In both chapters, the "culture of character" versus "culture of personality" was interestingThe section on workplace structure and productivity was really interesting! The gist is that workplaces are most productive when employees have their own space to retreat to. Cubicles are not evil! It makes total sense to me that the most productive workplaces have a mix of open space for collaboration and smaller, personalized spaces for individual work. Cain did a great job discussing the research on how personally is due to both nature and nurture.
