One important point is how our personality in childhood guides us to environments that encourage certain behaviors. Reading alone in your room develops different skills than playing in large groups. In this section, the story of the extrovert who has learned from introverts in her life is a good example of the strength of the introvert personality. I wasn’t as interested in the part about public speaking. The information on optimal arousal level made so much sense to me. I have a very low threshold for sensory input. I hate roller coaster, scary movies, even too much noise. My poor family knows that they can’t talk to me for too long before I have to retreat. I was even fascinated by the concept of highly sensitive people. I have always been suspicious of the concept - it seemed too touchy-feely or an excuse for wimpy behavior- but the way she described it makes sense. I was interested to learn that they may be more detail-oriented, feel more guilt, and dislike violence.The sections on cultural differences in introversion and extroversion and how to best deal with personality differences in romantic relationships were also informative and engaging. The final section on raising introverted kids was really helpful. My daughter is 8 years old and I think she is pretty introverted. She is a SUPER friend, highly sensitive and generous, and super fun in small groups. She definitely prefers to have a few close friends. The tips in this chapter will definitely come in handy.

Like the hundreds of thousands of people who picked this up before me, I am an introvert. Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking speaks to those of us who prefer curling up with the good book in bed to the late-night parties, who prefer the one-on-one conversations over the group get-togethers. It's the validation and the relatability we've always wanted, and not surprising, either. And that makes me wonder, how many extroverts were and are motivated to pick this up? I'm curious as to how the content, geared towards introverts, would relate to an extrovert.There's something alluring about figuring out the many-faceted intricacies of personality, and we can derive a sense of comfort or "a ha! so relatable" moments when we place ourselves along Myers-Briggs spectrums or Enneagram types. Extroversion-introversion has always been one of the most fascinating, as I've grown up with both extremes for parents. Before I embraced my introversion, I grew up idolizing how well my mom could navigate and chatter her way through any social situation. (I swear, much to my disbelief, every National Book Festival, she'd become best friends with the person standing in front or behind us in line! How?!). That was so far from who I was, and it was so easy to fall deceptively in pursuit for the Extrovert Ideal. So it's a comfort when Susan Cain shows us how classrooms and corporate workplaces are structured heavily towards the group/open settings of extroverts but then highlights a number of introverts who have flourished in their careers and adult lives. Cain expertly wields her previous background as a corporate lawyer and journalistic sense to communicate numerous psychology studies. I found that some sections of the book felt too heavy on the speculation without being backed by a compelling research finding; in many cases, extroverts felt unnecessarily demonized in order to add extra luster to qualities of introverts. This was a solid, quick read, though I wouldn't call it essential reading. Much of what is touted in this book is familiar, especially if anyone has any layman's background on psychology. More than 8 years after this book was published, I think we've made heartening strides in shining light on the "soft" power that these quiet and reserved people have in spades, and we can look back to Susan Cain as having had an important role in striking up a public and modern conversation about it. And to everyone thereafter that has spoken up, I say: thanks, fellow introverts! :) I love you guys <3

This is an amazing book for both the soft-spoken introverts who live in a noisy world that won't hear them, as well as for the extroverts who share work or home space with them. This is also a great book for ambiverts, sociologists and behavioral psychologists who may profit from the research findings and speculations revealed in this book.My favorite types of works are not only those to which I can relate, but also those that challenge the tyranny of the majority. Susan Cain does just that by questioning what she calls the "Extrovert Ideal." She states that we live in a society that values gregariousness over reflectiveness and verbosity over creative insight. It was refreshing when I came across Susan's blog for the first time and read in the Introvert Manifesto statements such as follows:1. There’s a word for “people who are in their heads too much”: thinkers.9. Everyone shines, given the right lighting. For some, it’s a Broadway spotlight, for others, a lamplit desk.15. Love is essential, gregariousness is optional.In a world in which almost every product, literary or otherwise, is aimed at convincing you to be something you are not, I was instantly mesmerized by the promise of this book to teach introverts to use their natural gifts to the fullest. The author talks about "soft power," which is the type of power that people like Mahatma Ghandi, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Rosa Parks used to achieve their ends. In fact, Cain devotes quite a large portion devoted to the latter two activists. She also mentions how Moses from the Old Testament was actually "dreadfully timid," by today's standards, yet Yahweh chose him to carry on the holy operation of the story. Even though we are referring to fiction, it is wise to remember that the hero of every story ever written is invented to fit the image of the author's ideal. It is interesting to note that in older times in a different culture, quiet leadership was valued over the rambling of the typical American extrovert.It is quite dreadful that we live in a society that requires people to act like overcaffeinated, hyperpseudoconfident chatterboxes in order to be taken seriously. Susan Cain states, "It's so easy to confuse schmoozing ability with talent. Someone seems like a good presenter, easy to get along with, and those traits are rewarded." Even one of the entrepreneurs Cain interviewed expressed worry that "there are people who are put in positions of authority because they're good talkers, not because they have good ideas" (52). Apparently our culture is still in that sophomoric stage of humanity in which people are easily swayed by appearance. Just as I frequently express in my blogs, we value not the best ideas, but those who have the best sweet-talking and acting skills."So may the outward shows be least themselvesThe world is still deceived in ornamentIn law, what plea so tainted and corruptBut being seasoned with a gracious voiceObscures the show evil?"Merchant of Venice, 3.2.73-77, William ShakespeareIn the business arena, people tend to act rashly and exude confidence, because showing the slightest doubt in their prospects would lead investors to abstain from investing in their companies. The world truly does not work on substance or merit, but on the appearance of these traits. Quiet challenges these cultural norms by suggesting that the extrovert majority pay more attention to the introverts, who may "seem stark mute but inwardly do prate" (Queen Elizabeth, "On Monsieur's Departure"). It is interesting to observe that in a business world dominated by histrionic and aggressive extroverts who act before they think, so many companies have failed.I love chapter three because it challenges the mainstream and blind reverence for "teamwork." Cain observes that we tend to organize our most important institutions in highly detrimental ways: "It is the story of a contemporary phenomenon that I call the New Groupthink-- a phenomenon that has the potential to stifle productivity at work," because the best ideas are diluted with the majority consensus. The author suggests that in the most ideal situations extroverts and introverts would contribute their individual best for common good-- the former in public domains and the latter in the theoretical and aesthetic, which are fields that are repeatedly shown to be the best for introverts. Another aspect that I love about Quiet are the frequent references to literary classics. One can tell Susan Cain is well-versed in the classics, which is not surprising considering her impressive education from Princeton University and Harvard Law School. I love how she characterizes the evolution from "Culture of Character" to "Culture of Personality" by referring to the timeless works of the respective age: "While poets of the previous century had wandered lonely as a cloud through the countryside (Wordsworth, in 1802) or repaired in solitude to Walden Pond (Thoreau, in 1845), Eliot's Prufrock mostly worries about being looked at by eyes that fix you in a formulated phrase' and pin you wriggling, to a wall" (31). These three works are in my list of favorites, and I feel the melancholy of her observation and the resignation to the reality that the majority has created.I also really enjoyed the chapters that delve into the physiological differences between extroverts and introverts (mostly Part Two). I learned some interesting things about how the more reactive one's amygdala, the less likely one is to seek the new situations, risks and meetings on which extroverts thrive. However, high-reactive introverts tend to be "more likely to develop into artists and writers and scientists and thinkers because their aversion to novelty causes them to spend time inside the familiar-- and intellectually fertile-- environment of their own heads" (110). Of course, there is also free will and the book does advise that sometimes it is good to pretend to be an extrovert for the sake of achieving one's goals in the world as it is. One can actually pretend to do as the Romans do, but only so much and not without a "restorative niche" (214), because introverts are often more prone to burnouts because we are more sensitive to the burdens of duplicity. I cannot possibly reveal more about the book without spoiling it, so please make sure to get your copy! You will not regret it, regardless of your personality type. It is an insightful read filled with relevant research findings, brilliant commentary, and peppered with entertaining side remarks that will make you chuckle while you learn.

I really loved this book! I am a person that can proudly say: I am both, introvert and extrovert. Most of my friends would describe me as outgoing and someone who wants to experience as much as possible. Also in normal times I am more on the road to meet friends and experience life. But I am also someone who loves deep talks and thinks before I speak (up). So I was so glad to feel myself perfectly described in several chapters of the book and I also loved learning about different cultures as well. I, as a scientist, love books with scientific references about experimental studies. So this book was the perfect mixture between scientific proof and "just" experience the author makes in several meetings. So I can totally recommend it. :)

So many times while reading this- as I imagine countless others too- I just thought, yup, that's me! I literally wrote that several times in the margins XDThoroughly researched (this books boasts 250+ references at the end!!!), this managed to still be engaging because she does a great job of looking at various aspects of introversion and the introversion-extroversion spectrum. And it was approached with such understanding. I especially liked reading about introverts in the workplace. I was really interested to read both the science and experiments/studies, and the theories underlying it all, along with the history of how we got to the current state of interaction today (particularly in the US). Though I should note, since it started out after the introduction with that historical context, it can read kind of dense right at the beginning. But in the end I didn't mind much because, again, it was interesting.Susan Cain has a business/financial background and, thus, many examples (more than I expected) and case studies reflected that. At times I thought there were perhaps too many examples or past researcher's work she was discussing, but I go back and forth because that is also what makes it so thorough. I do think extroverts kind of got the short end of the stick in this sometimes- LOL. It wasn't that she talked negatively about them, and she points out how everyone has their own power in wherever they lie on the spectrum, but I thought some of the descriptions of extroverts had slightly negative connotations.All in all, I would recommend this to anyone wanting (well researched) insight on introverts- which is to say- anyone who knows anyone because you more than likely interact with introverts daily or are one. :)

I always knew I was an introvert, so no surprise there, but I am not shy, not even a little bit. But I am quiet, in the sense of, if I have nothing to add then I don't talk, why would I when I don't have anything to say, that hasn't already been said, or is already known.This is a very well researched book, and it should be enlightening to both introverts and extroverts, and helpful in the workplace and with family and friends. I could see specific examples that exists in me and my husband, him being the extrovert. This book helps me to understand the extrovert. It also helps me to understand myself better and explains why I do what I do. Therefore this is a great book for people period if they want to understand others.Living in an extroverted world can be exhausting sometimes. Why is everyone always talking, about nothing, it seems sometimes they are yelling, "look at me," and it is very tiring. I have always thought that all this talking is about people needing to be heard, needing their self esteem to be validated by the listener, but now I guess this is just part of being an extrovert. Although not all by any means speak so very much about nothing.This book is broken down into four sections. Part One is "the extrovert ideal," and how much businesses place on one being an extrovert, this explains my inability to find employment. Just kidding. It also speaks about how too much collaboration hampers creativity, because everyone is so busy sharing ideas that no one does much of anything. Part Two is about the biology behind both introverts and extroverts, and nature vs nurture. The author gives great examples about a variety of people in business and how their personalities fit into this world. Part Three is about our different cultures, specifically Asians vs Americans. I think I like Asians, although I have never actually known one. Part Four is the differences of introverts and extroverts and how we can love each other and raise children that are different from ourselves. I think all teachers and parents should at least read part four for invaluable insight. This book could be used to teach teachers how to treat children as individuals rather than extroverts.At the back of the book are notes. I know I will refer back to these notes to read parts of this book again and again."The secret to life is to put yourself in the right lighting. For some it's a Broadway spotlight; for others, a lamplit desk. Use your natural powers--of persistence, concentration, insight, and sensitivity--to do work you love and work that matters. Solve problems, make art, think deeply." (pg 264) I love that paragraph, and it speaks to both introverts and extroverts, personally I love the lamplit desk.Someone commented that most of us are not all introvert or all extrovert, but rather a mix of both, yes with some of us more one than the other, but not necessarily the extreme of either, and I must say this is true for me.Quiet, yes I require quiet time, more than most, a time to re-charge myself so I can go back into the world again. I have been trying to figure out what to do with the rest of my life, work wise I mean, and I just can't figure it out. What do I like to do? I like to read, and absorb new information, a new way of thinking, I like learning just about anything, but most of all I like to figure out why people do what they do and why they are like they are, and I think reading helps me to do just that, but now the real question is how to find a profession that allows me to do that. Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.

I had very high expectations beginning to read “Quiet. The Power of Introverts in a World That Can’t Stop Talking” by Susan Cain, but ended up being very disappointed. The subtitle alone should ring alarm bells. Cain is a typically US-centric author who sees the whole world from her own perspective and does not seem to acknowledge a multitude of points of view or cultural diversity. Her assumption, which she tries to present as ‘the Truth’ throughout the book, is that the whole world favours extroverts. The whole world except Asia, or rather Chinese-Americans, whom she presents as sole representatives of the entire Asian continent and all Asian cultures. The book is clearly written for Americans and presents plenty of case studies from her own playground, which are not very applicable to other cultures, often focusing on other values. There is not a word about European cultures (even though many times Cain presents The US under the umbrella term ‘the West’, which is very misleading, as European - Western - cultures are very diverse, much more than she is aware of), African or South American ones. Readers get the impression that the whole world functions according to American standards and that is a gross misconception.From an author as highly acclaimed and praised as Cain I would except a much better research and balance of presented cases. Cain devotes ten pages to some workshops for extroverts, one page to a story of an introvert musician, three pages to her observations of a discussion among school students - both extro- and introverts, and many pages to various stories of extroverted and introverted business people, usually from the financial sector. There is little coherence, there is not enough analysis, and way too much focus on the corporate environment. Often I had an impression that I was reading a pseudo-intellectual business self-help book (heightened by cringeworthy chapters’ titles), the genre I never ever lay my hands on. If she uses a case study of a person in the limelight it is always a businessman giving presentations or sales pitches, never an actor, singer or a person working in a non-profit sector. The choice of people whose stories Cain decided to present is very poor and narrow, and the stories themselves sound often very repetitive. What put me off was also a lot of emphasis on success and making money, which, as Cain was trying to show, introverts can achieve too. I consider myself an introvert, who enjoys spending plenty of time on her own, loves talking on profound, complex topics, hates big parties, shallow small talk and people talking loudly, who doesn’t care about fame, wealth and status, who favours harmony over conflict, who is perceptive and inquisitive, serious and quiet rather than jovial and gregarious, who is sensitive and emotional with a tendency to melancholy and nostalgia, who has a big heart and a strong conscience. And who is confident, has rather high self esteem and who doesn’t seek others’ attention or approval to live how she wants. I grew up in an environment which favoured introverts and from a young age I was able to thrive academically and socially as myself. I never thought there must be something wrong with me and I always sought company of people who shared the same values and interests - there were many around me. I read “Quiet”, wanting to learn more about making better use of my introversion, but the narrow scope of Cain’s research and the monotonous style of the book left me uninspired and bored. The topic has so much potential and Cain wasted it completely.

3 stars - It was good.The Myer Briggs personality test pegs me consistently as an INTJ. As a female INTJ, I am part of the most rare, MB personality type gender grouping, making up less than 1% of the population. I don't say that to proclaim being "special", though I do have one super power... I say that to point out that I knew long, long, long ago at a very young age that I was a bit different from the other little boys and girls. While that made high school and its pseudo-forced conformity more interesting, somewhere along my mid-20s I just accepted that I would be happiest much of the time on a different path from most, and that was ok. Life has been better since. Most of this book I found to be slow and dry, even though the subject matter is interesting to me. The problem was that there was very little new or unknown information presented, as I was already aware of most of the points. There is a strong, repeating theme of "these are the things that make introverts so freaking awesome" throughout this book, and while there is clear warning of such in the book title, I would think that this book would be a painful read for extroverts. It's even painfully slow at times for introverts (unless you know next to nothing about basic personality groups).In contrast to the rest of the book, her conclusion chapter, while succinct, was beautifully written with excellent life wisdom for introverts in particular, but for everyone in general. While again, I have already figured much of this out (most of it the hard way), it could be life changing advice for those still trying to squeeze themselves into a mold for which they do not fit. I specifically love that she points out that if you don't want to go out to a crowded, smoky place full of drunk people that don't understand, let alone respect personal space on New Year's Eve, then don't. That may seem obvious to most of us, but I didn't have it figured out yet in my early 20's. It would have been a nice thing to know. If you are thinking of bailing on the book, definitely read her conclusion and sweet dedication note regarding her grandfather before putting the book down. In my humble opinion, she saved the best for last.P.s. From 3rd grade on, I have absolutely despised "group work", both in school settings, and with career/workplace settings. I hate all versions of this dreaded, mandatory, counter-productive activity. Now I completely understand why. (Why I hate it, that is. I still don't understand the purpose. No one understands the purpose of group work. No one.)P.s.s. My super power is an abnormal, seriously ridiculous, keen sense of smell. And yes, I do know that is incredibly lame. As Susan Cain points out, we don't get to choose which special magic powers we are granted -- we just make the most of them.----------------------------------------------------------------------Favorite Quote: Introverts are offered keys to private gardens full of riches. To possess such a key is to tumble like Alice down her rabbit hole. First Sentence: I have been working on this book officially since 2005, and unofficially for my entire adult life.

Confession time: I’m an introvert. I like spending time alone, reading and listening to music. I enjoy going out and seeing my friends, but I’m often relieved to come home to a quiet house where I can unwind on my own. I love thinking critically, but I’m rarely the first person to leap into the discussion. And in a culture that seems to value extroversion over nearly every other trait, I’ve always been made to feel slightly insecure about these things. Susan Cain’s book Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can’t Stop Talking helped me change my outlook.Quiet presents an idea that Western society so often seems to contradict: that being introverted isn’t a bad thing; our brains just work differently than extroverts’ do. As extroverts have their own strengths, we have our own, and the world needs a balance of both types of people to function well. It needs the people who can go out and charm the pants off of clients, and it also needs people who are thoughtful and perceptive.This book was really enlightening for me. It was so validating! I’ve always thought that my dislike of small talk, need to unwind in solitude, and the intense guilt I feel whenever I do something wrong are unusual and problematic. Quiet, however, taught me that these are simply common traits of introverts and that there’s nothing inherently wrong with these things. Roughly one third to one half of people are introverts! It’s not just me! Plenty of people feel like I do, and that makes me feel so much more comfortable with myself.This book also helped me realize what strengths I have, as an introvert: I think carefully before I speak; the quality of my communication is more important to me than the quantity. I am a creative thinker. (Did you know that most really creative people are introverts? They need quiet and solitude to think without interruption.) I process information deeply and will listen carefully to all points of view. I think before I act, I can stay on task for long periods of time without giving up, and I work accurately. The list goes on!Quiet is really well researched, and Cain includes many interesting studies that illustrate her points. It’s a very readable book, and nearly every page held some fascinating new piece of information that I just wanted to tell everyone — hey, did you know?I highly recommend this book. If you’re an introvert, Quiet will teach you a lot about yourself, and if you’re an extrovert, it will help you relate to your introverted friends, family members, and co-workers — because whether you know it or not, you have some. For employers, Quiet offers strategies for utilizing introverted employees by recognizing their needs and making the most of their strengths. For parents, this book provides advice on raising quiet children in a noisy world.More book reviews at Books Speak Volumes.

I found this book to be incredibly biased and dull, and I'm surprised that it is so highly rated with such great reviews. For someone who has studied and is well versed in the widely accepted Jung theories of introversion and extroversion, I found the author's take on introverted and extroverted qualities to be incredibly generalized.The author made statement such as "extroverts, in other words, are characterized by their tendency to seek rewards, from top dog status to sexual highs to cold cash" and "this theory of extroversion is still young, and it is not absolute... it suggests that when it comes time to make group decisions, extroverts would do well to listen to introverts, especially when they see problems ahead." I personally have known impulsive, pleasure-seeking introverts and thoughtful, problem-solving extroverts. These bold and generalized statements do nothing to help people understand each other's preferences or work more effectively together, rather they imply that one type is better than the other and encourage an "us versus them" mentality. The author went back and forth between detailed dull scientific concepts, practical situational examples, and then over-generalized statements summarizing the two. The book definitely felt a bit self-serving, as the author makes it clear that she considers herself an introvert who has struggled in an "extroverted world". I'm not saying that the author didn't make any good points or that there wasn't any truth to some of the concepts she put forward, but to be honest, the continued bias throughout the book made the author lose some credibility with me. There are so many great books out there about personality and introversion/extroversion that are balanced and put forth tips and suggestions for interacting with people who are different from us, that it's disappointing to see this book getting so much attention.

Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking is a book about a half of the worlds population that have found there quiet and thoughtful persona is becoming more and more unacceptable. These people are not the life of the party types or the first ones to speak up in groups of people and prefer in general deep meaningful conversations and quiet time alone. Like myself Introverts have are own personality traits that in this modern world are not as desirable as they once were with gregarious characters being seen as being likely to succeed in life despite no evidence to suggest that the best speakers are the smartest people.Susan Cain who herself a self confessed introvert tries to explain why the world has gone away from admiring softly spoken thinkers in the past and why and how things can be changed to create an even balance between Introverts and Extroverts in our society. Through interviews with psycholgists and other professional in universities and the corporate world she gives us the readers an understanding of introversion and how even some people who may seem a complete extrovert may not be the case and infact have learnt to overcome there fears to be more outgoing. She also mentions a number of famous introverts who although softly spoken changed the world with there conviction including Ghandi, Abraham Lincoln and Dr Seuss.For me this book is a celebration of all things introvert and gives a great insight into the gift that half the people in the world have. The author has has exstensivly researched and at times the chapters can seem abit overwhelming with so much information about various experiments. Despite this the book is deeply intriguing and is a potentially life altering examination of the human psyche and will be a great benifit to introverts and extroverts.

It's more about how you respond to stimulation and where you get your inspiration from. I am a teacher, and I'm already thinking of ways I can use these ideas in class, as I definitely have a number of students who clearly find group work and public speaking stressful. Not that it isn't important to work on overcoming those fears, but different personalities have different learning styles and it's important to acknowledge and nurture those differences.

I recently watched a TED Talk given by the author on the power of introverts (you can see it here) and it inspired me to read her book. I'd put it on my to-read shelf a few years ago, but I was really intrigued by her talk and wanted to know more. This book takes an honest and open look at the valuable contributions of introverts, who comprise one third to one half of all Americans. It targets schools and other organizations who attempt to force all people into an extrovert mold and shows how this can really be emotionally and psychologically damaging. And it shows how breakthroughs, whether in science, philosophy, art or literature often stem from quiet solitude and study, somehing that is not embraced in society today. We need people who excel in quiet surroundings, who are able to explore the boundaries of creativity and discovery without the noise and distraction of the rest of the world. Just as we need the outgoing personalities and gregarious people who blossom in a crowd. We need the quiet strength of people like Rosa Parks, just as we need the booming oratory and magnetic personality of people like Dr.Martin Luther King Jr..I have always thought of myself as being adventurous, outgoing and extroverted, and most of my younger years epitomized this. More than once, even now, I have been chatised for speaking too much and with too much volume, leading me to declare, "I live life loudly." I enjoy being part of a group or team very much, be it in sports, work or even as part of a club.But the older I get, the more I realize just how much I treasure my solitude, too. This book really revealed to me that I have many introverted traits myself. I am very happy to be quiet and by myself, even in the midst of a crowd. And I would so much rather be at home with my family with a good book than at a loud party. I think that part of this stems from my upbringing as an only child. I was alone often in my childhood and I grew to be quite comfortable and contemplative in that solitude. In fact, as I took the quiz on pp. 13-14, I realize that I may be an ambivert, but the majority of my answers lie solidly on the introverted spectrum. I suppose that my outgoing nature derived from wanting to be part of a group, that I already had enough alone time and wanted to have at least a part of my world fit in somewhere. But I think, also, that I just have a need for balance. Perhaps it was a bit of insecurity that drove me to try to fit in, so as I mature and grow more comfortable in my own skin, I feel less of a need to fit in just for the sake of fitting in. Either that, or I'm just becoming a bit of a curmudgeon.But enough about me. The really great thing about this book is that it does make you think, about the world, about yourself, and about what kinds of lessons we are passing down to our children. interesting quotes:"Now that you're an adult, you might still feel a pang of guilt when you decline a dinner invitation in favor of a good book. Or maybe you like to eat alone and could do without the pitying looks from fellow diners. Or you're told that you're 'in your head too much,' a phrase that often deployed against the quiet and cerebral. Of course, there's another word for such people: thinkers." (p. 7)"Open-plan offices have been found to reduce productivity and impair memory. They're associated with high staff turnover. They make people sick, hostile, unmotivated, and insecure. Open-plan workers are more likely to suffer from high blood pressure and elevated stress levels and to get the flu; they argue more with their colleagues; they worry about coworkers eavesdropping on their phone calls and spying on their computer screens. They have fewer personal and confidential conversations with colleagues. They're often subject to loud and uncontrollable noise, which raises heart rates; realeases cortisol, the body's fight-or-flight 'stress' hormone; and makes people socially distant, quick to anger, aggressive, and slow to help others." (p. 84) "We all have old brains, of course. But just as the amygdala of a high-reactive person is more sensitive than average to novelty, so do extroverts seem to be more susceptible than introverts to the reward-seeking cravings of the old brain. In fact, some scientists are starting to explore the idea that reward-sensitivity is not only an interesting feature of extroversion; it is what makes an extovert an extrovert. Extroverts, in other words, are characterized by their tendency to seek rewards, from top dog status to sexual highs to cold cash. They've been found to have greater economic, political, and hedonistic ambitions than introverts; even their sociability is a function of reward-sensitivity, according to this view - extroverts socialize because human connection is inherently gratifying." (p. 159)"Anyone can be a great negotiator, I told them, and in fact it often pays to be quiet and gracious, to listen more than talk, and to have an instinct for harmony rather than conflict. With this style, you can take aggressive positions without inflaming your counterpart's ego. And by listening, you can learn what's truly motivating the person you're negotiating with and come up with creative solutions that satisfy both parties." (p. 216)"Having spent so much time navigating my own career transition and counseling others through theirs, I have found that there are three key steps to identifying your own core personal projects.First, think back to what you loved to do when you were a child....Second, pay attention to the work you gravitate to....Finally, pay attention to what you envy." (p. 218)"Scores of studies have shown that venting doesn't soothe anger; it fuels it.We're best off when we don't allow ourselves to go to our angry place." (p. 233)"Your child needs to acquire social skills and make friends, not turn into the most gregarious student at school. This doesn't mean that popularity isn't a lot of fun. You'll probably wish it for him, just as you might wish that he have good looks, a quick wit, or athletic talent. But make sure you're not imposing your own longings, and remember that there are many paths to a satisfying life." (p. 259)"Love is essential; gregariousness is optional. Cherish your nearest and dearest. Work with colleagues you like and respect. Scan new acquantances for those who might fall into the former catergories or whose company you enjoy for its own sake. And don't worry about socializing with everyone else. Relationships make everyone happier, introverts included, but think quality over quantity." (p. 264)

At first I really loved this book; in nearly 40 years of living, reading it was the first time I'd received permission from anyone to be quiet in a group setting, to not participate in class if I didn't have something important to say.But the longer I read, the more I started to feel a subtle shift in my reactions. I'd gone from feeling recognized and appreciated to feeling pushed to the side and victimized.Hear me out:I believe there is a very, very thin line between empowerment and victimization. If you take a group of people, define them as unique, and then spend many pages exploring, through case studies and scientific research, how they are different emotionally, why they are different biologically, and why this is OK, the cheerleading can start to feel like overcompensation -- maybe for the author's deep down belief that the people she's championing really *do* need championing, because they aren't normal.Something about that feels dangerous to me. Cain spends a lot of time proving that introverts are all around us and that there are probably evolutionary reasons why we exist. But any time a writer goes out of her way to define a group, label it, and declare it biologically and fundamentally different from the majority culture, I get nervous. It's as if, in some bizarre trick of logic, setting out to prove that introverts are normal actually does the opposite. I mean no disrespect to the author. I am giving this four stars because it's well written and enjoyable and I do think she's doing a lot more good than harm. But as an introvert, the preponderance of scientific data about the brain and genetics started to make me feel like a research specimen, and apparently I'm not cool with that. I'd be curious to know if other introverts felt this way while reading this book. Maybe I'm a stubborn case; I like being appreciated for who I am, but I don't want other people to feel like they need to read a special book to learn how to deal with me. I'm not that fragile or unique.From a writing standpoint, here's what I liked or didn't like.Likes:- When Cain referred to her own experiences and her client consultations- The opening chapter on the evolution of our extrovert culture (great chapter, really fascinating; the first meta analysis I've seen of America's self-help culture)- The implication that we are an anxiety drug-taking nation because this culture is going against our grain (if 1/3 to 1/2 of us are introverts trying to be extroverts, it's no wonder so many of us are taking meds)- The chapter on Asians and Asian Americans because of the outside cultural perspective (though I think it's subject to some overgeneralization, and it might have been nice to hear from a second outside culture)- The bits about teachers learning to teach introverts differently (Oh how I wish this book had existed when I'd been a kid; it would have saved me so many low class participation grades and annoying chidings from well-intentioned teachers who thought my reticence was a sin.)- The case study about the married couple who must learn to compromise (the solution to their problem turned out to be one of the few actionable takeaway items in the book -- how to compromise with an overly sociable spouse)Dislikes:- Much of the science felt like pseudo-science; though having worked on a research-heavy book in a soft science myself, I understand the challenges of finding the right studies.- There were too many studies; after a while, I found myself thinking, "She just stated a personal opinion. Here comes the research study to support it." Again, this is not really the author's fault; there are only so many ways to present research and weave it into your narrative. But as a reader and a writer/editor (and an introvert), I have a tendency to pick up on patterns, and when they become very consistent, they start to feel predictable in a way that makes me feel smarter than the text. (I know; so arrogant. Sorry. I am the most exacting reader ever because I read for information and for style and structure.)- The general tone of "introverts matter too." While I completely agree that we introverts have something to offer, and that we should be encouraged to work in the way that allows us to make our best contributions to the world, I just feel like hearing that message again and again makes me feel like someone who needs special concessions. Like my temperament is a handicap. Since she'd already proved to the reader that it's our culture that's skewed, and not our introverts, I think I may have been happier with a little more proactive tone. (E.g., "How introverts can adapt to today's extrovert business climate.") Then again, maybe this book was not written for me. The more I think about it, the more I believe it was written for the culture at large -- so extroverts can understand introverts' strengths and styles.- The ending. Cain had proven at the start of her book that our culture is skewed in one direction. I think it would have been nice to end the book with the optimistic hope that it may, as is the nature of trends, either swing the other way, from extroversion to introversion, or balance out. Something about economics, the future of our country, the changing face of business with telecommuting and the nerd/tech industry, how to deal with other nations, etc. might have added a big picture cultural relevance to the last few pages of the book. After all, she did devote sections to the extrovert role in economic collapse. I feel like that thread got dropped. Rather than it being a standalone chapter, I'd have liked to have see that idea carried all the way through.Overall, I feel this book is 90% pop psychology culture book (like a Malcolm Gladwell book) and 10% self-help. I think that 10% confused me and left me wanting more, because I am an introvert, and concrete advice on how to proactively deal with extroverts is something I would like to see. Ms. Cain -- please write a follow-up and teach us polite ways to excuse ourselves from dinner tables and parties.

[I wrote this review in 2014 but had just found the text file in my flash drive. Since I cannot remember much about the book now in 2020, my editing effort is minimal.]QUOTES"Society is itself an education in the extrovert values." – William Whyte"I am a horse for a single harness, not cut out for tandem or teamwork... for well I know that in order to attain any definite goal, it is imperative that one person do the thinking and the commanding." – Albert Einstein"Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act." – Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi"The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances; if there is any reaction, both are transformed." – Carl Jung"With anything young and tender the most important part of the task is the beginning of it; for that is the time at which the character is being formed and the desired impression more readily taken." – PlatoSUMMARY(view spoiler)[INTRODUCTIONRosa Parks called her autobiography "Quiet Strength."One third to one half of Americans are introverts.PART ONE: THE EXTROVERT IDEALBeing extrovert is the cultural ideal, making introverts afraid of being who they are and pretending to be extroverts to fit in. There exist introverted charismatic leaders as well as extroverted ones.Even though schools try to teach us to New Groupthink, somehow collaboration kills creativity, and it might be better to work alone. William Wordsworth described Newton as "A mind forever / Voyaging through strange seas of Thought alone." Also, the best violinists tend to spend much more time practising alone than others.PART TWO: YOUR BIOLOGY, YOUR SELF?Infants born with an especially excitable amygdala have more reactions towards unfamiliar object, and are likely to grow up to become introverts. They are "high-reactive." For children who are more high-reactive tend to feel a lot more guilty about their transgressions than others.Not only in humans but in animals do these traits exist. Shy ones are more careful about being hunted while bold ones are better at defending territories.PART THREE: DO ALL CULTURES HAVE AN EXTROVERT IDEAL?Asians are more introvert-oriented. Their culture teaches them that being "humble," "altruistic," "honest," and "hard-working" is preferred.In an experiment of testing the persistence of children, researchers found that it took Japanese children much more time to give up than American ones.PART FOUR: HOW TO LOVE, HOW TO WORKProfessor Brian Little knew that he needed to recharge after giving speeches. Actually, he needed it so bad that he went and hid in the men's room if he could not find other escape hatches. [Note in 2020: I also do this.]Some findings show that introverts like people they meet in friendly contexts and respond better to robots that speak in a gentle manner; extroverts prefer those they compete with and work harder for robots that used more aggressive language. (hide spoiler)]THOUGHTSWhile reading this book, I took time to reflect on my own characteristics. When I read the parts that introverts need less stimulations than extroverts and tend to require "taking a break" after extensive socializing or participating in extrovert-dominating events, I realized that it is how I deal with stress and daily life as well.And that I prefer working alone. Working in a group demands energy for socializing and thus makes the process of it much more tiring than otherwise.On the contrary to being an introvert though, I am not afraid of and may even enjoy giving presentations in front of a big audience as long as I am notified well beforehand. Sometimes, last-minute changes in my schedule just freak me out.Even though the book states that Asian cultures emphasize more on introvert traits than Western cultures, I still think that in families, schools, and the society, people tend to think higher of those who are more extroverted. Also, we were taught not to be shy and should interact with others more often. Even if trying to be gregarious actually makes me feel uncomfortable and stressed out, sometimes I still coerce myself to socialize more.As a study mentioned in the book, a second grader, Isabel, said that "School is hard because a lot of people are in the room, [...] I like having thoughtful conversations because they make people happy." I find this very true indeed. When I was in elementary school, I always dread the start of semesters when all the students were rearranged into new classes. I hated to have to try to make new friends and often waited for others to do so.In high school, I finally understood how wonderful having thoughtful conversations can be. Sometimes, I need those deep talks to keep me sane in this overwhelming and over-stimulated world. And having retreats is just as relaxing and mood-lifting.Somehow, I think this book has changed some of my perspectives on life and now I continue to observe everything around and within me, trying to make sense of it all. Or maybe I am not really trying to understand, but rather purely enjoying the process of onlooking.

I had always felt embarrassed about my quietness and questioned my need for alone time. I’m the one who speaks rarely in staff meetings, and I’m the one who’d much rather eat lunch in my classroom than in the staff lounge. This book made so much sense to me because I am that introvert who always just seemed different from most other popular/sociable/confident/outgoing people out there. While I felt discomfort from the low-key part of me wanting to hide from excitement, I also knew there were parts of me that I felt good about, though it was hard for me to reconcile the two contradicting aspects. This book addressed all of this and taught me even more. Cain, through extensive research and years of writing, explains the science, social, and practical aspects of introversion, extroversion, and how to navigate our temperaments/personalities with one another. While one of out every two or three people are introverts, this culture is largely made for the success of extroverts. From the Harvard Business School model to corporate offices to even school practices, the Extrovert Ideal seems to be the exemplary performance standard. But Cain carefully details the strengths of introverts who, despite being quieter, reflect more deeply, communicate with more substance, and achieve higher level of thinking than seemingly/wildly successful extroverts. She explains why introverts work more deliberately and with more concentration, listen more than talk, are better writers than talkers, and need solitude to recharge. Cain discusses the biological differences between introverts and extroverts, documents longitudinal behavioral studies by scientists, as well as gives sound advice to help both groups of people. She shows how introverts can stretch to act more extroverted with purpose and practice. Cain even has an entire section on Asians and Asian Americans and how culture significantly affects personality styles, which I could completely relate to. Finally, she helps us guide our young children and students so that we can nurture their introversion to help them feel heard and propel them to succeed. I also very much enjoyed Cain’s TED Talk on this topic. I know she succeeded in her goal of writing this book with me: I now have a “newfound sense of entitlement” to be my introverted self. In fact, now I know that this is the part of me that I have always felt good about, or even proud of. I’ve had my daughter read Quiet Power, Cain’s book for young readers and students, and hopefully my son will read it, too, as we are a family of quiet introverts. Highly recommend this read for both introverts and extroverts alike!

"Our culture made a virtue of living only as extroverts. We discouraged the inner journey, the quest for a center. So we lost our center and have to find it again." - Anaïs Nin As an introvert, I have been curious about reading this book since 2012. It would have probably have been of better use to me then, time and experience has made the books potency less effective--but let me begin with the good. This book is the perfect laymen's guide to introversion. Anything the average person who may not know anything about psychology can use the book to its fullest extent. I think this use of simplification is good for getting these ideas circulated for a pop-culture crowd, that does not like complexity or "big-words." It gives good summaries of things and different research and stories of people making introversion work in an extroverted world. For me though, I have become relatively more versed in psychology and philosophy and the concept of introversion and extroversion. I don't mind more mature and technical explanations and a more in-depth look at these contexts. Unlike some reviewers, I don't think Cain was patronizing her audience, but she came dangerously close in some passages. Speaking of audiences....I am not sure if this was done intentionally or not, but it did become apparent to me that there where a specific demographic in-mind for this book--especially as the book made its way to chapter 8. It came to my attention that the group that she is writing to are (as she labels them) "European-Americans." Despite the fact that she opens the book with Rosa Parks, it becomes very clear who she is writing to. I would not have had issue with this if she made this intention clear up-front. I am guessing it was unconscious, but I could still notice the bias. While this is not that big a deal given I read older philosophy and psychology which is very intentional in their ethnic-bias, there was something that I could not ignore.Though the book uses European-Americans (again the author's label, not mine) as the default for introverts, it brings in Asian-Americans (and by extension "Asians" by which she means East Asians) early as an alternative introvert culture. At first, it did not sound to uncontroversial in the context of that chapter, but then we go to chapter 8 and I realized a quarter of the way in that she was trying to sell a modified version of the model minority myth. This myth is a form of contemporary-eugenics or scientific-racism, usually deployed to argue against civil rights for African-Americans. Of course, she is not arguing that position, but she is using almost all of the dog-whistle terms, that more sinister types would use to advance their white supremacist thought. Ironically, I could only make it through 3/5 of that chapter before I skipped the rest and moved on to the next chapter.This was an interesting book with some flaws in it, but I was impressed by how she got a lot of basic 101-level information in one book. It served for me mainly as a prelude for Carl Jung's Psychological Types.

I’ve read many books that thrill me. I’ve read books that stimulate every imaginative neuron in my brain. I’ve read books that incite laughter and tears and violent rage. But never have I read a book so close, so incredibly intimate to, and validating of, my fundamental being.This book was written for and about me. It was written for and about the 1/3 to 1/2 of our population who identify with the introverted soul. The Quiet, as Susain Cain so wonderfully names it. The quiet, introspective personality that the current world rejects, pathologizes, ridicules. But, as Cain points out, the Extroversion Ideal that we’ve so readily adopted in our society may be less beneficial than we had anticipated. Introverts are the yin to extrovert yang and we must recognize and create space for both to facilitate productivity, happiness, and social harmony. But in such a loud, boistrous extroverted world, what’s a highly sensitive introvert to do? I happen to like Susan Cain’s answer: Find where home is, the sweet spot, and then build on the strengths that seem to be natural pieces of your being. And, while you’re in a validating mood, give others permission to find their own truth, loud or quiet as it may be. I would wholeheartedly recommend this book to anybody who is interested, but more than anyone else, I would encourage teachers (even college professors!) and parents to read it. Teachers and parents: You shape the world. Seriously. And you have the capacity to create a wonderful existence for all of our magnificent, introverted students and children. You open the doors to self-esteem and confidence that they don’t know exist and show them that being who they are is not only okay, but that who they are is absolutely valuable; that they have incredible things to offer this world.As a highly sensitive, lifelong introvert, I am so grateful for the the people in my life who choose to honor me for who I am, rather than how often I raise my hand in class or the number of road trips I take with random groups of friends. I am so thankful that I have finally found ways (small as they may be) to be myself in a world designed for my opposite. Read this book.

Hello. My name is Emily and I'm an introvert.I mentioned this to a friend-of-long-standing the other day (we've known each other for about seven years) and she was shocked - shocked! - that I wasn't an extrovert. "Really?!? I never would have guessed!"In Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking, Susan Cain discusses some of the misconceptions about introversion - for example, that introverts are shy - as well as why some introverts are mistaken for extroverts. For one thing, introverts are the minority. About one-third of people are introverts and it's easy for the majority to simply assume that others are like them. Secondly, our culture favors extroverts. "Americans are some of the most extroverted people on earth." Extroversion - being outgoing - is seen as both a personal virtue and as a business advantage, so if you aren't naturally extroverted, developing some extroverted traits is pretty much required for survival. "Nowadays we tend to think that becoming more extroverted not only makes us more successful, but also makes us better people." And that's why many of us introverts fake it, at least some of the time.But, Cain points out, this view is counterproductive and prevents introverts' skill sets and gifts, such as sensitivity, keen observation, intense focus and concentration, introspection, and depth of contemplation, from being used to their best advantage. It "fail[s] to distinguish between good presentation skills and true leadership ability." It neglects the fact that "there are many different kinds of power in this world...The trick is not to amass all the different kinds of available power, but to use well the kind you've been granted."Cain cautions against New Groupthink, brainstorming, and open plan offices, which put introverts at a disadvantage...To read the rest of this review, visit Build Enough Bookshelves.

I enjoyed this book, she shared how America in the early 1900s switch from a focus on character to a focus on personality, and how this has had some harmful results. She showed how we have so glorified the charismatic, confident extroverted personality, that introverts feel they have to fit this mold. Susan Cain then shares some of the many strengths of introverts in the context of education, parenting, leadership, public speaking, business, relationships and culture. She also shared lots of interesting studies concerning personality theory. I now have a little more of an understanding of why I am so bothered by violence and anger and that it actually has something to do with me not having "thick skin"! It is interesting that I am wired to have a more sensitive conscience and to not be motivated by money, power and status. There was some things in this book I've not heard anywhere else, its a book I would like to see land in the hands of all my introverted friends and yeah, even extroverts could benefit from reading it, for it could give them a better understanding of us introverts.

A must-read for everyone: for introverts to gain some surprising insights and for extroverts to understand why quiet doesn't equal bad. One of the surprising things that I learned was extroverts prefer to be yelled at by coaches--it motivates them more. Introverts prefer encouragement. This helped explain a situation where I had quit a sport because I wasn't into being yelled at. I no longer had to feel bad or think the guy was mean; he was just appealing to extroverts.I have met some extroverts who seriously think that being an extrovert is superior to being an introvert. I think it's important for everyone to understand that theses are two equally valid ways of being both with their own strengths and weaknesses. Since introverts receive so many invalidating messages all the time, it's really important to read this book and learn about all of the valuable attributes that being an introvert has. Hopefully "introvert" will cease to be a dirty word if we begin to take pride in our introversion. We don't have to apologize or pretend to be an extrovert. We can just be ourselves.

This book was amazing! As I read thru I saw so much of myself within its pages I felt like someone had cracked open my head and peeled back all the layers. I also felt a fair amount of anger at moments that society acts as though there is something wrong with introverts being the way they are or expects them to be more like extroverts. The whole chapter on the period where drugs were pushed on introverted people to get them to be more extroverted (and essentially deny their own nature) made my blood boil. I highly recommend this for both introverts and especially for someone for who is an extrovert in a relationship with an introvert. You will thank me!Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop TalkingbySusan Cain This book was amazing!As an introvert I feltlike my head had beencracked open andall my secret thoughtspulled out.Highly recommended for introverts and extrovertstrying to understandthe introverts in theirlives!

As good as everyone says and a quick, interesting read. In some ways, it was validation of stuff introverts already know, which is why I can't give it 5 stars, but it was very interesting. I kind of wish that all bosses ever had to read it, since so much of the way that introverts thrive goes against the brainstorming/open floor plan/meeting-centric business model. Even though I think of myself as an introvert, it did help me realize some things about my (even more introverted) husband, and how we're introverted in different ways. Also, this will sound insane if you haven't read it, but it made me think that we're already seeing some introvert/high-reactive signs in my 10 month old, just based on some of the long-term studies Cain discusses. If that turns out to be true (which, based on her parents seems likely anyway), it gave some good ideas for parenting her in a way that is supportive of her introverty needs.

I read it in 3 days. I'm sure this book would be enjoyable for some people, just not for me.
