This was a pretty interesting book for the most part, but it didn't quite live up to the years of hype I'd given it. I think the main reason for that is that it's very America-centric, and while that's understandable, I would have preferred a text that approached introversion/extroversion in a more global sense. I also don't love reading about business people, and there were quite a lot of examples on that. Saying all that though, I feel like this is a good book for helping you come to terms with your introversion (if that is how you identify), and gives good ideas for how to deal with people/situations where the opposite is prevalent.

I already knew before reading Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking by Susan Cain that I am most definitely an introvert. Consider the damning evidence: I would rather stay home and read than go to a party (unless it's composed of close friends). I often find it painful to make small talk. I enjoy being alone. And although people tell me I have a strong personality, I loathe to be the center of attention, preferring instead to be, yes, the quiet, observant one. Yet despite knowing this about myself, I was astonished by how Quiet illuminated my personality, the personalities of those I knew, and my relationships. Reading Quiet was absolutely revelatory. It explained so much and connected so many dots for me that I couldn't stop talking about it for weeks after I read it. Quiet delves into all aspects of introverts such as the historical, psychological, biological. Cain, for example, pinpoints when our society transformed from a culture of character to a culture of personality. The world now celebrates an Extrovert Ideal - paying attention and valuing charisma and a bold personality, men and women of action over the "quieter" ones, those who prefer contemplation. She directly connects the 2008 financial collapse to our society's misplaced faith in extroverts - thinking that those who are the loudest and most persuasive should be at the helm of our financial institutions, without proof that they actually knew what they were doing. "Introversion---along with its cousins sensitivity, seriousness, and shyness--is now a second-class personality trait, somewhere between a disappointment and a pathology."Growing up, and even now, I always felt that my introverted tendencies meant that there was something wrong with me. Why didn't the prospect of large, boisterous parties attract me? Why did I like being by myself so much? Why did I hate making small talk when it was so easy for others? My sister always made fun of me for having much fewer friends than she did. It turns out that all these tendencies didn't mean that I was abnormal (phew!). (*I'm abnormal for other reasons not covered by this book.*)Most of the above stems from the fact that I need less stimulation than extroverts, who need the constant energy from socializing and interacting with other people.Furthermore, being shy and/or antisocial is not synonymous with being an introvert. I love getting together with my friends and planning dinners, movies, and activities. But unlike extroverts, I prefer small, intimate groups. My introverted nature likes one-on-one interactions over large parties. I prefer depth rather than breadth. Quiet celebrates the fact that I and other introverts flourish in solitary pursuits - which is a powerful affirmation. Rather than saying we need to be more outgoing or social, in other words, go against our own nature, Quiet says the world benefits from letting introverts be exactly who they are. Albert Einstein, Van Gogh, Gandhi - all introverts. "Some of our greatest ideas, art, and inventions---from the theory of evolution to Van Gogh's sunflowers to the personal computer--came from quiet and cerebral people who knew how to tune in to their inner worlds and the treasures to be found there." What's troubling is that the world - from schools to the workplace - are geared towards the Extrovert Ideal. Group work anyone? I hated doing that in school and I hate doing it now. Why? Because inevitably, either I do all the work while the group sits on my labor OR one person, usually the loudest and most persuasive, somehow dictates the direction the entire group will go. Yet my schoolmates and I were routinely forced to work in groups. In the workplace, Groupthink, as Cain puts it, is the trend, where everyone is forced to sit a room together to brainstorm ideas, even though studies show that it is less productive. I could go on and on about all the insights in Quiet, but suffice it to say that this is a powerful, insightful, and thought-provoking must-read not only for introverts, but anyone who is close to an introvert - which is to say, everyone should read it!

In her essay Trash, Art and the Movies, Pauline Kael writes:Because of the photographic nature of the medium and the cheap admission prices, movies took their impetus not from the desiccated imitation European high culture, but from the peep show, the Wild West show, the music hall, the comic strip - from what was coarse and common. The early Chaplin two-reelers still look surprisingly lewd, with bathroom jokes and drunkenness and hatred of work and proprieties. And the Western shoot-'em-ups certainly weren't the schoolteachers' notions of art - which in my school days, ran more to didactic poetry and "perfectly proportioned" statues and which over the years have progressed through nice stories to "good taste" and "excellence" - which may be more poisonous than homilies and dainty figurines because then you had a clearer idea of what you were up against and it was easier to fight. And this, of course, is what we were running away from when we went to the movies. All week we longed for Saturday afternoon and sanctuary - the anonymity and impersonality of sitting in a theatre, just enjoying ourselves, not having to be responsible, not having to be "good." Maybe you just want to look at people on the screen and know they're not looking back at you, that they're not going to turn on you and criticize you.Perhaps the single most intense pleasure of moviegoing is this non-aesthetic one of escaping from the responsibilities of having the proper responses required of us in our official (school) culture. And yet this is probably the best and most common basis for developing an aesthetic sense because responsibility to pay attention and to appreciate is anti-art, it makes us too anxious for pleasure, too bored for response. Far from supervision and official culture, in the darkness at the movies where nothing is asked of us and we are left alone, the liberation from duty and constraint allows us to develop our own aesthetic responses.Take those moviegoers, sunk to a seat for an all-too-brief 120 minutes of unrestricted freedom - the freedom to think for themselves, to react for themselves, to judge for themselves, to seed that aesthetic sensibility for themselves - and you have a rough approximation of what is going on with the segment of the population Susan Cain is talking about. Introverts discover, very early on, this pocket of precious ease and abandon; this space where all the rules and expectations vanish; where development, deep and profound internal development, can actually happen. And when given a choice this is the space they choose, the pocket they prefer to inhabit.Life is not particularly kind to the introvert. The "team" ethic and the collaborative demands introduced in schools and carried through to the business world often run roughshod over the heightened sensitivities of the quiet ones among us. And how is this reacted to? Well, we ask those quiet ones to suck it up. Suck it up and change. Speak up! Take charge! Stop being such a doormat! Get out there and participate! And the introvert will end up attempting this. For you. Because it's obviously what you need her to do. And because she wants to be respected by you, sad you, who doesn't seem to be capable of respecting her just the way she is.Wait. That's not what's happening! Or is it?Susan Cain has written a wonderful book that addresses these issues in a wonderful way. Well worth the read. In fact, I passed several copies out to friends.

I learned some things from this book but based on all the hype it received and my preexisting interest in the subject matter, it didn't quite meet my expectations. It was definitely emphasized the pop in pop science.Structurally, the chapters felt like serialized essays and I was never quite able to identify the thread pulling it all along. And that definitely kept me more distant and never really pulled me in. In particular, I was disappointed that at the end she admits she just followed whatever popular definitions of introvert and extrovert matched any particular topic she covered, rather than sticking to consistent meanings. I feel like I've seen this pattern before, where a journalistic writer immerses themselves in a subject and then feels compelled to dictate all of the experiences into a book length treatment, without stopping to throw some out and sculpt the rest in the service of building a more compelling whole. "If my editors paid me to go to a Tony Robbins seminar, well then I should have a chapter about it." That one could've been cut, as could the really watered down one about the evangelicals. I found the chapter on Asian immigrants in California to be particularly muddled. Since other parts of the book spent time on the genetic roots of introversion, I expected an explanation on how an entire country and culture could be more introverted than another. I wasn't expecting a deep psychological or sociological analysis, but she could have at least interviewed some folks on the question. To me, the whole section came across as being more about Eurocentric values (and specifically, the disastrous "You are special" values that millenials were spoon-fed) rather than really telling us anything new about introversion/extroversion. But, again, after I read the tacked-on disclaimer that "introvert" just meant whatever she needed it to mean at the time, perhaps I was expecting too much.A common criticism in other reviews (usually written by extroverts) is that it the book suffers from an anti-extrovert bias. It seemed hard to take those claims seriously when it seems more likely the reader was just used to the whole world singing the praises of their temperament 24/7 and being uncomfortable hearing that it had any weaknesses. If anything, I didn't find the book anti-extrovert so much as excessively pro-introvert, especially since it didn't do a great job disentangling shyness/social anxiety with introversion, and it seems clear that such anxieties are quite harmful.All that being said, it's a quick read on the subject and worth reading. It made me reflect on some of the ways in which I've conformed to extrovert work culture, particularly after working for years at a consulting firm which definitely emphasized the practical necessity of practicing extroverted behavior to succeed. It inspired me to do a better job to make space for all of us to hear and learn from quieter voices.I also very much appreciated Cain's overall goal to challenge the Extrovert Ideal. Trump's rise alone makes some of the material more frightening. It's one thing for extroverted finance Alphas to bring down the economy; it's a step further to annihilate the world with nuclear weapons. Let's hope we all hear more from introverts and less from blowhards.

For me, this book was truly amazing. It is the most comprehensive and insight psychologically based book I have read since discovering the Road Less Traveled 20 years ago. Most psychology or self-help books have a few strong chapters, followed by a few mediocre ones, followed by several terrible ones. This book is the exception. I kept waiting for the book to fall short – but it holds strong till the end. Susan Cain has done an amazing job not only helping others to see how introversion/extroversion plays out in the dominant US culture, but she has compiled a wealth of psychological studies that are summarized with stunning clarity and brilliant personal insight. I have taken the Myers Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) Test 3 times over the past 25 years. Each time I regrettably scored as an introvert. I was embarrassed by this label as I felt it meant I was destined to be shy, socially awkward, and not outgoing. However, this book has helped me fully embrace and accept my introversion. Her illuminating examples of what it means to be an introvert were incredibly helpful. I love to have fun as much as the next person, but I have purposely only eaten lunch with co-workers a handful of times over the past 19 years because I don't want to be exhausted the rest of the work day. On the weekends, rather than spend time making small talk at parties with people I barely know, I would rather spend time with close friends and family, talking in depth about meaningful topics while building relationships I value. The book also helped clarify for me why I love my work so much as professor, researcher, and therapist. I prefer the inner world of ideas, spending time alone thinking, and sharing the things I value with others through teaching and discussion (see free trait theory in Chapter 9). I also greatly enjoy understanding the inner worlds of others and working together to find ways to decrease emotional suffering and distress. A few of the highlights of this book include her summary of the emerging body of research on 'high reactive' and 'sensitive' temperaments in Chapter 4-5. It is revolutionary. And Chapter 6 which details how the introversion of Eleanor Roosevelt balanced FDR's extroversion is an exceptional piece of research and writing. Both introverts and extroverts will find value in this book. Introverts will likely appreciate how the book gives voice to feelings they have lived with for years but never quite had words to express. Extroverts will find increased understanding and appreciation for the inner world of the introvert - particularly if they have an introverted child, spouse, co-worker, or friend. Although I doubt extroverts will experience the excitement of discovery that introverts will often feel as they read, they will be able to more fully appreciate the differences between themselves and introverts. Cain makes this brilliant point more than once – that in the end, what we all need is balance. Introverts need extroverts, and extroverts need introverts. My hat goes off to Susan Cain. This is a beautifully written and researched book. I give it my highest recommendation.

It took me two months to read the first fifty pages, and then one day to read the rest.I've kind of exhausted myself on this topic over on my blog, and also in my conversations with my mother (a fellow introvert), so I'll just say here that while the book initially isn't what I wanted, I came around once Cain shifted her focus from societal trends to individuals. I appreciated that there was science, and, like Cain, the thing I found most revelatory was Professor Little's Free Trait Theory: you may sometimes act out of character/against type, and that's okay if it's in the service of something you really, really care about. (Also the corresponding Free Trait Agreement--if you're with someone, you'll give and take--was pretty cool too.)Bonus points for:1) Acknowledging the Universal Hide in the Bathroom Principle. (If you don't know what I'm talking about, that's okay, it takes all kinds!)2) Pointing out that the internet is actually the introvert's dream format. Peace without loneliness! Non-exhausting connections at your fingertips!3) The guy at Claremont McKenna who got up early "just to savor time alone with a steaming cup of coffee." Replace tea, and you've got my life now.4) "the life of the mind"5) "'The stereotype of the university professor is accurate for so many people on campus. They like to read; for them there's nothing more exciting than ideas. And some of this has to do with how they spent their time when they were growing up. If you spend a lot of time charging around, then you have less time for reading and learning. There's only so much time in your life.'" That last line is something both sides of the spectrum should be able to say, but you so rarely hear it applied in this context.6) Introvert guilt, which I completely identified with and had always chalked up to Catholic Guilt.7) The brief introduction to situationism.8) "Finally, pay attention to what you envy. Jealousy is an ugly emotion, but it tells the truth."9) "person-environment fit"Points deducted:1) In all that talk of fear of public speaking, not once did anyone mention nervous poo. Forgive me for being frank, but it's a phenomenon my college roommate (who I am sending this book immediately) discussed endlessly. Quelle oversight!No, but really:1 and only) I found the first section on the Extrovert Ideal annoying and stressful. Yes, we all know that's how it is. I don't want to read about the vagaries of open office plans and group work (spawn of the devil, and I knew that as a preschooler) and megachurches where extroversion is mandatory. I want to read about people and what they actually do. In the two months it took me to read that part, I found myself thinking longingly of what I wanted to be reading instead: a book of essays written by introverts about their full, purpose-driven lives. Learning by example, that's me. I want to be shown, not told. Fortunately the book changed tack slightly, but she almost lost me there.

I am a closet introvert. Most of my life I have functioned as an introvert, but in my work I take on the persona of an extrovert. Susan Cain calls me a pseudo-extrovert -- someone who for various reasons takes on the identity of an extravert. Cain's thesis is that for most of the 20th century, Americans worshiped people who were extroverts and discouraged introverts. We see this in a school system that encourages socialization. In the last 30 years parents have taken this to the extreme with extra-curricular activities almost every day of the week. Outgoing, friendly people are celebrated. The book worm, the loner, is discouraged. My wife of 40 years, on the other hand, is a classic extrovert. She was born talking. She has never met a stranger who she couldn't start a conversation with. We can be sitting in the Drs. office and she will strike up a conversation with someone sitting in the next chair. In the mornings, I prefer silence. Since I don't talk, she turns on the TV so she hears someone talking. She is outgoing and friendly. Everyone falls in love with her. People when they first meet me see me as grumpy and grouchy even though I am not. I am just very quiet. We are opposites that were attracted to each other. What has happened in the last 40 years is that I have taken on some of the behaviors of an extrovert and she has taken on some of the behaviors of an introvert. We have learned to live together.Susan Cain has amassed an enormous amount of research demonstrating that society, business, communities and even marriages need and benefit from having both introverts and extroverts on the team. Steve Wozinak, inventor of the Apple computer, needed a Steve Jobs to market and sell the computer. We are all to varying degrees somewhere on the introvert - extrovert continuum. If you are an introvert or an extrovert or in a relationship with one or the other, then you need to read this book. Business people should read this book to understand their employees, their bosses and their peers. Teachers should read this book to understand the differences in the personalities of the children they teach. Husbands and wives should read this book to understand each other. If there is only one book you are going to read this year, it should be Quiet by Susan Cain. This book could save your marriage, your job, and your life.

If American culture has a personality preference would it be the outgoing, social extrovert or the reserved and thoughtful introvert? In Susan Cain's new book Quiet: The Power of Introverts In A World That Can't Stop Talking she posits that the former is our template, something she calls the Extrovert Ideal. This "ideal self is gregarious, alpha, and comfortable in the spotlight" and though this is an "enormously appealing personality style ...we've turned it into an oppressive standard."The most compelling material is front-loaded, especially in discussions like how new the phrase "having a good personality" is (20th century), and how advertising for things like soap in the 1920s were pointing toward a more confident outgoing self. Cain visits a Tony Robbins rally/seminar and Harvard Business School seeking to understand the dynamics of extroversion, and visits Rick Warren's Saddleback Church with the author of a book on introversion in the church who has good insights into the quiet, liturgy, and contemplation found in high church tradition and missing in evangelical megachurches. There will be recognition here for most readers drawn to a book like this.The missteps come later on, mostly centered on explaining events/people through the lens of extroversion/introversion and the "exciting research" of neuroscience. She frames things like the rejection of Al Gore's climate change advocacy and Moses’ reluctance to serve Yahweh in terms of their introversion and tries to show that evolution has given us a "new brain" that replaces the "old brain", which sounds suspiciously like our sinful nature to begin with. There are time where inserting categories like temperament can't bear the weight of the application she's using, and between these speculations that are not well grounded and the trips into scientism they grind the book to a halt in places.This is a book that will appeal to readerly types whose very love of books and what they provide predispose them to the arguments contained. There is a bit too much us-versus-them and it is overlong but to have someone write about what so many of us think is thrilling if not completely satisfying in the end.

I always knew that I was reserved but never considered myself an introvert. I was the one who preferred to go to the movies alone and always hated unexpected surprises from friends. Once I went to the movies alone, it was so peaceful that I felt that I was the only one in the theater. After researching countless of articles, I realized that I was not antisocial. Neither was I shy or rude as some extroverts assume but I was simply a introvert. There are a countless of occasions when I can remember me feeling like I did not belong in a big crowd. All of that mingling meaningless chatter about nothing has put a tremendous toil on me. Usually I will recharge by reading a book or walking alone in the park. Now I have told my close friends of who I am, I now can live my life without feeling socially awkward for not talking.Susan Cain book taught me to appreciate my introversion. The initial pages of this book was mesmerizing, the way she described herself under a different name. I loved how she eloquently described the misconceptions about an introvert and a extrovert. My favorite part was when she detailed why introverts are considered "bad leaders" because their unwillingness to speak up. It really highlighted the bias that society has against them. Introverts are in the minority but they are possibly the most trusted and respected individuals. However I am not suggesting that they are smarter than the extroverts but because of them being misunderstood,they are richly valued.Although this book had some great valid points, I can't say that I agree with all of it. For instance, I don't think that an introvert should conform to extroverted traits. Whether that is a on job interview, date or making friends. They should be allowed to live amicably with everyone, whether they have a gregarious personality or a quiet one. Also I thought that this book was heavily researched(not saying it is a bad thing) and it somewhat took away the quality of the book. In other words, I wanted it to be more persuasive than informative.Despite those minor flaws, this is a excellent book for introverts and extroverts. Understanding the difference can possibly change your perspective of them & possibly your life!!!

If you are an introvert, you've got to read this book. The author admits she has been working on this book since 2005, but has really been thinking about it all her life. If you live in the USA, you live in one of the most extroverted countries in the world, one where your strengths as an introvert are not often valued. From the time you were a child you were probably told to speak up in class, make large groups of friends, and join lots of group activities. As an adult, you may work in large offices with no private space. This book is filled with fascinating research. Ms. Cain traces the time in our history when personality with a capital P came to be the most valued trait, rather than character. Just at the time when people began leaving the farm for industrialized cities, the extrovert ideal began to blossom. Our Western cultural emphasis on rugged individualism contributed to the mix. (Later in the book she notes how Asians, whose cultural ideal is one of humility and harmony with the whole, have trouble navigating the extreme extroversion required in our places of education and business.) Ms. Cain looks at current brain research and speculates on how evolution may have required the two aspects of behavior as balancing strengths for human survival. She gives you ways to manage your life to make sure your requirements as an introvert are met. She looks at introverted children in the home and classroom, and at partnerships in which one member is an extrovert and the other an introvert. She says that from one third to nearly one half of us are introverts, so we are not so rare; many of us have just become very good at masking our true selves to meet the requirements of our society. This is an empowering book for the quiet, reflective, introspective among us. As the author says at the end, "We know from myths and fairy tales that there are many different kinds of powers in this world.....The trick is not to amass all the different kinds of available power, but to use well the kind you've been granted." (p.266)

From the start I was very frustrated with the "us" (introverts) versus "them" (extroverts) tone that carries throughout the book. This is a complex characterization; different people fit into different categories based on circumstances and situations. Putting everyone into only two categories oversimplifies human behavior.The author states American society is dominated by extroverts; introverts are either pushed to the sidelines or forced to become extroverts. Yet the only examples she presents to support this statement are Harvard Business School and, to a lesser extent, salesmen. Neither of these examples are even somewhat representative of American society. Most of the author's examples of introverts seemed to argue against an extrovert dominated society.The author only mentions the fields of law and psychology. Why wasn't there more research or discussion about stereotypical introvert fields like engineering, mathematics, or research science? I have a hard time understanding how the author struggled to make a connection between race but didn't dive into the segregation of professional fields in our own culture. The Asian argument was interesting but poorly developed. How do Indian cultures differ? I would have been interested in more development of Asian business culture. Where is the line between cultural differences and personality type differences? (I used to work for an engineering firm in Taiwan; of all the challenges we faced, I never felt is was due to different personality types).Another frustrating theme that carried throughout was one third to one half of society are introverts. Yet, the author narrated as if introverts are a significant minority, a uncommon occurrence. Where are all these extroverts that dominate our culture? I don't know any, maybe I have subconsciously built up a shield and only surround myself with the introvert minority.One star may seem harsh, but this was a very frustrating book for me to get through.

The main focus in Susan Cain’s book is on the quiet uncelebrated introvert. We spend so much time enamored of the Tony Robbins of the world, but couldn’t we use a little more time listening to those who don’t often speak-up? We need to set aside time for the thinkers, the dreamers, and those who speak only when it really matters. Allowing introverts their quiet reflective time can bring out the Tsunami of an idea. Author Susan Cain also points out that some of the greatest thinkers were introverts like Einstein, Newton, and even Dr. Suess.One of the great things this book does is to identify why people are introverted and how they can use those inherit traits (calm, resolute, reflective) to be very effective in any work environment, even as CEOs of major corporations. It made me think a great deal about how to work with those who may need more space or may take more time to come to a conclusion. Those who are introverted, as I myself am, need to find a balance of stimulation in their life. It provides excellent advice for those who are introverted, how to create an environment for success, and how to harness their power to bring out the best in them. If you read only one chapter, read chapter nine. It talks about when you should act more extroverteed than you really are, but also to identify when you are acting like a pseudo-extrovert. She even goes further than this analysis and confidence building, but also goes into relationship advice and parenting. This is a whole new category that we need to pay more attention to other than the occasional Myers-Briggs testing. I think the most important point was that whatever your personality you have to find your right stimulation balance and stand firm in that need. It will lead to a happier and better balanced life.

As an introvert (like, I suspect, many of us on here!), it was very comforting to read this book. We're often made to feel as if there's something wrong with us, and indeed until introversion became more well-known I felt as if there was something wrong with me.This was on the whole, a warm, reassuring hug in book form. It was slightly drier than I usually prefer my non-fiction, but it was still an excellent read.

This could have definitely been 4 stars if not for 2 reasons:In the first chapter/section of the book Cain comes off praising introverts and putting down extroverts in every way. I understand that she herself is an introvert and there will be that bias, but I was not a fan of her tone. To me it seemed that she was saying introverts were intrinsically better people than extroverts by enumerating all the bad things extroverts do (gambling, failing in stock market, cheating on significant others, etc). Not sure if she was trying to go for a strong hook to catch readers or what the intention was since this isn't the same tone in the rest of the book.The conclusion of this book is also a bit unexpected. Towards the end it seems like it becomes a child development book for new parents. I appreciate the connection Cain makes between what the experiments have taught us in the lab and connecting that to practical uses, but it ended up being unexpectedly focused on children.Aside from those complaints the book was engaging. I was very interested in how she defined the two groups and she gave complete definitions supported with a good amount of data as well as real world examples most people could relate to. The sections on connecting biology to the psychological differences differences between introverts and extroverts was also very fascinating. Most importantly I did enjoy the message of accepting and adapting to people as they are, and being very mindful that people aren't always how they seem on the outside (which isn't necessarily a bad thing either).

In the American business world of team building, groupthink, committees, office barns with no privacy; of schools with pods of students trained to adhere to the American business model, there is also the academic research world of scientists who are discovering and affirming that celebrating and promoting "hail fellow, well met" Harvard Business School clones exclusively might not be in America's best interests. Consider the American financial world's performance leading up to 2008, when senior management level non-risk averse/reward-seeking/dopamine-addled extroverts almost brought down the entire global economy. Susan Cain has done considerable research for this book, indeed she said she has been working on it nonstop for her entire life, in part because she is an introvert and is passionate about the subject. She also has a consulting practice that helps businesses and people learn how to live with quiet people, temperament differences, and how to raise a confident, successful introverted child. I couldn't put the book down, so I underslept a little. I'm an introvert, and although I can act out as an extrovert, have managed to take the Myers-Briggs often enough to change my I to an E, it's a relief to know that there's not much point. Plus all that exposure and test taking is exhausting. Introverts comprise about 1/3 of humans, introverts are creative, thoughtful. contributing people, and we need to give them a little room. And a door. With a lock.

An enlightening read. Some parts are a bit text book-like with the scientific study results, but the author was adept at weaving between those and the real life personal stories of people interviewed for the book, keeping it interesting. Some of those studies are quite fascinating. Overall much food for thought in these pages. Americans in particular undervalue the introvert. From the time we’re small children it is almost universally accepted as a negative, unpopular trait, despite the fact that most of our cherished inventions and grand ideas come from the minds of these individuals. This book will give anyone a new appreciation for the shy and quiet among us and hopefully be fuel for a change of perspective in corporate settings and classrooms. From the introduction:Without introverts, the world would be devoid of: the theory of gravity, the theory of relativity, W. B. Yates’s ‘The Second Coming’, Chopin’s nocturnes, Proust’s ‘In Search Of Time, Peter Pan, Orwell’s ‘Nineteen Eighty-Four’ and ‘Animal Farm’, The Cat In The Hat, Charlie Brown, Schindler’s List, E.T., Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Google, and Harry Potter. More examples abound, and yes, those geeky introverted guys who imagined and built the first prototype of my beloved Apple Macbook Pro are given their due.

This book offers moments of profound reassurance for those of us who call ourselves introverts. I recommend it to anyone who has found themselves cringing in a corner at a busy party, counting down the minutes until a speech or presentation or meeting is over, or opting for the company of a good book over friends. It's also a great read if you are extroverted and simply don't understand why your employee, spouse, or child doesn't want or require the same degree of social participation you do. It explores how Western culture is essentially a culture of extroversion, and the unique challenges and opportunities this presents for the introverts of the world. Cain also makes a case for a greater acceptance and deeper appreciation for people who might have lots to say, but not necessarily out loud, all the time. Shyness is not a disease, and solitude offers great benefits and breeds big thinkers. There is a cultural, psychological, and physiological basis for different personality types - Quiet suggests that the social scales be balanced for a greater understanding of our fellow man.

Since the time I picked it, I'm wondering why I didn't pick it up earlier? That would have made my life much easier and days merrier.Being a classic introvert, the book resonated with me. It was like somebody knew exactly what I'm and then telling that back to me. I'm planning to write complete extract of Quiet so that I can read it every now and then. Why I liked Quiet so much is it doesn't force you to become someone else you don't want to. It encourages being yourself because it's perfectly OK to be and that there's nothing wrong with you. When everyone around tries to be cool, Susan Cain prompts to remain warm and be compassionate with oneself. She also tells that there are different strengths being sensitive and cerebral. Instead of trying to be what you are not, play to our own strengths and make best of us. I would urge everyone to read it. One in every three persons is introvert and so it maybe your close one if not you. It enriches us, improves our understanding about the fellow human beings and promots acceptance. Now isn't it a great message?

I started Quiet with no small sense of trepidation; At times what passes for Psychology non-fiction in the marketplace can leave one cringing for days, also reference to the controversial Myers-Briggs personality types had me much worried about spurious trends and links between personality and success.That sense, however, left as quickly as it arrived. Cain uses Intro and Extravert as broad terms, focusing more on how responsive people are to their environment (people who are highly responsive tend to be introverted as the world is that much more intense and need plenty of processing time)Cain goes on to explore how extraversion is over-valued in Western culture, how this is different across other cultures and the risks of a world that loves outspoken action rather than sensitivity and nouce.For me this book was a personal revelation, not just about my own psyche, but how the world around works.

This book will be on the shelves in Jan. 2012. I'm reading an advanced reading copy from the publisher and I think, as a confirmed introvert, that I'm really going to like it.I've finished the book and I must say that it gave me some really good insight into our "extrovert ideal" culture and the pressures that are brought to bear upon those who don't fit that mold. Especially fascinating is research done on infants that shows introversion/extroversion characteristics at very early ages. This book encourages introverts to accept their temperaments, to appreciate the positive aspects of being "quiet", and gently advises us how to feel more comfortable in a world that does not always value introspection. Good advice for parents as well on raising introverted children.

This was interesting, I had no idea there was so much to explore about the introvertism. I've long known that I like to spend time by myself surrounded by lots of other people in stimulating environments, and now I know that it isn't in conflict with me being a card carrying introvert. I learned that you can situationally fake not being an introvert, particularly if you are pursuing something that is meaningful to you. But that faking can come at a cost, and one needs to be mindful of restorative spaces. This has come highly (view spoiler)[in a quiet way (hide spoiler)] recommended to me and I have been Quietly waiting in the library queue for this to become available. SCREAMS... FINALLY! Now, shhhh while I put in my earbuds and listen.

Shhh! Hey, c’mere. I know, I know, I’m whispering, but you have to when you are talking about a book like this. Quiet. It’s called Quiet. And it’s a book about all the amazing people out there, doing amazing work, but who aren’t In-Your-Face people. We forget about these people. We have, as a society, Cain writes, come to believe that everyone who is anyone is an extrovert. Cain speaks up for the quiet people, reminding us of all those who have been and are doing their quiet work, who have and are living their quiet lives, who have and are quietly eating and drinking and shopping and reading books. Being an introvert is not bad, she proclaims. Quietly, of course.

It's not just me! Finally, we introverts have a voice to verbalize all the thoughts and fears that the extrovert world doesn't understand or tolerate. This book is liberating. We are not anti-social and it's ok to need occasional solitude to recharge. I read this book and felt great but also angry. Our culture is messed up, we are encouraged to speak and not listen, to fake gregariousness and not be genuine, and to utilize group-think (whatever the hell that is) instead of focused concentration. Susan Cain rocks. Read it and lose the guilt.

Life changing. Wish this book was on more educators' lists. Everything in the Common Core is about collaboration and yet there are studies that show independent workers are often more successful than teams. Most importantly, this book validates my life! Now that I know my need for "restorative niches" is real due to my personality, it will make me feel less guilty about looking for them on a daily basis.

I am an introvert but most people who don't know me well (and some who do) are fooled. I found this book to be a breath of fresh air. I understand myself a little better and I think I will know how to raise my child better. I suspect he's either a sensitive or also an introvert and a sensitive like his mom. I recommend this to anyone who wants to interact with the world with greater ease, understanding, and compassion.

Thoroughly enjoyed this book. While I learned more about the differences between extroverts and introverts, I enjoyed the personal vignettes -- the glimpses into the extraordinary lives of some well-known and lesser-known introverts.

Look, there are some really interesting topics in this book, but she could have told this in half the space. Too much history and talk talk talk, so I got bored, so then I left it for a few weeks.The fact that it took me over 10 months to finish says enough.
This book really helped me to understand me and how I mechanize. I'll probably go back to this book time to time and reread it.
Good book and a great way to begin to really understand introverts!It ends at 70% (references and the like).
