A bit dry, but lots of good bits. Just took a while to get thru - taking it a little bit at a time. Would have been really helpful if I had this 25 years ago! Had to learn some of these things the hard way over the years. For example, from grade school thru high school I would often be accused of being stuck-up. Totally confounded me - I wasn't popular, my parents didn't have a lot of money to spend on trendy, fashionable clothes, I didn't have a car or whatever item/gadget was "the thing to have" at the time. If it wasn't being accused of being stuck-up, I be accused of not liking or hating someone, while maybe I hardly was even aware that person existed, not to mention knowing them well enough to have established an opinion one way or the other about them. That continued even later on after college when I started working. Finally I realized that my being so quiet (and VERY much an introvert - like ALL the way over on the scale) many people are intimidated by that. And since they can't read my mind, and I'm not running on at the mouth giving away what's running thru my mind, they will project their thoughts onto me. If they are insecure, those thoughts they project will not be positive in attitude - instead they will assume I am thinking the worst about them. A worthwhile read, if a little tedious at times. But I think I'll probably go back to it now and again to re-read parts of it, and refresh parts that I highlighted. This book would probably be most interesting to introverts, extroverts who live or work closely with introverts, or someone who has a particular interest in behavioral psychology.

My niece and I, who are both high-reactives, decided to read this book together. We learned much about the psychology behind our introversion, our hypersensitivity, our propensity toward creativity, etc., but my niece made a particularly insightful observation early on in the read that proved true throughout the entire book: extroverts are not always put in the best light. Modifiers ascribed to extroversion in this book consistently are negative, while modifiers applied to introverts are, if not always positive, at least used to put the best construction on a situation.Overall, I found the book helpful, though it is difficult to trust the research values behind anyone who publishes statements such as this: "Even the Western God is assertive, vocal, and dominant; his son Jesus is kind and tender, but also a charismatic, crowd-pleasing man of influence."The work cited as historical proof of this assertion? Not any primary source, but...wait for it...Lloyd Webber's JESUS CHRIST SUPERSTAR.

It's a valuable book, but it's written in such a dry way that my mind was often wandering and I didn't care about the vast majority of what was in here. It seems my initial instinct of "do not read, you already know tons about introversion from the internetz" was mostly true. I did not, however, hate it and I did find some value in it such as the importance of looking at if there are spots for me to hide away and reflect at work. My current work is not open concept exactly, but it sort of is and everything is overcrowded and I just hate it. I think the chapters about introverted children are also especially helpful for parents or teachers who just don't know or understand how to respect who their children are.

"Quiet" is definitely a book that anyone could benefit from reading and I especially recommend it to all parents and teachers for its excellent discussions about the learning style of an introvert. It is an excellent exploration of the introvert-extrovert personality functions and encourages people to appreciate both ways of functioning. Susan Cain excels in exploring how introverts have influenced the world, and in particularly the internet and the upstart of the computer age. My feeling is that the positive understanding of the introvert described in this book would please Carl Jung, who as Susan Cain points out to have coined both the word 'introvert' and its original meaning with the person primarily receiving energy from within the world of one's ideas, imagination and feelings rather than from the outer world of people and things as do extroverts. And Jung never intended for the word introvert to be synonymous with the word “shy” as it has been twisted to mean nor that introverts are necessarily ineffective people or less appealing than extroverts. In fact, Jung was an introvert himself, as was both Myers and Briggs (that I know from personal communication in the 70s with Isabel Myers herself), who were instrumental in introducing us to these concepts of the functions of our personality with the MBTI. So the question is, how did the meaning of introvert" get so twisted and distorted as to mean something less valued than being an extrovert? Susan Cain addresses this question with an explanation of the business personal models and the extrovert ideals that began to storm into the picture in the 20s with Dale Carnegie and others who were pedaling a shift from honoring morality toward self-presentation and personality. I think it would give her discussion a deeper understanding if she also looked at the huge influence that John Watson and his behavioristic views had in the 20’s and 30’s on the advertising world, as well as on business and personnel assessment and development. After being forced to leave the academic world due to a sexual scandal, Watson entered Madison Avenue in the 20s and began showing the advertising world how to apply behavioristic methods to boost sales by the manipulation of the public ideals. His influence of applied psychology in the field of personnel assessment and management was responsible for the idea that “failing businessmen” (remember we are also talking about the gender prejudice of the 20s and 30s) were advised to learn to “talk about more than just their business but also other subjects, like golf and fishing in order to be ‘all you can be’”. Watson strongly advised that we reinvent ourselves to be more of the successful ideal, and yes that meant being outgoing and talkatively social. In many ways, I have felt that the distortion of Jung’s original brilliant Depth Psychological meaning of the word “introvert” was a result of the conflict between Watson’s behaviorist applied psychology and more humanistic schools of psychology. And the struggle between and among these vastly different schools of psychological thought still prevails, less we would have little need for this wonderful book by Susan Cain explaining what being an introvert is really suppose to mean.As a graduate student in the 60s in school psychology and psychometry, I was disgusted with the personality inventories commonly used and that I had to study and endure taking and giving as a part of my studies. On the left side of the test results and assessment profile sheets of these inventories were personality characteristics that were considered undesirable and emotionally unhealthy; and on the right side were the healthy and desirable personality traits (reflecting the DSM-3). You may have already guessed it that “introvert” was on the left. This interpretation of typology served to throw me toward looking for an alternative inventory that reflected a way of viewing people that included all ways of functioning as valuable. This was not because I was an introvert, as I have always scored very extrovert, but because this arrangement of introvert and extrovert as one being good and one being bad was plain unbelievable to me, since I had also had the opportunity to read some of Jung’s works and knew this was not how Jung viewed introvert and extrovert. Fortunately, after beginning a teaching career in Gainesville, Florida where the MBTI was being studied extensively, I met and had the grand experience of personally knowing Isabel Briggs Myers, and consequently embraced the MBTI as a personality inventory. Anyone who enjoys “Quiet”, would also enjoy reading Isabel Briggs Myers’ book “Gifts Differing: Understanding Personality Type”, which was published in 1980 upon her death, and is written also in a very easy to read style exploring type in positive ways.Martha Char Loveauthor of What's Behind Your Belly Button? A Psychological Perspective of the Intelligence of Human Nature and Gut Instinct

Quiet was great at helping think about the kind of work that I want to do. There's a certain amount of self-negation that I have taught myself after moving to this country. Not that India was any more or less friendly to the introverted kind, just that I felt comfortable in my own skin and less of an outsider. Except, that self-negation is not really taught but rather a reaction to how I know people perceive my personality, and I feel much better equipped to think about how I interact with different kinds of people. Susan Cain's cheering of the introverted personality was comforting to read. She throws study after study aiming to alter the way introversion is perceived as anxious, terrified and misanthropic. I've read all about the introvert processing more external stimuli and being highly reactive to the environment, however it was good to remind myself about that again. I'd recommend this for introverts who need a little reaffirming of their selves., this book is categorized as self-help after all. Unfortunately, I still see a world where the extroverted ideal is considered better than anything so the best my fellow introverts can do is find ways to cope. For that, this book is great.

It is funny how someone speaking softly but with conviction can change a conversation. Susan Cain has done just that with her bestselling Quiet. The book is about the unique gift, the "quiet power", introverts bring to the world, particularly American culture, which places a premium on extroverted behavior--group work, public charisma, being the life of the party. And this is important as she argues because one-third to one-half of all people are introverts. Cain is not arguing that we suddenly coddle introverts or that being extroverted is bad. Rather, she paints a compelling picture of what happens when introverts and extroverts can appreciate each other's temperament and gifts. Her examples of this include Rosa Parks and Martin Luther King, Jr and Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt. She introduces the book with a compelling narrative of her work with a young Wall Street lawyer and the negotiation she faced in terror that turned out with her being offered a job by opposing counsel. During the negotiation "Laura" turned to her "quiet power" and through persistent questions and proposal carried the day against her extroverted, brazen opposite. "Laura", it turns out is our author.The first part of the book focuses on the American extrovert ideal. Cain traces the history of this ideal and what she calls "the new Groupthink" and its manifestations in education, business, and even the church (she visits Saddleback Church at one point observing that it was "all communication" with no chance for reflection).In the second part of the book, she turns to the research on temperament and argues that introverts are actually different in their sensitivity to stimuli, in how their brains process dopamine, and more. This is the most technical part of the book but Cain livens this up through first person interviews and illustrative stories including that of Franklin and Eleanor, and the contrast between the "Masters of the Universe" on Wall Street and Warren Buffett. At the same time, she avoids a "biology is destiny" argument. Introverts can push the boundaries of their temperament in things like public speaking when it is for causes and purposes they care for deeply.Part three is the shortest section, just one chapter, in which she proposes that all cultures do not share our extrovert ideals. Working in a university context with many Asian-Americans, I found this of interest because she suggests that the Asian ideal is different and that all the group discussions in our classrooms and the extroverted character of much of campus life poses real strains for many Asian-Americans. Part of the strain is the pull to deny one's own cultural heritage and temperament, thinking the American is "better".Part four focuses on how introverts may constructively engage an extrovert world--when to act more extroverted than you are, how to talk to the opposite type and how to raise children who are introverted. Most enlightening to me was the idea of not "throwing them in the deep" when they fear something, but gradually and safely introducing them to new things. I've know introverts who received the former treatment in childhood who still carry painful memories of these experiences.Perhaps it is part of her lawyerly training, but Cain writes with clarity, building a compelling argument in a quiet voice, with nothing extra. What I most appreciate, in contrast to some I've read on this topic, is that Cain does not come off "whiny" or with an entitlement mentality. She makes her case for cherishing the gift introverts bring to the world without downplaying the gifts of others. Her plea is one that plays not on guilt manipulation but the recognition of a tremendous opportunity to recognize what introverts add to our families, our organizations, and our world.

“Introversion—along with its cousins sensitivity, seriousness, and shyness—is now a second-class personality trait, somewhere between a disappointment and a pathology. Introverts living under the Extrovert Ideal are like women in a man’s world, discounted because of a trait that goes to the core of who they are.”The first thing I want to say about this book is that I want to give it to everyone. I want to bulk buy it and just hand it to everyone I know and people I meet on the street. I also understand that this is not because the book itself is perfect, but because it covers a subject that is incredibly dear to me and that not enough people know about. I wish I’d known about introversion and extroversion when I was growing up, I wish my parents, my teachers, my friends, had known. I wish this because, despite growing up with a decent amount of self-love, a lot of the guilt I felt for not socializing more, for not liking parties, for not having a shitton of friends, is something I can still clearly recall. I wish I’d known I was perfectly normal. There are things about this book I dislike; how it focuses too much on introversion vs. extroversion in the world of big businesses (we’re introduced to Wall Street lawyers, salesmen, etc.) and is extremely USA-centered. A broader range of examples, from people and situations from different social-classes (not just the top and a few in the middle) would have been nice, as well as perhaps a European perspective. However, they are small complaints. All in all I found this to be an excellent look at introversion. Susan Cain treats her subject-matter very seriously, probably due to the fact that she is herself an introvert and feels, the way I do, that the world ought to know being an introvert is perfectly fine – that in some ways, we have strengths that extroverts don’t (and vice versa). The crime being that one is accepted as the norm, while the other is considered a flaw, thus lowering (to an extreme degree) the chance of those introvert-strengths ever being put to good use. If you want a very deep look into what makes a person introverted/extroverted, then this is not that book. It’s a mix of science, psychology, real-life examples/experiences and advice. It touches on plenty of subjects, but Cain doesn’t linger too long. She explains (putting the science and her own examples to excellent use) and we understand, making it a simple, enlightening and validating read. Enlightening to both introverts and extroverts a like, and validating for all of us who’ve gone through life feeling wrong and guilty for being who we are. It’s short, but it’s sharp and on point, with all the information boiled down into the essentials. There are plenty of sources if you want to dig further into the various studies, but it’s plainly written for the common reader. Anyone who might have need of this book will be capable of understanding it, and that is so hugely important. I’m grateful for this book and to Susan Cain for putting so much effort, work and love into it. The world is indeed built, it seems, to serve extroverts (if you wonder why; she explains that too), but that can change, as soon as introverts stop feeling they have to make excuses for themselves. As soon as quiet is accepted on equal footing its louder counterparts. “None of this is to denigrate those who forge ahead quickly, or to blindly glorify the reflective and careful. The point is that we tend to overvalue buzz and discount the risks of reward-sensitivity: we need to find a balance between action and reflection.”
3.5 stars. I wish the extroverts in my life would read this book.

I'm a big disbeliever in personality types. I think they limit our abilities rather than reveal them and most of the time we end up judging and labeling each other by that narrow perspective we built upon those categories. (We cut pieces out of you so we can box you in a category that's easier to judge)..So if I am to review the book from that standpoint ;it is a disaster. It builds walls between the camp of doers and the camp of thinkers, it fuels prejudice, and it disconnects us from being a beautiful spectrum of integrated uniqueness to individualistic unconnected dots. But that's not the case. Susan here is not really on a mission to gather Introverts on a plan of revenge as I thought she was. But she's here to tell us that if you would rather read a book under the blanket than joining the party next door, or if you'd rather study alone than in a group, or if you like to watch a movie in total silence and take long walks alone, then it's Ok... Actually it's more than Ok, it's awesome! On a small scale, this book is a guide for Introverts to get to know themselves (and feel less guilty and more compassionate about it). And a guide for extroverts to know why their friends keep their cellphones closed on weekends. On a large scale, this is a book for the world to stop the freaking extrovert culture madness! JUST STOP IT! When Introverts are left unrecognised we all suffer. When we don't give Introverts the chance to succeed the way they are, quietly and softly, we risk destroying the next E=mc2 or the next harry potter series or the next peace activist who will bring independence to his poor and scattered home land. My only complain here is the use of what seemed unpublished research work or weak social experiments. Some of the cited social work is not mature enough to establish facts or support theories. Also some of the experiments conducted in the book looked naive to me and unconvincing. Since the topic here is a cultural and social aspect of human identity I'd expected more qualitative data than quantitative data. And the qualitative data to be of more value. The stories in the book are great but they are not enough, that made me feel that Susan might have been trying to push the limits to prove something that was not really scientifically proven. However, my view changed when she started reality-talking Introverts. She encouraged Introverts to do extroverted stuff if it's essential to our goals and that sometimes we will have to put down our quietness and yell and shout and scream. So I think I'm comfortable with the facts she tried to pursue. "We know from myths and fairy tales that there are many different kinds of powers in this world. One child is given a light saber, another a wizard’s education. The trick is not to amass all the different kinds of available power, but to use well the kind you’ve been granted. Introverts are offered keys to private gardens full of riches. To possess such a key is to tumble like Alice down her rabbit hole. She didn’t choose to go to Wonderland—but she made of it an adventure that was fresh and fantastic and very much her own.Lewis Carroll was an introvert, too, by the way. Without him, there would be no Alice in Wonderland. And by now, this shouldn’t surprise "

Have you seen the movie Cast Away with Tom Hanks? That's the one where he's stranded on a deserted island and tries mightily to get off of it for seven years. When I saw that, my first question was, "Why are you trying to leave?" I mean, come on, peace and quiet at last!I'm an introvert. Other introverts think I'm too introverted. Back in the 1980s I had knee surgery and didn't leave the house for three weeks when my college roommates went home. We didn't have cable TV or personal computers, nevermind the internet. I was happily alone. My girlfriend at the time said she could envision me living alone on an island. Little did she know what that dude on Bosom Buddies had in store for me!So yeah, I liked this book. Shocking.As I was reading along, I would occasionally post excerpts on Facebook and ask people their thoughts or if they saw these same tendencies in their kids when Cain talks about how they followed babies into adulthood to see how they'd turn out on the extrovert-introvert scale. Stuff like that. I got some interesting answers from parents and teachers and psychologists, and it sparked some wide-ranging discussions.But the extroverts? Man, they had FITS. I hadn't noticed, but apparently a lot of them are feeling rather put-upon by all these introverts coming out of the closet and organizing into online groups. I kind of surprised myself by feeling no pity.My school was dominated by extroverts and their rules. So yeah, a lot of this book rang true. Hell, even my math class had a portion of the grade set aside for "class participation." It wasn't enough to know the damn equations, you had to participate. And even when you tried, if you didn't do it right according to the outgoing teacher, you got a poor grade. So why should I even bother? I'm incredibly uncomfortable already and you're still not going to give me a grade as good as the doofus sitting in the next desk because he always raises his hand and puts wrong equations on the board? Screw that.Hm... I may have some repressed stuff here that I didn't know was lurking under the surface.And that's because we live in an extroverted world run by extroverts. Which is pretty much Cain's central thesis, which is so true it hurts. Yet I've had a number of extroverts protest this. It's exactly like White Privilege: if you don't see the problem, you ARE the problem."Why don't you try to understand extroverts?" one of my theatre friends proclaimed.Um, because I don't have to. You guys broadcast everything all the time. You're always thinking out loud and organizing things and woo-hooing all over the place that it's impossible to escape you. the reason we introverts enjoy the internet so much is because we can indulge at our convenience and take it at our speed. It's asynchronous and we can wade in when we've recharged out batteries.Quiet has a lot of science and study to back up what we already know is true, which is good. Cain also challenges us -- introverts and extroverts alike -- to consider the world from the other perspective, because we truly do have strengths and weaknesses that make us better as a whole.It's just that introverts are better. But you knew that.

If you have found this review and if you are contemplating the investment of reading time, don’t hesitate any longer.“Quiet” is thought-provoking and rich. I hope it promotes a shift back from our current culture of personality to a culture of character. I know it’s doubtful, but one can hope. “Quiet” encourages us, from schools to the workplace to our everyday interactions, to reconsider our thinking about introverts. It’s an argument that the world would be a better place if we celebrated all aspects of humanity and understood that we need all types of brainpower and all types of character traits in order to move ahead. “Quiet” is one of those non-fiction reads that provides a new prism in which to view the world and I highly recommend it.This review is being posted to suggest another audience for “Quiet:” fiction writers.If you read “Quiet” and if you write fiction, you might never think about any characters you develop without thinking about where and how they fall within the world of introverts, extroverts and ambiverts (individuals who don’t lean one way or the other).From Susan Cain’s “Note on the Words Introvert and Extrovert” from the end of “Quiet.”The book “focuses on the person who recognizes him- or herself somewhere in the following constellation of attributes: reflective, cerebral, bookish, unassuming, sensitive, thoughtful, serious, contemplative, subtle, introspective, inner-directed, gentle, calm, modest, solitude-seeking, shy, risk-averse, thin-skinned. Quiet is also about this person’s opposite number: the ‘man of action’ who is ebullient, expansive, sociable, gregarious, excitable, dominant, assertive, active, risk-taking, thick-skinned, outer-directed, lighthearted, bold, and comfortable in the spotlight.”Cain uses “introvert” and “extrovert” in broad terms but I’m recommending this book to any writer who is trying to think through a character under development—where does your antagonist or protagonist or other minor character fall within the options available? “Quiet” is a handbook, based on science and lots of research, about personality types and how they function.And, as with a lot of great fictional characters, it comes down to the inner life versus the outer life. A solid contrast between the two always makes for a juicy character. “Whoever you are,” Cain writes, “bear in mind that appearance is not reality. Some people act like extroverts, but the efforts costs them in energy, authenticity, and even physical health. Others seem aloof or self-contained, but their inner landscapes are rich and full of drama. So the next time you see a person with a composed face and a soft voice, remember that inside her mind she mind be solving an equation, composing a sonnet, designing a hat. She might, that is, be deploying the powers of quiet.”It’s a fascinating read—and an excellent breakdown of how to think about characters and you might cast them in your story.

I was once an introvert. "Reserved" was the term my mother used, reflecting her New England background. She was armed with many reasons about how she was unable to change from that temperament herself. By contrast, my father was quite gregarious. When I was a teenager, I was in awe of his ability to talk with strangers. Happily, as I got out in the world, I became more like my father. It has been a good thing indeed. But I still treasure my time to be alone, to read and think. I guess I'm an ambivert.As for my mother's excuses, and others I see proffered by some other introverts, I have always liked this scene from Pride & Prejudice in which Elizabeth Bennet is playing the pianoforte under the critical eye and ear of Lady Catherine de Bourgh at her Rosings estate. And commands the intense gaze of Darcy.ELIZABETH: First time I ever saw Mr Darcy was at a ball, where he danced only four dances... [Colonel Fitzwilliam laughs.] ELIZABETH: ...though gentlemen were scarce, and more than one lady was in want of a partner. [Darcy fiddles with his signet ring, pondering her statement.] ELIZABETH: I am sorry to pain you, but so it was.COL. FITZWILLIAM: I can well believe it.MR DARCY: I fear I am ill qualified to recommend myself to strangers.ELIZABETH: Shall we ask him why? [Elizabeth plays a few more chords.] ELIZABETH: Why a man of sense and education, who has lived in the world, should be ill qualified to recommend himself to strangers? [Elizabeth finishes the chords.]MR DARCY: I'm…I have not that talent, which some possess, of conversing easily with strangers. ELIZABETH: Well, I do not play this instrument so well as I should wish to, but I have always supposed that to be my own fault, because I would not take the trouble of practising.-----------Looking back, I think I was a lot like Darcy, even though bored by high school, I was the class clown and enjoyed telling humorous stories to a couple of friends during lunch break. When I was in college I met a new student who was bold enough to confront me about my reserve. "Its a form of egotism," he told me. I was not offended, only surprised by his insight. Darcy, indeed. It would take many years and life experiences to come fully out of my reserve and be at ease with people, including those I just met and strangers in public settings. I know others will differ, but I've had a much happier life as a result of this change. As Elizabeth says, it was a matter of the willingness to practice.

The GoodThe beginning, detailing the rise of the salesmen ideal in the United States and it's correlation with vapid consumerism, is fascinating. It brings attention to the issue of different work styles and provides tips for teachers and managers to get the best out of the half of their employees that do not do well under social pressure. It addresses causes of cultural clash in college environments of Caucasians and second generation Asian Americans, who feel disillusioned when meritocracy gives way to charismatic schmoozing in even our most lauded universities.It blows the lid off of the idea of 'Group Think' being more effective than solo idea generationIt brings your attention to a lot fascinating personality studies that can help explain some behaviors that could potentially help the reader relate better with others.The BadAlthough the first section is critical of the self help industry, the second, third, and fourth parts sound a lot like self help much of the time. She IS a consultant after all. For a book about trying to value introverts, barely ten pages go by without some form of advice, encouragement, or role models for introverts to fake being extroverted. The book I checked out to say 'Yes it's okay to be you' really ends up saying 'No. No it's not.'My Biggest Pet Peeve:Her case studies suck. Everyone is a "High Powered Lawyer" or a "Highly Successful Consultant with Clients like Famous Millionaire" "An Incredibly savvy Hedgefund Manager" or "An Ivy League Professor whose lectures receive standing ovations!" The only people who probably don't have a million to their name are the kids, and they're all Ivy Leaguers whose parents have similarly 1 percenter occupations as all the other subjects. I understand write what you know, but it would have been nice if the author had bothered, even for one or two chapters, to explore the majority of introverts who earn $30,000 a year, not $300,000. She doesn't even cover any NORMAL Lawyer or NORMAL Doctors. It's like she conducted all her interviews on yachts. This is the Achilles heel of the book, and a huge insight into the author gilded rose colored glasses. If you happen to be a millionaire performance artist/consultant who likes to take walks, you will find the subjects of this book familiar. If you're like the rest of us (A high school teacher, a factory worker, a harried secretary, a nurse, or a waiter) you will possibly find the message condescending and incredibly alienating. I sure did.

Last year I read a book on introversion called The Introvert Advantage: How to Thrive in an Extrovert World, and I went into this expecting plenty of repetition, but I was willing to give it a try because I'd heard the author on NPR, so I thought the book might be more scholarly. I suppose I was somewhat right on both counts. Both books contained roughly the same biological description of introversion - greater sensitivity to stimuli and a more pronounced fear center - and both had the self-help sections you'd expect: work, relationships, and parenting. The main difference was that this book gave more of a cultural analysis, showing how both classrooms and the business market favor extroverts. In other words, it's not necessarily the person with the best ideas who succeeds but the person who presents them best. Often that's bad news not just for the overlooked introvert but for everybody who didn't take the time to listen to what might have been a better idea. The author, who was an attorney on Wall Street, blames the financial crisis on precisely that dynamic. To some, this may sound like an oversimplification, but as someone who's been pretty much ignored most of my life, I think it's quite likely to be true.Introverts reading this book might not discover anything new about themselves. The biggest insight I got was about extroversion, i.e. that whereas our fear centers are more active, their reward centers are more active. One psychologist even theorizes that reward-seeking is the definition of extroversion. I'm married to an extrovert, and like the Wall Street insight, it may seem like an oversimplification, but I think it's probably true.Even though I didn't find this book to be such a life-changer, I really do admire the author, and not just because she's the granddaughter of a famous rabbi. She's an introvert who's stretching herself beyond her comfort zone to help all other introverts do the same and to help the world to listen to us more closely. I've got to love a mission like that. May Hashem help us all to succeed.
